Hemorrhagic & ischemic strokes can present with a variety of symptoms: facial droop, slurred speech, aphasia, apraxia, arm weakness, hemiparesis, undifferentiated AMS, dizziness, neglect, gaze palsy. When we suspect stroke, calling an alert is crucial for time-sensitive diagnosis & care. However, being aware of mimickers can help inform a more thorough assessment & provide a more complete picture to the receiving physician.

⚠️REITERATION: If patient exhibits stroke symptoms, call it. Understanding mimickers is for the purpose of creating a more accurate clinical picture.

🥸BELL’S PALSY. Unilateral (typically) facial muscle weakness or paralysis due to dysfunction of cranial nerve VII. Symptoms appear suddenly over 48-72 hours, likely due to dormant virus. Biggest mimicker is facial droop, although patients will often exhibit eye droop, tearing & forehead paralysis (ask them to raise eyebrows) as well.

🥸TODD’S PARALYSIS. Seizure followed by period of temporary paralysis. May be partial or complete; typically occurs unilaterally. Lasts from ~30 minutes to 36 hours. May also affect speech, vision & cause gaze palsy. General post-ictal states may also be confusing for stroke, especially if no seizure witnessed.

🥸MIGRAINES. May present with severe headache that develops over minutes to hours, vision changes, or an aura (may happen before headache). Sensory disturbances can include flashes of light, blind sports, tingling in arm or face, muscle weakness, dizziness. Some patients with migraine may never experience a headache.

🥸AORTIC, CERVICAL ARTERY DISSECTIONS. An aortic dissection that extends into cerebral blood supply (or isolated carotid dissections) can cause a disruption in brain perfusion, resulting in stroke-like symptoms. While these mechanisms are not a traditional form of stroke, they can indeed cause brain ischemia. Other symptoms may include facial pain, headache, Horner’s syndrome (unilateral sagging eyelid, one smaller pupil), & other neuro deficits.

🧐Other mimickers: sepsis, substance use, metabolic/electrolyte derangements, brain tumor, hepatic encephalopathy

What stroke mimickers have you seen? Leave your experiences below👇🏻

Dispatched for a 40s-year-old male with stroke symptoms. Arrive to find him laying in bed, alert but lethargic with facial droop and severe unilateral arm weakness. BGL 98 per FD. BP mildly hypertensive (SBP 150s), HR in the 80s. Pupils PEARL. All other findings unremarkable. No trauma. Patient has history of HTN, high cholesterol. No previous strokes. Last seen normal time < 3 hours ago. 

Stroke alert called. Extrication takes several minutes due to stairs and distance to unit. 

Upon loading into ambulance, transport initiated and IV access obtained. It’s noted that patient’s mental status has decreased. Skin is now cool and clammy. BGL is rechecked (different device) and reads “LO.” Transport is < 5 mins, dextrose is given ✨with haste✨. Mental status and skin improved, other deficits remained. LVO confirmed via CT in ER. No history of diabetes - cause of hypoglycemia 🤷🏻‍♀️. 

Lessons:

•Physical assessment > machines.
•Glucometers (and any monitor) can be very wrong.
•Patients have can multiple major issues going on at once.
•Trust but verify.

DISCUSSION:

👇🏻When have your tools deceived you?
👇🏻When have your patients had multiple major malfunctions presenting at once?
👇🏻When did your physical assessment yield findings that machines couldn’t?

📷: John Moore, Getty Images

Pelvic binders are one of the few opportunities we have to reduce internal bleeding prehospitally. When placed appropriately on a suspected pelvic ring fracture, it can reduce the space available for the pelvis to bleed and facilitate earlier tamponade. Proper placement is critical.

Which location is correct? Why?👇🏻

Phantosmia (“phantom” smells, or olfactory hallucinations) occurs when a patient detects smells that aren’t actually present. They may be foul, pleasant, fluctuating or consistent. This differs slightly from “parosmia” which occurs when a smell is present, but is perceived differently from what it actually is - often due to damage to the olfactory system.

👃🏼COMMON SMELLS:

🚬Cigarette smoke
🍞Burnt toast
🛞Burning rubber
🧪Chemicals, ammonia
🥚Something spoiled or rotten 

👃🏼POSSIBLE CAUSES (not exhaustive):

👉🏻Nasal polyps
👉🏻Migraine
👉🏻Cold or upper respiratory infection
👉🏻Brain tumor
👉🏻Head trauma
👉🏻Inflamed sinuses
👉🏻Stroke
👉🏻Parkinson’s disease
👉🏻Seizures
👉🏻Radiation for throat or brain cancer
👉🏻The Virus Of Which We Do Not Speak

Bottom line? Snoot hallucinations are a relevant assessment finding with a broad range of causes. When appropriate, investigate patterns + associated symptoms and report at turnover. 

Leave your experiences with this in the comments👇🏻

It’s not good for us or our patients. Here’s 18 ways you said you mitigate it. What would you add?👇🏻

Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation (NIPPV, or NIV) can be life- and intubation-saving in pts with increased work of breathing (WOB) who can benefit from ventilatory support & PEEP.

While hospitals often place patients on BiPAP, some prehospital agencies only have CPAP. What’s the difference?

CPAP = continuous positive airway pressure. CPAP utilizes one single pressure, or PEEP, to improve 👉🏻oxygenation👈🏻. If we set the PEEP at 10 mmHg, the pt is receiving no additional support when they breathe in, but they are breathing out against 10 of PEEP. Because pts are receiving positive end-expiratory pressure but no inspiratory support, they may tire faster on CPAP than on BiPAP.

On BiPAP (bi-level positive airway pressure), we have the ability to provide inspiratory support ✨as well as✨ PEEP (IPAP & EPAP) to improve 👉🏻both oxygenation & ventilation👈🏻. For example, we can give 10 of inspiratory support and 5 of PEEP. While we’re still providing PEEP to aid in oxygenation, we’re also providing positive support with each inhalation. 

Who qualifies for NIV? (not exhaustive)

🫁CHF exacerbations. Wet lungs benefit significantly from PEEP. NIV increases alveolar recruitment, opens more surface area for gas exchange, and improves V/Q mismatch. In combination with nitro as a preload/afterload-reducer, NIV can rapidly turn these pts around. 

🫁COPD. Pts who exhibit increased WOB risk ➡️ respiratory failure. Decreasing WOB by providing support via NIV (in combination with appropriate pharmacology) decreases likelihood of intubation.

🫁Can be considered in pneumonia with increased WOB & oxygenation needs.

CAVEATS:

📌BiPAP may be considered in asthma to reduce WOB✨as long as✨underlying problem is being aggressively treated with meds (nebs, mag, steroids, epi). CPAP is not ideal, as it makes expiration difficult without inspiratory support in a patient who already has an exhalation problem.

📌Patients who do not have adequate intrinsic respiratory effort/mental status do not qualify. NIV ≠ a BVM. 

📌Hypotension is typically a contraindication. PEEP ⬆️ intrathoracic pressure and ⬇️ preload, risking further deterioration. 

How do you use NIV?👇🏻

Yesterday I shared a great trivia question on the story from @critical_care_academy about hyperkalemia. He asked which meds result in an intracellular shift of potassium. There was some confusion regarding the correct answer since much of our hyperK cocktails are actually NOT for the purposes of shifting potassium. 

Let’s chat about the prehospital cocktail👇🏻🍸 

👉🏻CALCIUM. Calcium does nothing to fix hyperkalemia. It✨does not✨shift K back into the cells. HOWEVER, K makes the heart cranky, and calcium temporarily protects the heart from its effects (stabilizes cardiac membrane) until we can fix the actual problem. This should be our first go-to to ward off bad juju (lethal arrhythmias).

👉🏻ALBUTEROL. High-dose albuterol (10-20 mg) facilitates intracellular shift of K (from outside to inside, where it should be). It is not given for bronchodilation here. May not be ideal in an acute setting, especially in patients who take beta-blockers. However, prehospital options are limited, so this stays on the menu. 

👉🏻SODIUM BICARB. Not shown to shift K significantly or rapidly, but may play a role in shift over time. 

What will actually fix the problem quickly?

👉🏻INSULIN. Accelerates movement of K into muscle cells by binding to its receptor on skeletal muscle. Why do we also give dextrose? Because it’s poor form to kill patients with iatrogenic hypoglycemia. Not typically a prehospital option. 

Consider hyperK in patients with arrythmias secondary to renal failure, missed dialysis, crush syndrome. 

Prehospital friends - what’s your hyperK protocol? Hospital friends - what else is in your cocktail?👇🏻

📚Source + great reading: 
USpharmacist.com, “Updated Treatment Options in the Management of Hyperkalemia,” by Kimberly Erin Ng, PharmD, BCPS (2017)

Since y’all are being monsters and terrorizing my DMs with the latest fentanyl hysteria vid, it appears it’s time for us to discuss this again 😅😭

1️⃣Fentanyl cannot be absorbed through in-tact skin via casual exposure. Fentanyl patches are specially formulated with high amounts of fentanyl and take long periods of time to absorb through the skin. Casual encounters do not have the same effect.

2️⃣Accidental inhalation of fentanyl is not a viable concern in the casual encounters we see in these videos. “At the highest airborne concentration encountered by workers, an unprotected individual would require nearly 200 minutes of exposure to reach a dose of 100 mcg of fentanyl.” We give 100 mcg routinely for pain. ✨Perspective✨ (ACMT and AACT Position Statement: Preventing Occupational Fentanyl and Fentanyl Analog Exposure to Emergency Responders)

3️⃣Presentations of “exposed” individuals in most viral stories are consistent with anxiety or conversion disorders, not opioid overdoses. “Dizziness,” “feeling like dying,” “racing heart,” etc. have been reported rather than objective respiratory depression. 

4️⃣To date, none of the reported events involving LEOs overdosing via contact on the job have been confirmed by toxicology.

To be clear, we’re not hating on the individuals who believe they’ve been affected. Gross misinformation was put out by major government agencies (*cough*DEA*cough*) and distributed to LE agencies across the country years ago. However, the hysteria continues to grow with every viral video, and with every glove company that labels their product “fentanyl protection” 😤

Spread knowledge. Stop the madness.

Conversion disorder (or functional neurologic disorder) is a condition where a person experiences physical and sensory problems (paralysis, altered mental status, numbness, vision changes, etc.) in the absence of an underlying structural neurological or medical condition. Patients experiencing these symptoms are not “faking it” or intentionally producing them; rather, the problems are real, but are not caused by a medical condition. Often exacerbated by stress or trauma. Affects both adults and children.

🧠POSSIBLE SYMPTOMS (varied and non-exhaustive):
•Weakness or paralysis
•Episodes of unresponsiveness
•Difficulty swallowing or feeling a “lump in the throat”
•Loss of balance
•Nonepileptic seizures 
•Changes in ability to walk, see, hear
•Speech problems
•Cognitive issues (memory and concentration)

🧠POSSIBLE TRIGGERS:
•Reaction to stress
•Reaction to psychological trauma
•Reaction to physical trauma

⏰May appear suddenly after a stressful event, or after emotional or physical trauma.

TREATMENT: psychotherapy to identify emotional bases of symptoms.

🚑Always rule out possible physical causes or concurrent issues (substance use, stroke, hypoglycemia, TBI, epileptic seizures, etc.). 

Leave your experiences with this in the comments👇🏻

Cervical arteries include the vertebral arteries - arteries that arise from the subclavian arteries, run along the cervical vertebrae, and join to form the basilar artery - and the carotid arteries. Under traumatic or spontaneous circumstances, these arteries can dissect - i.e. the inner walls tear away, creating a false lumen. 

This false lumen 1. can decrease blood flow to the brain 2. may create a nice cozy cove for clots to form which can break away and travel straight to the brain (ischemic stroke). Common cause of stroke in young adults. 

⚠️CAUSES + RISK FACTORS:

•Connective tissue disorders 
•Neck trauma (especially sudden movements)
•Excessive vomiting or coughing
•Atherosclerosis
•High blood pressure 

✂️DISSECTION SYMPTOMS:

•Severe, sudden headache or neck pain that doesn’t go away
•Pain behind one eye
•Horner’s syndrome (carotid dissection may cause nerve symptoms on one side of the face)

🧠If a dissection progresses to an ischemic stroke, symptoms may include:

•Balance problems
•Dizziness
•Double vision
•Vertigo
•Speech difficulty,
•Ataxia (problems with coordination)
•Limb weakness

🏥TREATMENT:

•Prehospitally, supportive care + thorough assessment
•Definitively, antiplatelets or anticoagulants to prevent stroke; possibly stenting to reinforce vessel walls

Leave your experiences with this in the comments👇🏻

Pupillary findings can be beneficial in prehospital & emergency settings but must be considered amidst the entire clinical picture. Many pupillary abnormalities are not acute and may be arbitrary findings. Pupils alone are not diagnostic, but should be assessed and correlated with the patient presentation. 

Below are possible causes of pupillary changes to consider in acute situations. Not exhaustive.

😳BILATERAL DILATION:
•Stimulant use (meth, cocaine, etc.)
•Marijuana use
•Dim light
•Brain injury 
•Dilating drops
•Anticholinergic toxicity (diphenhydramine)
•Cardiac arrest or brain death (unreactive)

😐BILATERAL CONSTRICTION:
•Opioid use or administration
•Bright light
•Organophosphate (cholinergic) toxicity
•Trauma or stroke (usually involving pons)
•Age-related change in geriatrics

🤪ANISOCORIA (unequal pupils):
•Increased ICP, herniation
•If a constricting medication gets into one eye (e.g. ipratropium = anticholinergic and can cause dilation if neb gets into eye)
•Horner syndrome
•Ocular prosthesis (fake eye)
•Baseline due to preexisting conditions in some patients; ask about whether finding is normal
•Shape abnormalities may be acutely associated with trauma

🐢SLUGGISH PUPILS:
•Alcohol
•Increased ICP

👀GAZE DEVIATION:
•Stroke
•Seizure activity
•Todd’s paralysis (stroke mimicker post-seizure)

What would you add to the list? What unique causes of pupil changes have you seen?👇🏻

• • • • •

Yesterday was two years of this account existing. What happened on a whim at the request of a few students turned into a community of healthcare professionals from across the world who are constantly contributing their experiences, sharing perspectives, asking great questions, and teaching me in return. Thanks for being here and cheers ☕️ to another year of meducation 🤓♥️

There’s a common teaching that if we give a CHFer a nebulizer, we’ll cause deterioration. The bottom line: there isn’t sufficient evidence to support this; however, there isn’t much evidence, period. 

If the LV is failing, it can’t move volume forward adequately. Pressure backs up behind it into the pulmonary system (think traffic behind a traffic crash 🚗). This pressure forces fluid into the alveoli, causing pulmonary edema. ✨In the absence of concurrent issues (COPD exacerbation, asthma), bronchodilators do not address the root of the problem✨. These patients need nitro to reduce cardiac workload (preload + afterload) and NIPPV to improve oxygenation and reduce work of breathing.

When compensating, these patients typically present hypertensive and hypoxic with wet lungs. But what about when the presentation is blurred, perhaps with a wheeze and history of COPD? Will a neb cause the lungs to “flood” as is sometimes taught, worsen MI, or cause cardiac arrythmias?

Based on the review and studies below (see citations in comments), there is insufficient evidence currently to suggest this is the case. However, no randomized, prospective studies exist regarding albuterol in acutely decompensated CHF patients (like we often see in EMS). Some retroactive studies have demonstrated harm, but we cannot determine if correlation = causation. 

Bottom bottom line: understand the pathophys behind our respiratory patients and the purpose of the interventions we provide, and treat accordingly. No treatment is without risks.

One of the most common grievances voiced during precepting discussions here is regarding preceptors who have a hard time letting go; those who don’t give preceptees a chance to assess, intervene, or learn. This is a beast to tackle on its own, but what about the opposite? When moments are made teaching moments that shouldn’t be?

Many years ago, I was a green medic and an even greener preceptor. I fell somewhere on the left side of the Dunning-Kruger curve. My perspective was that if there was a skill to be done, it should be left for the student. What better way to learn than to do everything? It never bit me in the ass…until it did. 

Eventually, I ended up on a messy hypoxic peri-arrest with a preceptee. The patient needed aggressive airway management ASAP. I left it to the student in a situation where a student had no business dabbling. We had a failed airway for far too long and the patient died. Would the outcome have been different if I had made different decisions? I don’t know. 

I’ve never been one to feel responsible for patient deaths. We can only do so much, and shit happens. But this was the first and only time in my career that I felt near-complete responsibility for a poor patient outcome - that it was my poor decision-making that deprived the patient of a chance they deserved. It’s the only call that’s ever given me nightmares. 

Eventually I moved on, and now I’m thankful for the incredibly important lesson that call taught me. Since then, I have had countless moments with students that were deemed “not a teaching moment” for the good of the patient. There are times when speed and proficiency will significantly impact patient outcomes, and we owe patients the best outcomes possible. And students deserve to be set up for success. 

Weighing patient benefit vs. student benefit is a difficult balance to master. For me, it was a lesson learned the hard way, but one that has helped so many patients after. Some of the hardest lessons teach us the most.

Remember, each mistake is one less we’ll make in the future. We can either let it eat us alive or put it to work. 

What’s a lesson you learned the hard way?👇🏻

A couple of years ago, my husband and I decided we could handle a dog. I saw Lily on a rescue page, fell in love from afar, and we scheduled a meet-and-greet. We fell in love with her in-person (in-dog?), knowing she had a severe heart murmur that would require lifelong treatment. 

We brought her home. She could barely make it up hills. She coughed a lot and had no stamina. So, we took her to a doggy cath lab where she got a valvuloplasty for her severe pulmonary stenosis (the worst her doggo cardio had ever seen 🥺). While still in the “severe” category after her surgery, she ran (and continues to run) around like an asshole, living her best pupper life - with the help of beta blockers 💊. 

Lily is social butterfly. At a fundraiser event for Lily’s rescue, I met Gus. We have a picture together that is the epitome of love-at-first-sight. Long story short, he came home with us as a foster. After determining he and Lily would be BFFs, we adopted him. 

Lily is the annoying little sister who wants to play constantly. Gus would be an immobile potato if it wasn’t for Lily. Gus plays with her in exchange for ear cleanings by Lily©️. Symbiosis. 

Anyway, adopt a dog. And that’s the tale of Gus & Lily.

Prehospital treatment of TBI revolves around rapid transport to appropriate definitive care and reducing secondary injury. While we cannot reverse the primary problem, there are steps we can take to significantly reduce mortality. In suspected TBI, especially when signs of increased ICP are present:

✔️Avoid hypoxia. This is not a situation where we’re concerned about hyperoxia in the acute setting given the known detriment of the opposite. Keep SpO2 > 90%. If BLS maneuvers aren’t sufficient, intubate. 

✔️Avoid hypotension. MAP - ICP = CPP. A “normal” BP in the presence of clinical signs of ICP may not be enough to maintain CPP. Treat aggressively with fluids and consider a pressor when appropriate. If intubating, use extreme caution with induction meds and doses to not cause even transient hypotension. 

✔️Avoid hyperventilation. Hyperventilation increases intrathoracic pressure and decreases CPP. Hypocapnia diminishes cerebral blood flow and oxygen delivery without evidence of improved outcomes. EPIC guidelines do not recommend it, even in the presence of herniation, as risks outweigh benefits. ETCO2 goals should be normal: 35-45. Hypercapnia should also be avoided. See table for more.

Ventilators are the gold standard for ventilating intubated TBIs. Low-normal (lung-protective) tidal volumes of ~7 mL/kg IBW should be used to avoid increased intrathoracic pressure. Rate set to achieve ETCO2 of 35-45 and adequate minute ventilation 🫁 

Elevate the head of the bed. Hypertonic saline can be considered if available to decrease ICP, but the known staples of care and mortality-reducers listed above should be prioritized. Always check glucose and treat hypoglycemia 🧠 

How does your agency treat TBI?👇🏻

Sources in comments.

Tomorrow is no different than today. 

If we’re going to use the New Year as a starting line for new goals, they must be backed by intrinsic motivation. A New Year on its own carries no ownership or accountability. 

If you’re going to get healthier and stronger, do it for you. 

So that YOU can feel better.

YOU can perform better for your patients. 

YOU can give your coworkers the help they deserve. 

YOU can be the best you can be for your family.

You owe the New Year nothing. You owe yourself everything. Go get it. 

What are you going to do for YOU this year?👇🏻

When used appropriately, vasopressors can be a life-saving treatment in the setting of acute shock. Push-dose or drip?

Push-dose pressors are highly diluted vasopressors that are safe to give via IV bolus to living patients. They’re ideal for transient hypotension (e.g. negative reaction to sedation, analgesia), as a bridge to a drip when a fast solution is needed, and as part of pre-RSI resuscitation. While push-dose pressors can be given every several minutes, they should not be used for long-term perfusion management. Drips provide far more consistency without ups and downs (and free up hands and cognitive load).

💉PUSH-DOSE EPI (10 mcg/mL - dose: 5-20 mcg, 1 mcg/kg in kids). Can be made rapidly via code epi or epi 1:1. Best used in not-profoundly-tachycardic patients (but if it’s all you have and you need it, give it). Also the best option for severe asthmatics or anaphylactic patients not responsive to IM epi (tachycardia is not a concern here) as a bridge to a drip.

⚠️Note that this is NOT the same as a “dirty epi drip” which is 1 mcg/mL.

💉PUSH-DOSE PHENYLEPHRINE (NEOSYNEPHRINE) (100 mcg/mL - dose: 50-200 mcg). Pure alpha, no beta. Increases BP without increasing HR; good for profoundly tachycardic patients, not helpful for bradycardia. Watch for reflex bradycardia.

💉PUSH-DOSE VASOPRESSIN (1 U/mL) & NOREPINEPHRINE. Less commonly used options prehospitally, but they exist. Vaso may be preferable for pre-RSI resuscitation in trauma patients.

🚑BIGGEST ISSUES WITH PDPs:

1️⃣Math. If these syringes aren’t prefilled, med errors can easily occur with inappropriate dilution. Use a standardized process and always cross-check.

2️⃣Using boluses as a long-term solution during long transports. The ups and downs of bolus-dose pressors are not what’s best for patients requiring consistent support. Get comfortable with drips and transition when needed.

🤓Using a push-dose pressor does not dictate what drip needs to be started. Norepi is the first-line vasopressor of choice in many patients. If push-dose options are limited, follow-up with the most appropriate drip for the patient, even if it’s a different med.

How does your agency use push-dose pressors?👇🏻

Interpreting ABGs is beyond the scope of an IG post, but it’s critical to understand one of the most important concepts for transport medics: not killing our acidotic patients with the vent.

Shoutout to @coffeebreakhems for his insight on this. Check out his vent book + podcast for more 🤓

First - look at the time on the ABG. A gas from pre-intubation or peri-arrest is not helpful for a patient who’s been on a vent for 30+ mins.

Metabolic acidosis is a common derangement that may be seen in sepsis, DKA, renal failure, salicylate poisoning, etc. How does the body compensate? The fastest way is by ⬆️ minute ventilation. Why? To blow off more CO2. We can equate CO2 to an acid (simplified), & breathing it off is the fastest way to get rid of it. 

But, when it’s decided that these patients need intubated, they are no longer able to compensate for themselves, especially while paralyzed. If we don’t compensate FOR them, we can kill them. On a metabolic acidosis ABG, we can use the “thumb rule” to see if the PaCO2 is close to the latter part of the pH after the decimal to determine if there is appropriate compensation. For example, if the pH is 7.18 and the PaCO2 is 20, the patient is compensating. But, if the pH is 7.18 and the PaCO2 is 43, compensation is not appropriate. Here, we can use Winter’s Formula to get us in the ballpark of appropriate PaCO2 goals: (HCO3 x 1.5) + 8 ± 2. When using ETCO2 to monitor, always consider other influencing factors (perfusion). 

So, let’s say we find a patient on “normal” vent settings at bedside: 7 mL/kg IBW, rate of 16, MV of 100 mL/kg-ish, ETCO2 is 40. Great.

…until we see the most recent ABG.

The patient is in a metabolic acidosis with a pH of 7.17. Their PaCO2 is 41. 

This patient is not compensating. The PaCO2 isn’t even in the ballpark of 17. We’re allowing the acidosis to worsen and the patient to further deteriorate. 

What needs to happen?

We need to mimic compensatory minute ventilation with lung-protective tidal volumes + rates & safe lung pressures. In most cases, if tidal volume is appropriate, the first step is to ⬆️ the rate. Titrate to an appropriate ETCO2 (when reliable) until another ABG can be obtained.

The Damar Hamlin case has created a lot of discussion about this. On one hand, it showed how the expectations for healthcare providers vary vastly from the general population. Hamlin’s cardiac arrest paralyzed a stadium of thousands of people. The crew? Expected to do the job & get back to work. 

On the other hand, it’s our job. “It’s what we signed up for.”

There tends to be negative reaction to the latter statement, but let’s consider some perspective: 

NFL players are expected to take hits & sustain injuries that many of us could never tolerate and get back in the game. It’s what they signed up for. 

Veterinarians are expected to put down the family pet & treat the animal abuse case that would have many of us in a puddle and get back to work. It’s what they signed up for. 

Oil workers are expected to be away from their families for weeks at a time and put their life on the line for a physical job that many of us would never consider. It’s what they signed up for. 

Military members are expected to risk their lives, be away from family & get back to work in an environment that many of us couldn’t tolerate. It’s what they signed up for. 

A job is a choice. Ours is a job that not everyone is capable of, as is the case for many professions. We can’t forget that there are jobs we intentionally didn’t sign up for. 

However, it doesn’t negate the fact that we are all human. 

NFL players deal with lifelong injuries. 
Veterinarians have sky-high suicide rates. 
Military members risk broken families, physical injury & mental health injury. 

The list goes on. 

Both sides of the argument are correct. We did sign up for this, and working in any field is a choice. Our expectations ARE different from the general population, because it’s OUR job to be competent in this environment, not theirs. 

But, even the most well-equipped provider needs a break. Mental health needs time & attention. And sometimes, our differing expectations aren’t fair.

Signing up for a job doesn’t make us immune to the injury it can inflict. We must both acknowledge the choice we’ve made & acknowledge that we’re only human. If the job is worth the injury, we need to work to lessen the blow.

Sedatives & analgesics have the potential to cause hypotension, especially when used in large doses in patients who are already shocky or at risk of becoming shocky. When giving induction agents in shock, full doses can kill. 

First, resuscitate before intubation. Fluids, blood, pressors to achieve an acceptable perfusion status. Fill the tank with volume and catecholamines as needed before we take them away. 

Then, reduce doses. Shock in itself is an anesthetic and may result in catecholamine depletion. Any induction agent can have cardio-depressant effects (even Ketamine). Hemodynamics may already be at risk during intubation due to positive pressure ventilation (increased intrathoracic pressure) and worsening acidosis during apnea - don’t add fuel to the fire. 

The typical 2 mg/kg IBW ketamine dose is often reduced to 0.5-1 mg/kg IBW in shock. Etomidate doses should also be reduced. Even in the absence of RSI, consider starting with lower doses of analgesics in shock. We can always add more. 

The goal is to achieve adequate sedation without killing the patient (or causing transient hypotension in patients who can’t tolerate it like TBI). We can always add more, but we can’t takesies backsies the peri-intubation arrest that we caused. Use perfusion status and shock index to make good decisions. 

Leave your shock-dose protocols in the comments👇🏻

Patients love to bend the rules, especially when it comes to shock. We know what ✨should✨ happen when patients compensate or decompensate, but…

(A quick written overview of yesterday’s reel + a couple extra)

1️⃣Beta blockers and other rate control drugs. These patients can’t compensate via increased HR like they’d otherwise be able to. 

2️⃣Kids. Kids have a higher heart rate at baseline, but if we fail to recognize that the HR is higher than it should be for that age group, we may be missing one of the earliest signs of shock. Did the kid “fall off the cliff,” or did we miss the signs?

3️⃣Neurogenic shock. The odd shock out. Hypotension occurs due to impaired sympathetic stimulation below the injury site (and subsequently unopposed parasympathetic stimulation). This is the same system responsible for compensation 😢. Without “fight or flight” these patients can’t increase HR or vasoconstrict - an uncompensated distributive shock at baseline. 

4️⃣Vagal response to abdominal bleeding. Bleeding into the belly can trigger a vagal response that keeps HR low when we’d otherwise expect it to elevate. 

5️⃣Chronic hypertension. Patients who live at a higher blood pressure may become hypoperfused when they drop below it - a number that may look totally “normal” to us. Clinical signs > numbers. 

6️⃣Hypertensive anaphylaxis. Rarely, patients in anaphylaxis can present profoundly hypertensive. The treatment is still epi to help stop the release of inflammatory mediators. 

Treat the patient, not the textbook 🤓

📷: JEMS, “South Carolina EMS Integrates In-Hospital Sepsis Care into Protocols”

Spent the day getting my ass kicked by scary patients in sim lab. It was 5-star training. 

I know what it’s like to be in a department that doesn’t prioritize education or training. It’s frustrating, disheartening and demotivating. 

The ability to do this type👆🏻of high-fidelity training in EMS is a luxury. As a profession, we should be fighting for it to be the norm…but we can’t wait for it to be. 

Hoard expired supplies for hands-on skills. Find great videos online. Look for new literature and discuss it. Do daily skills and scenarios with your shift. Talk through complicated calls and find key takeaways. Subscribe to continuing education resources. 

One day, EMS education will be where it needs to be (I hope). Until then, it’s our responsibility to do the best we can with what we have, even when it’s not handed to us in a pretty package. 

We don’t rise to the occasion, we fall to the level of our training. We have to take responsibility for our education and own it. 

How do you stay on top of training and education on your own?👇🏻👇🏻

Psychogenic nonepileptic seizures (PNES), formerly known as “pseudoseizures,” ≠ “faking it.” They’re a physical manifestation of psychological distress. Present with episodes of movement, behaviors & sensations similar to epileptic seizures, but are of psychological origin rather than neurogenic. Video EEG is best used to diagnose if the activity can be caught. 

🧠COMORBIDITIES: PNES patients often have associated mental health ailments. Depression, PTSD, dissociative and personality disorders are common. Many patients have a history of physical and/or sexual abuse. 

👀UNRELIABLE INDICATORS: self-harm, incontinence can be associated with PNES or neurogenic seizures. 

🧐CLINICAL FEATURES (⚠️NOT diagnostic):
•Ability of provider to alter/halt patient’s motor activity
•Asynchronous limb movements
•Closed eyes during seizure activity, eyes resistant to opening
•Avoidance behavior during activity
•Emotional or situational trigger
•Waxing and waning of motor activity
•Pelvic movements
•Side-to-side head movement

🥸NOT TO BE CONFUSED WITH:
•Frontal lobe seizures (associated with significant vocal and motor outbursts + retained consciousness)
•Fasciculations secondary to syncope
•Fasciculations secondary to ventricular arrhythmia (the death shimmies)
•Patients who have a history of both PNES and neurogenic seizures (common)

💉When in doubt, treat with benzos. This is a safe intervention either way as long as we monitor airway & hemodynamics closely. 

📢Understand that psychogenic nonepileptic seizures are a coping mechanism for psychological trauma, NOT an effort to deceive us or waste our time. The brain is the most complicated and least understood organ in the human body - treat these patients with the compassion they deserve. 

💭Personal note: recently had a patient who presented so severely with nonepileptic seizures that she was intubated by us in the field, extubated in the PICU, then re-intubated for recurrent presentations. Err on the side of caution.

📚: “Psychogenic nonepileptic seizures,” TAOUFIK M. ALSAADI, M.D., AND ANNA VINTER MARQUEZ, M.D. Am Fam Physician. 2005;72(5):849-856

📷: Wikimedia Commons

The terms “cold shock” & “warm shock” have been around for some time, hypothetically describing a patient’s hemodynamic state based on clinical findings. This has been found to be unreliable in determining true SVR and CO, though, and the 2020 Surviving Sepsis guidelines recommend moving away from this terminology. 

Does it matter in the prehospital setting?

Not particularly. 

What matters is identifying the possible range of sepsis & septic shock presentations (warm or cold), understanding how they may be altered by factors that inhibit compensation, and feeling confident to call a sepsis alert based on physical findings + history. Sepsis ≠ septic shock, but both are important to identify. Sepsis is an infection gone systemic; septic shock is when it becomes so severe that end-organ perfusion is impeded, largely by vasodilation.

🦠COMMON SOURCES:

•Pneumonia, other 🫁 infections
•UTI
•Skin infections
•Indwelling devices (PICC line, foley)
•Abdominal infections
•The Virus Of Which We Do Not Speak

🤒SIGNS & SYMPTOMS:

•Altered mental status, delirium (may be first sign in geriatrics)
•Tachycardia (unless inhibited by rate control drugs)
•Tachypnea, hypocapnia
•Fever, hypothermia (decompensation), normothermia
•Symptoms associated with source
•Warm, flushed skin or cold, ✨shocky✨ skin 
•Normotension or hypotension (if progressed to shock); remember that the threshold for “hypotension” may vary for patients with baseline HTN

🚑If a patient presents as septic, attempt to ID source, call an alert, and give responsible IV fluids. Calling an alert decreases time to antibiotics 🥳

🚑If a patient presents with septic shock, O2, fluids & possibly pressors are appropriate. Order of operations depends on severity. Do not withhold pressors until fluid bolus is in if patient is circling the drain. Norepi typically pressor of choice due to limited beta effects in presence of tachycardia. 

👶🏽 NOTE: This terminology is still common when discussing kids. “Cold shock” = ⬇️ CO, ⬆️ SVR. “Warm shock” = ⬆️ CO, ⬇️ SVR. The former may be more likely to be treated with epi (to ⬆️ CO) while the latter may be more likely to get norepi (to ⬆️ SVR). 

Sources in comments.

Follower found Bigfoot! Posterior MIs are commonly associated with other obvious ischemia visible on a normal left-sided EKG, rendering a posterior EKG unnecessary. While anterior depression is suspicious, there are other causes. A negative posterior EKG does not rule out an MI, but in cases like this, a positive finding can certainly speed up the process. (Elevation in III + high lateral depression is a red flag, but the posterior elevation seals the deal for a STEMI alert).

When do you use posterior EKGs?👇🏻

Excited (or agitated) delirium (ExDS) is an acute state of confusion associated with intense paranoia, hallucinations, and violence toward objects and people. Patients are often aggressive, incoherent, uncooperative, have unusually high pain tolerances, and cannot be deescalated via logical means. 

Excited delirium ≠ patients who are simply high, agitated, uncooperative, etc. These patients need verbal deescalation and, in rarer cases, may qualify for lower-level sedation like droperidol. 

💊ExDS ETIOLOGIES: stimulant use or acute psychiatric emergencies

☠️PROBLEM: aside from obvious safety concerns for patient, providers and bystanders, these patients become hyperthermic and, during agitation and struggle, can work themselves into acidosis and rhabdo. If not corrected, this can lead to sudden cardiac arrest. 

💉THE FIX: identification and sedation. Dissociative-dose ketamine or high-dose benzos are common treatments. This halts the process of over-activity and reduces the likelihood of cardiac arrest. Assess closely for concurrent medical or traumatic ailments post-sedation. 

😴POST-SEDATION: while IM sedatives are largely safe treatments, they still carry the risk of hypoventilation, hypoxia, and hypercapnia. Every conscious sedation patient should receive continuous ETCO2, SpO2, and EKG monitoring. Why all three? For checks & balances. Pulse oxes fall off, nasal cannulas move. Ensuring that ventilation, oxygenation and HR are all on the same page keeps our patients safe.

Most complications post-sedation can be easily addressed with basic airway management, as long as they’re expediently recognized. 

What’s your ExDS protocol? Leave your guidelines and experiences in the comments👇🏻

If you missed yesterday’s podcast recommendation on the story, it was EM Clerkship’s recent deep dive episode, “Aortic Dissection.” It’s a quick, concise, and relevant overview of these potentially life-threatening emergencies. 

One of the most important aspects of dissections for prehospital & emergency providers is recognizing the vast number of ways these patients can present. While there is often (not always) a sudden, severe pain initially, dissections can morph into vague pain, perfusion problems, and mimickers. 

What is an aortic dissection?

The inner wall of the aorta tears away, creating a false lumen that has the potential to 1. rupture, and 2. occlude smaller arteries should it extend beyond the aorta. 

We commonly talk about dissections involving the ascending and/or descending aorta, but we can’t forget about all the smaller arteries that branch off of the head honcho. If the tear extends into any of these, perfusion can be obstructed:

🧠Carotid artery ➡️ stroke symptoms

🫀Coronary arteries ➡️ STEMI pattern on EKG; can also bleed into pericardium and cause tamponade

💪🏻Subclavian(s) ➡️ diminished perfusion to affected arm(s)

🔌Spinal arteries ➡️ spinal cord ischemia & distal symptoms

🤰🏼Mesenteric arteries ➡️ abdominal pain from ischemia 

🦵🏻Iliac artery ➡️ diminished perfusion to affected leg(s)

🫘Renal arteries ➡️ renal hypoperfusion 

Medical management prior to surgical intervention (if indicated) includes analgesia to reduce catecholamine surge, heart rate control via beta blocker to reduce shearing forces, and pressure control via calcium channel blocker if further reduction is needed. 

🚑Prehospitally, thorough full-body assessment, high index of suspicion, and analgesia are key. 

Leave your dissection presentations in the comments👇🏻

Alcohol withdrawal occurs in regular drinkers who suddenly stop drinking or ingest significantly less volume than usual. Prehospitally, this can present as undifferentiated mental status or seizures, with the latter being the greatest life-threat. Symptoms typically peak within 24-72 hours of last drink ⏰ 

🤒SYMPTOMS:

•Anxiety 
•Depression
•Fatigue
•Irritability 
•Shaking or tremors
•Mood swings
•Nightmares 
•Brain fog
•Sweating or clammy skin
•Headache
•Insomnia
•Nausea, vomiting
•Pallor
•Tachycardia, tachypnea

😰DELIRIUM TREMENS: form of serious withdrawal symptoms that typically occur 48-96 hours after the last drink. Symptoms include delirium, deep sleep for prolonged periods, hallucinations, and worsening of symptoms listed above. 

⚠️SEIZURES: most common 12-48 hours after drinking, with or without DTs.

🚑TREATMENT: benzos for significant withdrawal symptoms (even without seizure activity for prevention and comfort), IV fluids as needed, glucose check and management, EKG monitoring, electrolyte management in ER, encourage safe withdrawal practices (medically managed)

🍺POSSIBLE COMORBIDITIES: alcoholic cardiomyopathy, liver disease, neuropathy, Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome (alcoholic encephalopathy that can lead to permanent brain damage), esophageal varices 

🏥IFT: These patients often require interfacility transport for other reasons and may be difficult to sedate. Add benzos if not already initiated. 

💭Addiction is a disease. No one wakes up and thinks “I’d like to be dependent on X substance just to survive every day for the rest of my life.” Just because one person is able to say no doesn’t mean another person has the same capabilities (nature, nurture). To assume that everyone’s life experiences and biology puts them on an equal playing field is simply inaccurate. Be kind. 

What are your experiences with alcohol withdrawal?👇🏻

During my college years, I spent my summers working at a camp for kids with disabilities. To this day it holds the #1 spot for most exhausting and gratifying job I’ve ever had.

One summer, I received a painfully blunt performance review. It went something like “you make things more dramatic than they need to be. You come up with a lot of problems but never any solutions.”

I was ✨mortified✨. It was 100% accurate. And that college-kid-summer-job review changed how I operated moving forward - at work, in my relationships, in life. 

When we present problems chronically without solutions, we’re perceived as complainers. When we present problems in conjunction with viable solutions, we’re perceived as analytical. One is far more likely to breed negativity, while the other is far more likely to yield positive results for everyone.

Perspective is everything. Think negatively ➡️ feel negatively ➡️ exude negativity. When we flip the script and start looking for solutions instead of problems, we can dig ourselves out of a hole that’s holding us back, both personally and professionally.

When possible, present problems only with a potential solution. Find answers, be a part of them, and watch yourself grow 🌱

“High flow nasal cannula” in the prehospital setting typically refers to a normal nasal cannula set at 15L of flow for the purposes of preoxygenation or apneic oxygenation. This is a great tool in many circumstances. 

However, it’s not a tool for long-term use. Typical nasal cannulas are not designed to deliver high levels of flow, and without humidification and warmth, it can be irritating over a long period of time. 

A true HFNC is designed to deliver significantly higher flow rates of air while warming, humidifying, and allowing FiO2 to be titrated as needed. Peds can generally get up to ~25L of flow, adults up to ~60L (varies by cannula size and device). 

Pictured is the AirVo2. We choose a correctly sized cannula (an adult and pedi example seen here) and set the appropriate mode (adult or ped). We choose flow rate (AIR - not O2), temperature, then titrate level of OXYGEN liter flow from an outside source to achieve the desired FiO2 (calculated and displayed by the machine).

Who benefits from HFNC?

Patients who don’t quite need NIPPV but need a little extra help. Super common in respiratory kiddos (bronchiolitis, RSV - sometimes they just need a reminder to breathe), pneumonia patients, and even patients who would benefit from NIPPV but will not tolerate and don’t qualify for intubation. May also be used pre-intubation, post-extubation, and in DNI patients. 

In the transport world, these patients require calculations and pre-planning to determine whether our oxygen source will last the duration of the flight/transport on the current and anticipated settings. Ensure you know how your device consumes oxygen and know how to calculate length of time available based on your tank fill. 

How does your agency or department use HFNC? What device do you use?👇🏻

Note: screen pictured displays mode, temp, flow rate and FiO2 (frame speed wasn’t agreeing with my camera).

We know that myocardial infarctions can present with a variety of alarmingly-vague and seemingly-unrelated symptoms: nausea, syncope, tooth pain, arm pain, neck pain, back pain, flu-like symptoms, dizziness…the list goes on. 

Women, diabetics, & geriatrics are at particular risk of atypical presentations, but this possibility should be considered across the board. Most medical complaints from nose-to-navel can justify a 12-lead. 

Let’s add one more to the list: hiccups. 

Hiccups have been associated with OMI and non-occlusive MI patients for some time. While they are typically accompanied by other symptoms, the case report below cites the unlucky case of a man with persistent hiccups as his only symptom.

Why does this happen?

Theory 1️⃣: Irritation of the phrenic nerve (innervates the diaphragm) by inflammatory markers released from the ischemic myocardium may trigger hiccups. Hiccups are often associated with inferior MIs, as the bottom of the heart lies near the diaphragm. 

Theory 2️⃣: Ischemia may irritate the vagus nerve (which innervates the heart), triggering hiccups. 

🥸BOTTOM LINE: the heart loves to pull a sneaky on us - even with hiccups. When in doubt, do the 12-lead. 

Have you seen an MI patient with hiccups?👇🏻

Calls bother different people for different reasons. For many, kids hit hard. Young drunk-driving deaths and suicides have always stuck with me. For others, it may be domestic abuse or overdoses or unexpected arrests.

For many of us, it’s also the calls we relate to. The death of a patient who reminded us of our sibling. The kid who’s our age who suddenly lost their father. The couple experiencing a tragedy that reminds us of our own marriage. The patient facing the same struggles that we’ve been through or our family has been through. 

A call doesn’t have to be gory or traumatic or a major event to be “justified” in bothering us. Sometimes, it just resonates on a level that’s personal. It makes us scared for what we have to lose, sad about what we’ve lost, heartbroken for what we know the patient or family will endure, sorrowful for the hurt that other humans are experiencing. 

It’s as okay to be bothered as it is to be unbothered. We’re not weak for being sad or heartless for not.

We’re humans working in a field with inhuman expectations. Trauma, chronic stress, unpredictable environments. Wash, rinse, repeat. Sometimes our walls are strong and solid - we cope and compartmentalize. Sometimes they get knocked down - we’re human.

Stay that way.

Yawning is associated with a host of benign or routine causes: tiredness, certain medications, anxiety, etc. On rare occasions, it can also be associated with life-threats and significant medical problems.

🫀HEART ATTACK. Irritation of that pesky vagus nerve (which may also be responsible for hiccups during MIs) can cause excessive yawning during myocardial infarction. 

🧠STROKE. Excessive yawning may happen before or after a stroke, potentially related to its role in thermoregulation. There is also some evidence that it can occur in the setting of brain stem damage. 

🧠⚡️SEIZURES. Temporal lobe seizures may trigger yawning before, during, or after the seizure. 

🧠🧬MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS (and other CNS disorders). MS causes fatigue, but also disrupts temperature regulation and elevates cortisol which are both linked to yawning. 

🧠🥔BRAIN TUMOR. Frontal lobe tumors may be associated with excessive yawning. 

It’s most likely that the yawning patient is just tired, fatigued, or stressed - but in the setting of excessive and unexplained yawning 🥱 be suspicious 👀. 

Have you seen yawning as a symptom?👇🏻

In the presence of significant burns (>20% BSA), patients can experience massive fluid shifts from capillary leakage and tissue edema in the first 24 hours. The goal of fluid resuscitation is to support perfusion and prevent kidney and organ failure with the least amount of fluid. 

Traditional formulas like Parkland and Modified Brooke often result in over-resuscitation. Fluids should be based on BSA% and weight, but titrated to clinical response and urine output which is not measured prehospitally. Why is this a problem?

Edema forms in the dead and injured tissue of burn patients. Excessive fluid administration can exacerbate swelling and lead to:

⚠️Extremity compartment syndrome
⚠️Abdominal compartment syndrome
⚠️Pulmonary edema
⚠️Cerebral edema
⚠️Upper airway edema (a patient who did not previously require intubation may require it after too much fluid)

Thus, in the prehospital setting (prior to precise BSA calculation and urine output monitoring), the use of fixed rates for resuscitation is recommended. ABLS recommends the following:

💧125 mL/hr for 5 years and under
💧250 mL/hr for 6-13 years
💧500 mL/hr for 14+

There are other acceptable ways to calculate appropriate initial resuscitation; the key is to remember that while timely initiation of fluids is important, it is not without risks. Administer responsibly to avoid undue complications. 

👉🏻Reminder that BSA% only includes partial- and full-thickness burns, and that LR is the fluid of choice if available. 

How do you calculate burn resuscitation fluids?👇🏻

More caveats than I could cover in 90 seconds, but here’s the basics:

If patients are paralyzed, they MUST be receiving sedation and analgesia. Rendering a patient paralyzed and aware is incredibly inhumane. Do not rely on tachycardia, tearing, etc. Be (responsibly) aggressive with dosing and timing. 

Ketamine is both a sedative and analgesic, but many patients benefit from adding fentanyl. 

Benzos have no analgesic properties whatsoever. In the acute setting, most patients need/deserve pain management. Add fentanyl. 

Cut doses in shock (yes, even ketamine) to avoid killing the patient. 

Don’t forget about post-ROSC patients. While we won’t always get to this point prehospitally, some are great candidates for sedation and analgesia. Consider how painful the procedures we just performed are. 

If transport times and protocols allow, utilize a drip. Provides more consistent coverage without the ups and downs of boluses.

Spoiler alert: there’s no reasons.

Why the “sync” in synchronized cardioversion?

Synchronized cardioversion is simply a more accurately timed defibrillation, often (but not always) starting at a lower dose, used to reset an electrically chaotic heart. 

When we hit “sync,” the monitor finds and marks the R waves. When we hit and hold down the “shock” button, the monitor waits until it’s on an R wave to deliver electricity. This way, we’re guaranteed to miss the relative refractory period during the T wave which would potentially make bad squiggles worse ☠️ 

Traditionally, we sync cardiovert alive, unstable tachyarrhythmias (in-hospital, sometimes stable patients are cardioverted, but prehospitally, we don’t typically have a need to zap our stable friends). Our monitors can sync with the R waves of SVT, VT, and a-fib/flutter. Even though the R waves may be irregular in the latter, they are all still uniform and are able to be synced. 

Polymorphic VT R waves rotate up and down over the isoelectric line, rendering syncing unlikely. So, these patients are defibrillated, even if alive. 

Why don’t we sync in cardiac arrest? Some providers do, but the issue is mostly time. We can have our monitor fully charged and ready to go prior to a rhythm check allowing for immediate defib if indicated. If we sync, we’d add several seconds to the process to sync and charge after the rhythm is identified. 

Do the cons of a short delay in electricity outweigh the benefits of syncing in cardiac arrest? I don’t know, and we don’t have the evidence to tell us. Womp. 

Leave your cardioversion experiences in the comments 🤓

It’s been one of those weeks where I feel like I know nothing.

(Again).

I’ve lost count of having this feeling in my career. 

Doing medicine right means embracing new information, letting go of inaccurate and outdated knowledge, and questioning even our most basic assumptions. 

There’s always a caveat we didn’t know about.
An explanation we've never heard.
A concept we didn’t know.
An exception to the rule.
A better way. 
A different way. 
An option we didn’t consider. 
A mechanism we’ve never heard of. 
A quality we overlooked. 
A characteristic we missed.
A process we misunderstood. 
A practice that’s been disproven. 
An algorithm that’s changed. 

It’s impossible to know everything in medicine - even within our niche. There’s simply too much, and the information that does exist is constantly changing. 

The most dangerous weapon in medicine is a know-it-all attitude. It kills patients and stifles the growth of the profession. Those providers are either faking it or are so blissfully unaware of their own deficits that they actually believe there is no room for growth. Scary shit. 

Embrace the feeling of not knowing. Replacing it with new knowledge means we’re learning and growing and avoiding staleness. It means we’re being honest and not pretending. It means we’re being real and setting the stage for a career of continuous improvement while doing the best we can for our patients.

Remember -

Not knowing isn’t a weakness. Pretending we do, is.

Hyperkalemia can present vaguely and variably but can result in extreme hemodynamic instability and death. We are not able to diagnose prehospitally, but in the presence of clinical suspicion + EKG changes, should consider treatment.

Who gets hyperkalemic? Commonly, renal failure patients who are deteriorating or who have missed dialysis. Can also be associated with rhabdomyolysis, DKA (these patients can also be HYPOkalemic), new medications, Addison’s disease, heart failure, and more.

🤒PRESENTATION: abdominal pain, chest pain, weakness, dizziness, arrhythmias, nausea, vomiting…

🫀What about the EKG? Peaked T waves → widened QRS → loss of P wave → sinusoidal wave. May be bradycardic or tachycardic. These changes do not occur in a consistent manner amongst patients. Some patients may progress slowly while others show no changes prior to sudden decompensation. 

How do we treat it?

STEP 1️⃣. ✨Stabilize the cardiac membrane✨ (our favorite phrase in paramedicine) with CALCIUM. Calcium works immediately to mitigate arrhythmias and prevent deterioration of the EKG. While it does nothing to actually shift K back into the cells/lower K levels, calcium counteracts the toxic effects of potassium. It ✨keeps the bad juju away.✨

STEP 2️⃣. Drive potassium back into cells where it came from. Insulin + dextrose is a rapid and effective approach, but not a prehospital option. Prehospitally, albuterol (and possibly bicarb in the presence of suspected acidosis - controversial) can be used to initiate a slower shift.

STEP 3️⃣. Remove excess potassium from body. Dialysis, diuretics, etc. This is left to the ED experts after diagnosis confirmation with labs.

What are your protocols for hyperkalemia?👇🏻

Trauma arrests may be worked if deemed potentially viable. Protocols vary but often include witnessed arrests, arrests without asystole, those with agonal resps, or with non-fixed/dilated pupils.

Priorities in traumatic arrest revolve around correcting reversible causes. In many cases (hemorrhagic or obstructive shock), compressions and epi will do little-to-nothing until the underlying cause is addressed. (On a good day, CPR produces 20-30% cardiac output). Prioritize appropriately. 

What kills people in trauma? (in no particular order):

🫁TENSION PNEUMO. Compressions not maximally effective until tension is relieved. Bilateral chest decompression is indicated in arrest with potential mechanism for tension. Know landmarks to avoid unnecessary complications. 

🩸HYPOVOLEMIA. Compressions not maximally effective unless tank is full. Fill it (ideally with blood products). Stop any external bleeding and consider pelvic binder. 

😨AIRWAY OBSTRUCTION. Patient may be rendered unconscious by a non-life-threatening head injury and be unable to protect their airway. Priorities should include those of a typical hypoxic arrest.

🫀CARDIAC TAMPONADE. Compressions not maximally effective until tamponade is relieved. Pericardiocentesis is indicated. Always consider in presence of penetrating chest trauma. 

🧠TBI. Compressions and epi warranted (nothing else to do). In case of ROSC, strong focus on perfusion and oxygenation. Consider hypertonic. 

⚡️NEUROGENIC SHOCK. Spinal cord injury can lead to distributive shock. If deemed viable, compressions, epi and fluids are appropriate. Multisystem spinal patients are also bleeding until proven otherwise. 

😷MEDICAL PRECEDING TRAUMA. Always consider this possibility and treat accordingly.

🔪Resuscitative thoracotomy can be utilized for fancy HEMS programs 🤌🏻

BOTTOM LINE: Be a clinician, not a cookbook medic. These patients are rarely clear-cut. They don’t come with X-rays or CTs but they do come with multiple injuries. Consider what is most likely to help the patient right now and prioritize those interventions. 

What are your trauma arrest protocols?👇🏻

Early defibrillation is a critical component in the chain of survival during cardiac arrest, but some new protocols are challenging this notion by stating that defib should only be performed when ETCO2 reaches a certain level (typically >20 mmHg). 

Per Hubble et al (2021):

👉🏻The chance of survival from v-fib declines 7%-10% per minute until successful defib.

👉🏻When vf is prolonged, immediate defib of the ischemic heart is less likely to result in ROSC. 

👉🏻Repeated unsuccessful defibs are associated with post-ROSC myocardial dysfunction.

👉🏻The timing of defib can (should?) be based upon the probability of shock success. Theoretically, ETCO2 can guide this decision.

Hubble et al. found an optimal defib threshold of 27-32 mmHg. Savastano et al. (2017) found statistically different success rates amongst ETCO2 levels. When < 7 mmHg, no shock was successful. > 45 mmHg, all shocks were successful. Shocks followed by ROSC were preceded by higher ETCO2 values than those that were ineffective, or effective with ROSC. 

Higher ETCO2 levels seem to be correlated with more effective defibs and less myocardial damage. But, do these benefits outweigh the risks of delayed defib? Research is limited, but as we know, research to support major changes in cardiac arrest management can be difficult to obtain. Are these early protocol changes premature, or are they made in good faith that the benefits outweigh the risks? 

Leave your thoughts (and your protocols if applicable) in the comments👇🏻

Artifact on EKG can be a source of panic and inappropriate treatment. Understanding how to differentiate artifact from arrhythmias is critical in our unstable, limited-information environment. All pictured rhythms are artifact.

What causes artifact? (Not exhaustive)

•Tremors
•Shivering
•Patient movement
•Loose leads
•Compressions during CPR
•Neurostimulators
•Helicopter vibrations 

How to assess for bad squiggles vs. artifact:

👉🏻Look at your patient. If it looks like vfib and the patient is still very much alive, unlikely to be bad squiggles. 
👉🏻Palpate a pulse. Radial, carotid, whatever you can get. If there’s a strong, regular pulse that matches patient condition, unlikely to be bad squiggles. 
👉🏻Look at other leads. Sometimes artifact only affects certain leads, and if there’s an organized rhythm in other leads at the same time, it’s not bad squiggles. 
👉🏻Look for underlying QRSs beneath the mess. If there are larger, more distinct complexes within what appears to be too many complexes, those are likely the real ones. 
👉🏻Look at the SpO2 pleth. If there’s a reliable pleth with good waveform and decent perfusion, it should match the actual palpable rhythm.

What experiences have you had with EKG artifact?👇🏻

Sometimes patients don’t follow the rules when it comes to the colors they present with. Here’s a few abnormalities that may be seen in the prehospital or hospital setting. When have you seen patients present with abnormal colors? 🌈👇🏻

🌚BROWN/BLACK BLOOD. Methemoglobin is a form of hemoglobin that has been oxidized, changing its heme iron from the ferrous (Fe2+) to the ferric (Fe3+) state. It cannot bind oxygen and thus, is brown/black in color. Can be acquired via many meds and substances (benzocaine, inhaled NO, sodium nitrate/nitrite) or can be congenital. May be associated with cyanosis. 

🩸RED URINE. CyanoKits (hydroxocobalamin) are a common prehospital antidote for presumed cyanide toxicity. In the hospital, it’s sometimes given for refractory vasoplegic shock. No matter the indication, it turns urine a nice shade of red. 

☘️GREEN URINE. Meds like propofol, indomethacin, methylene blue (not exhaustive), UTIs with the bacteria Pseudomonas, food dyes, and genetic disorders can cause blue-green urine. 

👦YELLOW SKIN. Jaundice, a yellowing of the skin or eyes, can be caused by acute or chronic liver failure, bile buildup in the gallbladder from abdominal pressure during pregnancy, and hyperbilirubinemia in infants. 

☂️PURPLE URINE. Purple urinary bag syndrome (“PUBS”) is usually a side-effect of long-term catheterization + UTI. The bacteria cause chemical reactions in the bag resulting in the blue-purpleish color (urine is not purple when it leaves the body). 

🥦GREEN BLOOD. In sulfhemoglobinemia, a sulfur atom prevents iron from binding to oxygen, making blood appear dark blue, green or black. Usually drug-induced or caused by exposure to excessive sulfur compounds.

The vagus nerve is the primary nerve of the parasympathetic nervous system. Its primary neurotransmitter (communication chemical) is acetylcholine. Overstimulation of this system can lead to SLUDGE - salivation, lacrimation (tears), urination, defecation, GI upset, and emesis.

What do all of these symptoms have in common? They’re wet💦. What happens if we counteract the parasympathetic nervous system? We dry things up🌵. 

There are 3 primary prehospital drugs that have these properties (parasympatholytic aka vagolytic aka anticholinergic):

1️⃣Atropine. A potent anticholinergic that works against the vagus nerve, increasing heart rate (taking off the breaks) and drying secretions. May be used for hypersalivation as well as cholinergic (e.g. organophosphate) toxicity, since that toxidrome has a nice ✨moist✨ presentation. 

2️⃣Atrovent (ipratropium bromide). In addition to its bronchodilatory effects, Atrovent has anticholinergic properties that can dry up mucus secretions in clogged airways. This can be particularly helpful for asthmatics and other respiratory patients who develop inflammatory mucus plugs in smaller bronchioles. 

3️⃣Diphenhydramine (Benadryl). Another med with anticholinergic properties that will successfully dry up your snot. If you take Advil PM (ibuprofen + diphenhydramine), you may also notice that you pee less at night thanks to anticholinergic urinary retention (…or maybe that’s just me and my walnut-sized bladder🤷🏻‍♀️). 

Hospital and prehospital friends - what other meds do you use to dry things up?👇🏻

Prehospitally, bradycardia is only corrected if it’s causing the patient hemodynamic instability and there are no obviously reversible causes (e.g. hypoxia). In these cases, we have two primary options: a drip (epi), or transcutaneous pacing (TCP). Atropine can also be considered. 

TCP is a temporary solution until the problem can be fixed, or a more permanent pacing solution can be placed. Can be used in bradycardias and blocks of any origin.

The defib pads are placed, but only a small amount of electrical stimulus (measured in milliamperes) is provided at a predetermined rate of our choice (usually 60-80 bpm). ✨The limb leads must also be placed.✨ If we choose demand mode (preferred), impulses will only be delivered if the patient’s intrinsic rate is below the set rate. In a fixed mode, impulses will be delivered at the set rate no matter what. 

The goal of this electricity is to “capture” the patient’s underlying electrical activity so we can take control and speed it up. Transcutaneous pacing only takes control of the ventricles, as they are what provide the overwhelming majority of our cardiac output. Capture is indicated by a pacer spike immediately before what will be a wide QRS complex (due to atypical depolarization pattern). Mechanical capture must also be confirmed by ensuring the palpable pulse matches electrical⚠️. 

Milliamps required for capture (typically ~40-90 mA) may increase, or there may be failure to capture, in cases of poor pad placement, metabolic derangements (hyperK), increased distance between pads and heart (emphysema, obesity), just to name a few.

Pacing can be super uncomfy; consider sedation and analgesia as perfusion allows. 

What pearls & tips do you have for transcutaneous pacing?👇🏻

Needle decompression anatomy, ft. Lily’s bone nomming in the background. She’s not sorry. 

1️⃣Anterior axillary line, 4th-5th ICS. Triangle of safety is from bottom of armpit to nipple line (5th ICS) in men. Nipple line or a space or two above is safe. In women, find the inframammary fold below breast tissue and go up an ICS. This will be the bottom of the🔺. Applies to needle and finger thoracostomy. 

2️⃣Mid-clavicular, second ICS above the third rib. Alternative option for needle decompression. Clavicle extends from sternum to tip of shoulder, making “mid-clavicular” more lateral than we think. Too medial risks poking the heart or great vessels 🥲 First ICS is below the clavicle. Go down one more. 

These procedures are only appropriate in the setting of a ✨tension✨ pneumo which requires absent/nearly absent lung sounds and, most importantly, hemodynamic compromise. Most simple pneumos will never turn into a tension, and these procedures have the potential to cause significant damage if not done appropriately.

Common question: mag or benzo for active seizure in eclampsia?

First, this is typically a non-issue. Eclamptic seizures are often self-limiting (1-2 minutes) and don’t require pharmacological intervention. Once the seizure is terminated, the answer is mag to prevent further seizures.

But, in the rare circumstance that there’s a prolonged seizure in late pregnancy (or postpartum) due to suspected eclampsia, there are varying perspectives. There is rarely one right answer, but here’s my take on why benzos are ✨more right✨:

Prehospitally, we work without a diagnosis. While there may be reason to suspect eclampsia, we often won’t know for sure that’s the cause of a seizure during pregnancy. Is it glucose related? Epilepsy? Drugs? [Insert a bazillion other possibilities here?] It would be unfortunate to give mag for an active seizure that won’t be relieved by mag. 

Mag requires IV access, a mixed bag, and time to infuse safely. It’s not intended to be a rescue drug in this situation. A hypoxic mama is a hypoxic baby - we need to get on it. Stop the problem with a benzo, then reevaluate and consider whether mag prophylaxis is appropriate. 

So, if the preggo or recently preggo patient is seizing, check glucose. Protect airway. Apply O2. Give a benzo IN or IM if no IV access. 

Then, once the seizure has stopped, do a thorough assessment for possible causes and, if eclampsia is suspected, give the mag. 

What do your guidelines say about this?⬇️

Sinus tach has a vast number of possible causes. We must assess for the underlying problem & understand that ✨cardiac interventions (antiarrhythmics, electricity) are not effective or appropriate.✨

ST or SVT? Textbook rates can overlap which means our DDx of the rhythm may rely heavily on history & physical findings. 

Sources (not exhaustive):

🤒SEPSIS & INFECTION. ⬆️ HR & RR are some of the earliest signs. Sepsis ≠ septic shock; BP in sepsis is often “normal.”

🌵DEHYDRATION. Sick dehydrated kiddos can meet “SVT” rate criteria but be in sinus tach and need aggressive fluid resuscitation. 

😬ANXIETY. High emotions ⬆️ HR.

🫁PULMONARY EMBOLISM. Sinus tach is the most common arrhythmia in PE. Early presentation can look just like anxiety - stay suspicious. 

🥵HYPERTHYROIDISM. Metabolism ⬆️, HR ⬆️. 

🏃‍♀️EXERCISE. Giving yourself adenosine or a zappy zap after sprinting to lower your HR would be the same as giving many of these other patients those same treatments. Not helpful 🙅🏻‍♀️

☕️STIMULANTS. PCP, cocaine, meth, caffeine, etc. all ⬆️ HR & sympathetic response. Unfortunately, they can also trigger true SVT. Must use clinical judgment when assessing rate & patient presentation. 

😨SHOCK. Tachycardia is a compensatory mechanism in most cases of shock with the exception of neurogenic. Patients on rate-control drugs may not be able to compensate with HR. 

😤DIFFICULTY BREATHING. Don’t withhold life-saving resp meds from a tachy patient because they’re tachy. They’re likely tachy, in part, because they can’t breathe. Fix it. 

💉BETA-AGONISTS. Albuterol, epi. If your patient has been sucking down nebs all day, that likely played a part in their tachycardia. 

🥃WITHDRAWAL. Withdrawal from any substance can result in tachycardia, acute illness, & risk of seizures.

🩸ANEMIA. Reduced O2-carrying capacity due to less RBCs or sad RBCs can lead to compensatory tachycardia. 

💊ANTIMUSCARINICS. TCAs, antihistamines, atropine. Consider meds the patient is taking and those that we’ve administered. 

🤕PAIN. Pain can ⬆️ HR & BP but it is NOT guaranteed and should never be used as a sole evaluation of pain. No tachycardia ≠ no pain. 

What else?👇🏻

These opinions are not all on this list because I personally agree; they’re here because they all have merit and can bring beneficial discussions to the table. What do you agree with? Disagree? Why? What else would you add to the list? 

No South Pole elves in the comments please.

Ideal body weight (IBW) is the optimal weight associated with a specific height. For males, this can be calculated via: 50 + 2(inches over 5 ft). In women, 45 + 2(inches over 5 ft). There are more precise versions of this formula, but this is a close ballpark and can be done sans calculator.

Ex: female is 5’ 7”. 45 + 2(7) = 45 + 14 = 59 kg. Would use 60 kg for math needs.

When is this used prehospitally?

1️⃣Tidal volume. As patients get fluffier, lungs do not. Overweight patients do not need more tidal volume. Via ventilator, safe tidal volumes are typically 6-8 mL/kg of IBW (appropriate tidal volumes & minute ventilation vary by condition).

When using a BVM, remember that bigger patients do not need more volume. While they may need more pressure to overcome the weight of the chest, we can still cause barotrauma with too much volume. Ventilate responsibly.

Airway devices like iGels should be sized based on IBW. Patients get fluffier, airways do not. A 400 lb (180 kg) patient falls into the iGel 5 sizing, but if their IBW is < 90 lbs (likely), this may be too large.

‼️BOTTOM LINE: Use of IBW in ventilation management is a must.

2️⃣Medication dosing. This can be a bit controversial and guidelines and practices vary, as there are limitations to the IBW formula. However, medications that are predominantly distributed in lean tissue, or those that do not have higher clearance with increase in actual body weight, may result in supratherapeutic doses in obese patients if actual body weight is used.

Meds (often but not always) dosed on IBW: ketamine, propofol, midazolam, rocuronium, opioids. Etomidate is dosed on actual body weight.

✌🏻SECOND BOTTOM LINE: This concept is less concrete and practices vary widely. While using IBW has the potential to under-dose, using actual body weight also has the potential to over-dose obese individuals. You can always add more, but you can’t takesies backsies.

How does your department use IBW?👇🏻

📚 Erstad, B.L., Barletta, J.F. Drug dosing in the critically ill obese patient—a focus on sedation, analgesia, and delirium. Crit Care 24, 315 (2020). https://doi.org/10.1186/s13054-020-03040-z

Sodium nitrite is a yellowish white crystalline powder commonly used as a preservative in cured meat. It’s also used in dyeing and printing fabrics, in photography, and as part of the treatment for severe cases of cyanide poisoning. It’s an oxidizing agent that causes hypotension and hypoxia by forming methemoglobin - a form of hemoglobin incapable of carrying O2. Thus, it’s a chemical asphyxiant ☠️ 

While accidental exposures do occur (rare), there has been an alarming trend in self-harm attempts via sodium nitrite in recent years. Given the number of legitimate uses, it remains readily available. The ingestion of one teaspoon of sodium nitrite has the potential to be lethal in an adult. 

😨SIGNS & SYMPTOMS:

•Cyanosis
•Dyspnea
•Dark brown blood
•Hypoxia not fixed by supplemental O2
•Altered mental status
•Nausea, vomiting 
•Arrhythmias
•Death

🧐IDENTIFICATION: sodium nitrite may be sold in a bottle or package, and may be labeled “curing salt.” 

🚑TREATMENT: Prehospitally, rapid identification and ER notification of potential toxicological issue is key. Poison control should be contacted. In the ER, methylene blue is indicated for methemoglobinemia and is time-sensitive.

Ketamine has different effects at different doses. At low doses (0.1-0.3 mg/kg IV), it has primarily analgesic effects. At high doses (1+ mg/kg IV), it’s a dissociative, sedative, and analgesic. Doses in the middle of the two risk putting patients in an angry scary la-la land 👻 

*IM doses typically higher. 

Pain-dose (low-dose) ketamine is an excellent tool for patients with high analgesic needs who do not need intubated. Here’s why:

1️⃣Does not result in dissociation. Patients remain awake, able to protect their own airway, and able to answer questions. 

2️⃣Little risk of airway compromise. While dissociative-dose ketamine given s l o w l y✨should✨maintain adequate respiratory drive, this isn’t always the case, especially if given too quickly. Low-dose ketamine significantly reduces risk of even transient hypoventilation and hypoxia. 

3️⃣Ketamine + opioids have great synergistic effects. A little bit of ketamine can make a couple boluses of fentanyl go a long way. ✨Fentamine✨ for the win. 

4️⃣Less is more in hemodynamically unstable patients. Ketamine in high doses can cause hypotension, especially in the presence of shock. Lower dosing reduces this risk (extra important in TBI).

5️⃣Avoids patients having to exit their ketamine high through angry scary la-la land 👻. Middle-dose ketamine is on the road from high- to low-dose, and not all patients love it there. More ketamine or benzos can help, but this is simply not necessary in a large percentage of the population. 

6️⃣Less inhibiting of neuro exam upon arrival at ER. Dissociated patients can be altered for a significant period of time, rendering the receiving neuro exam less helpful. Less ketamine = less altered mental status. 

We can always add more, but we can’t take it back.

⚠️There are times when dissociating without intubation is what’s best for the patient, but remember that pain-dose ketamine can be a powerful tool with less risks and implications.

💉Does your department use low-dose ketamine?

Some of us believe in a God. Some of us don’t. Some of us aren’t sure. 

Some of us believe everything happens for a reason. Some of us believe shit just happens. Some of us believe we can find good in anything, even a tragedy.

Some of us believe in Heaven. Some of us believe we disappear into the ground. Some of us believe in reincarnation. Some of us believe our energy stays but changes. 

Some of us believe in miracles. Some of us believe in events that aren’t yet understood by science. 

But we can all agree: there are many things in healthcare & life that can’t be explained by science. Might they be explained one day? Maybe. Maybe not. 

The patient who never should’ve survived but did. 

The patient death that ate us alive but brought us peace through an undeniable sign. 

The loved one who spoke to us after death. 

The one who showed us they heard us. 

The patient whose timing reignited our light and saved our career.

The list goes on. 

Healthcare workers experience so much tragedy and sadness that some degree of spirituality is a must to survive. Whether we find the strength deep within ourselves, in a star we talk to, in prayer, in therapy, in a sign we see, in a dream we have, in meditation, in a tree we visit, in a walk we take, in a scream we yell - we must be able to step outside of ourselves, or reach deep within - and find peace. We can be open to it coming from the outside, but we must also know how to find it on our own. 

What brings you peace in times of difficulty and tragedy? What events have changed how you experience your work and world? How do you make your own peace?👇🏻

However - we must understand that allowing a patient to remain hypoxic and hypercarbic while hoping Narcan will work is unacceptable. Hypoxia is what kills these patients. Ventilation and oxygenation is the fix. If the patient isn’t doing it themselves, we need to.
