Spoiler alert: almost never.

The key word is ✨working✨. If an SGA is in place and the patient is adequately oxygenating and ventilating, there are very few reasons to switch prehospitally. While the patient will eventually get an ETT as a definitive airway, there is little reason to risk complications of the switch in the prehospital environment (hypoxia, inability to get the tube, airway trauma, delayed care, etc).

“But we can just put the bougie through the iGel and intubate that way.”

If it’s working, why are we performing a blind intubation? If it’s not working, why are we trusting that the bougie will enter the trachea? In 2023, why are we okay with a blind intubation at all?

In my program, we’re specifically prohibited from doing this. Preoxygenate, visualize, and do it right if a switch is needed.

When would we remove a working SGA?

If predicted clinical course suggests airway swelling, this may be appropriate (burns, for example).

Heavy secretions, high pressure requirements, inappropriate sizing or unusual anatomy may deem an SGA ineffective. Remove and replace with something effective if ✨not working✨. 

Patient care is never black and white, and there will forever be exceptions to rules and assumptions. However, patient needs > ego. BLS airway > unnecessary hypoxia. Treat accordingly.

A knowledge gap exists in the law enforcement world regarding opioid exposures and management; we (as the medically-trained responders) should be helping our LE partners better help others. Here’s 8 discussion points to share and discuss with our local LE friends and agencies. Less criticism, more problem solving.

This TikTok challenge is still making its rounds and causing hospitalizations & deaths. The trend encourages kids to take 12-14 Benadryl pills to induce hallucinations, with some taking significantly more.

Diphenhydramine toxicity has anticholinergic and sedative effects. It can cause delirium, psychosis, and coma. Effects are dose-dependent.

Anticholinergic effects include blurred vision, dry mouth, tachycardia, urinary retention, constipation.

Benadryl OD can affect sodium and potassium channels, prolonging the QRS and QT intervals. This places the patient at higher risk of arrhythmias like torsades; thus, sodium bicarb (for QRS widening) and mag (as an antiarrhythmic that doesn’t prolong QT) should be considered. 

⚠️EKG may present as a really-wide-but-only-a-little-fast tachycardia (mimicking a slow VT). Treat toxicological and metabolic causes. Antiarrhythmics like amiodarone that further disrupt Na and K channels can be harmful.

Seizures are common. Treat with benzos and manage the airway. 

Seizures, agitation, and muscle compression during coma can lead to rhabdo. Utilize EKG monitoring and fluids, and consider possibility of hyperK-arrhythmias if relevant (long down time on hard surface, EKG changes). 

🏥IN-HOSPITAL:

Charcoal can be considered in early toxicity if airway is protected.

Physostigmine as an anticholinergic antidote remains controversial. Consult poison control or your hospital toxicologist. (Edit: apparently moot point because it’s no longer manufactured? Thanks comment section 🤓). 

VA-ECMO may be required in severe cases for hemodynamic support. 

📞Did I mention consult poison control? 800-222-1222

Naloxone is thought to cause non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to catecholamine-induced vasoconstriction & fluid shifts, but non-anecdotal evidence is both lacking & conflicting.

A 2020 retrospective study (Farkas et al.) found an increased risk of 🫁 complications when higher doses of naloxone were given out-of-hospital. A few days ago, however, @thereal_pragmed & @evidence_based_memes shared a great post regarding a 2023 study by Acus et al. While it was another retrospective study, it did not support previous findings. Patients were divided into low (< or = 2 mg), medium (2-4 mg), or high-dose (> 4 mg) naloxone. Among the groups, there was no difference in pulmonary complications, hospital admission, or length of stay. 

More robust research is needed, but if naloxone isn’t always the culprit, what is? A few possible mechanisms:

1️⃣Aspiration. These patients frequently inhale their own vomit or secretions which can result in mild to severe 🫁 complications. 

2️⃣The patient’s own respiratory effort against a closed glottis after Narcan may result in excessive negative pressure in the lungs that draws in fluid. PPV prior to Narcan would likely mitigate this risk (and angry wake-ups). 

3️⃣Increased vascular permeability due to hypoxia, acidosis, & histamine release. 

Overall, this is a rare side-effect. Narcan should be given responsibly, but benefits continue to outweigh the risks. Ventilate & oxygenate, then restore natural ventilations when possible.

📚: Acus K, Krizo J, Prete S, Langlois T, Pajela A, Mangira C, Simon E, Raubenolt A. DO HIGHER DOSES OF NALOXONE INCREASE THE RISK OF PULMONARY COMPLICATIONS? J Emerg Med. 2023 Mar;64(3):353-358. doi: 10.1016/j.jemermed.2022.10.017. Epub 2023 Mar 4. PMID: 36878758.

📚: Grout, S, Dave, M, Lefort, R. Naloxone-associated pulmonary edema in a 3-year-old with opioid overdose. JACEP Open. 2022; 3:e12740. https://doi.org/10.1002/emp2.12740

📚: Farkas A, Lynch MJ, Westover R, Giles J, Siripong N, Nalatwad A, Pizon AF, Martin-Gill C. Pulmonary Complications of Opioid Overdose Treated With Naloxone. Ann Emerg Med. 2020 Jan;75(1):39-48. doi: 10.1016/j.annemergmed.2019.04.006. Epub 2019 Jun 8. PMID: 31182316.

Fun fact: TikTok diagnosed me with this last year thanks to chronic lower back pain and excessive use of heated car seats and heating pads 🫠 Anyone else?

Erythema ab igne is an acquired hyperpigmentation of the skin due to repeated exposure to moderate heat. It can be seen in bakers and industrial workers, but also with the chronic use of heating pads, laptops (sitting on legs), and heated car seats. Also known as “toasted skin syndrome.”

With the prolonged application of moderate heat, elastic fibers and basal cells break down, resulting in the release of melanin (the dark pigment we see). With removal of the heat source, it can spontaneously resolve. However, persistent exposure can lead to permanent pigmentation or even progression to different types of carcinomas (yikes).

Go easy on the heat.

An incredible case from my friend @doc.resener, a HEMS physician in Brazil:

“We were dispatched to a scene call for a female in her 30’s, third trimester pregnancy, in cardiac arrest at home. I was hoping for it not to be a real arrest - it was.

Mom went unresponsive, a bystander started CPR and called for help. The BLS crew arrived about 20 minutes after the event. We arrived 10 minutes after them.

In a resuscitative hysterotomy, we cut the uterus and deliver the baby to save the child while continuing to resuscitate the mother. The event is relatively rare and no one will do a double-blind prospective RCT, but from the case reports it seems there’s a clear benefit to delivering the baby and removing the placenta, as the pressure over the IVC is released and the need to provide blood flow to the baby and placenta is removed, redistributing the blood to the mother’s organs. At the same time, the team may provide care for the newborn as needed, as flow during mother’s CPR might not be enough.

The current recommendation is to do one cycle of CPR while preparing for surgery. If no ROSC after the first cycle, the baby should be delivered before finishing the next cycle. It’s aggressive but it’s feasible. The incision is a large medial one, the uterus is opened and the baby delivered. The placenta is delivered, abdominal bleeding is controlled, and CPR is continued. Neonatal care is no different from standard care in less traumatic deliveries.

Likelihood of ROSC in the mother increases when the baby is delivered within 10 minutes of arrest. In this case, we arrived around 30 minutes after. Chances for the mother were virtually zero - for the kid, slim at best. But we got ROSC on the child. Chest compressions and bagging were enough to get the heart going. When the nurse said she got a pulse, I honestly doubted, but there it was, drumming the stethoscope. We managed to stabilize and get the newborn to the NICU. Last I heard, he was alive, but only time will tell how the brain held up.

Aggressive intervention is fundamental for good outcomes, both for the mother and baby.”

Traditionally, push-dose epi (10 mcg/mL) has been made in two ways:

1️⃣Draw up 1 mL of code epi (100 mcg/mL) and add to 9 mL of saline in a 10 cc syringe or flush for a 10 mcg/mL concentration. 

2️⃣Add 1 mg epi 1 mg/mL to a 100 mL bag for a 10 mcg/mL concentration. Draw up into a syringe for push-administration. 

The latest EMCrit podcast episode (“A new way to mix push-dose epinephrine from Sam Ghali - commentary needed”) discusses a new option that’s so simple, one might wonder why we haven’t been doing this all along (or maybe you have?). 

3️⃣Draw up 1 mL of code epi (100 mcg/mL) into a 1 mL syringe. Give 0.1-0.2 mL pushes for 10-20 mcg boluses.

Fast. Easy. No mixing. Less potential for med errors from incorrect dilution.

Whatcha think?👇🏻

In the US, epinephrine 1 mg in 10 mL (either pre-packaged or diluted by providers) has long been the standard of care in cardiac arrest. Epi 1 mg/mL is typically reserved for IM administration. While in a living patient, IM epi doses (0.5 mg for anaphylaxis, for example) do not translate to safe IV doses (hypertension, arrhythmias), this concern is not the same in cardiac arrest.

⚠️This post is for DISCUSSION ONLY; don’t go sending epi 1:1 on your cardiac arrests and telling people insta told you to ✋🏻

Conversations on this page over time have revealed that many parts of the world administer undiluted epi 1 mg/mL in adult cardiac arrests, followed by a sound flush or given in-line with running fluids. With shortages of 1 mg/10 mL here in the States (and with how much room they take up in a med box), why not?

“It’ll be forgotten about in the extension set.” Should always be flushed well. 

“Extravasation would be worse.” It’s not great for many of the drugs we give. Monitor line patency and administer meds responsibly. 

“It’s too much drug at once.” It’s the same amount of drug with 9 mL less of NS - much of which would be made up for during adequate flushing anyway. (We don’t dilute amio or mag in arrests when we do in living patients). 

“There’s a higher likelihood of med errors.” Maybe, if multiple doses are drawn up at once (5 mg in a 10 mL syringe, for example). Draw up one at a time for safer admin. 

We know that the role of epi in cardiac arrest is questionable anyway (see: PARAMEDIC-2 trial) in non-asthmatic/anaphylactic arrests. Many agencies have already moved to decreased dosing, and some have even implemented drips during arrest for gentler dosing and cognitive offloading. But, bolus-dose likely won’t be disappearing entirely any time soon. 

Is this a case of “it’s how we’ve always done it”?

👉🏻If your country/area gives 1:1 during arrests, leave your experiences below. 
👉🏻If your agency uses non-traditional dosing during arrests (lower dosing, drips, etc.), tell us about it. 
👉🏻What are your thoughts on the risks/benefits of using 1:1 during arrests?

Anxiety and hyperventilation can be symptoms of an anxiety disorder. They can also be symptoms of things that kill people: pulmonary embolisms, MIs, dissections, etc. We cannot rule out the latter prehospitally. 

Even in the case of a truly benign anxiety attack, let’s consider how these patients feel: like they’re dying. Really, truly, actually dying. Imagine trying to “calm down” amidst the perception of active death. Even worse, imagine trying to “calm down” whilst actually dying of a PE or MI or dissection that someone wrote off as a panic attack. Oof. 

Instead, in either case:

1️⃣Be an educator and a comforter. Tell the patient exactly what’s going on, how you’re going to help them, and provide assurance that we’re going to provide the best care possible and get them where they need to go - or, that we’ll check them out thoroughly. 

2️⃣When carpopedal spasms are present, inform the patient that this is a totally normal and temporary reaction that will resolve once breathing slows. No need to worry - it’ll go away. 

3️⃣Distract. In cases of hyperventilation, especially from true anxiety, calm and casual conversation is often enough to break the cycle. Get the patient talking (if appropriate) and focusing on other topics. 

4️⃣Recognize that some patients are breathing quickly for a reason (see: compensation). Telling patients to slow their breathing simply isn’t necessary - hyperventilation in itself doesn’t kill. Use empathy and open communication to address reversible tachypnea. If it’s not reversible, it’s probably there for a reason. 

5️⃣Recognize that while sometimes anxiety truly is the most probable differential diagnosis, we never know for sure. Do a thorough assessment, avoid tunnel vision, and advise patient of other possible risks if refusing. 

[exit soap box]

Todd’s paralysis is a phenomenon that can follow an epileptic seizure and mimic stroke. Following seizure activity, patients present with paralysis that is often one-sided and may be partial or complete, and can involve just an arm or an entire side. It may also affect speech and vision but will resolve within 30 minutes to 36 hours. The paralysis is contralateral to the side of the seizure focus. 

Other symptoms: confusion, amnesia, AMS beyond postictal state, aphasia, agitation, psychosis, gaze palsy, neglect, numbness, visual field deficits.

The cause? We don’t really know. “The current and most accepted understanding of the condition is theorized to be the exhaustion of the primary motor cortex (or any other area of the brain) after neuronal hyperexcitation in a seizure state, or due to hypoperfusion to the affected area of the brain through vasoconstriction mechanisms, thus limiting the function of that area through relative oxygen starvation.” So, there’s that. 

Prehospitally, these patients still require a stroke alert. Seizure can be a symptom of stroke, and even in the presence of a history of Todd’s paralysis, we cannot say for sure that’s what’s happening today. But - Todd’s paralysis (once confirmed in the absence of stroke) is an indication that the patient did indeed have an epileptic seizure, if there was any question. 

Have you seen this? Leave your experiences below👇🏻

Legit. Here’s a few less-common but totally possible allergy sources. Consider these possibilities in undifferentiated shock or anaphylaxis 👀 

(Note that an exercise allergy is not the same as needing to go to the gym 🫢)

🥶COLD URTICARIA. Localized or systemic hives that appear after exposure to cold air, liquids, or objects. May result in anaphylactic reaction. Avoidance of cold, antihistamines, and anaphylaxis treatment are warranted as needed. 

🥵HEAT URTICARIA. Rare condition where hives are triggered by heat source (hot water, sunlight). Usually localized and immediate, but delayed and systemic reactions can occur. 

🏃‍♀️EXERCISE-INDUCED ANAPHYLAXIS. Characterized by anaphylaxis symptoms during or immediately after physical activity. Mechanism is largely unknown, but exercise may result in changes in mucosal tissue osmolality, which may result in basophil histamine release.

🍽️🏃‍♀️FOOD-DEPENDENT EXERCISE-INDUCED ANAPHYLAXIS. The above condition occurs in presence of ingesting certain food triggers within several hours of exercise. Believed to be a primary IgE-mediated food allergy which may be exacerbated by exercise, NSAIDs, or alcohol. These factors increase intestinal permeability and increase antigen (allergen) absorption.

Lazarus effect is an unsettling phenomenon where someone is declared dead after resuscitative efforts, then spontaneously shows signs of life, usually within 10 minutes of CPR cessation. 

How many of these reported incidents are truly Lazarus, and how many were not really dead to begin with?

Ultrasound is the most objective way to determine presence or absence of cardiac contractility, but it’s not always available or well-executed. Asystole can actually be fine v-fib, PEA can be pseudoPEA, palpated pulses are unreliable, asystole can be normal for some time after defib. It’s possible to see how death can be…misinterpreted.

I’ve had two patients in the last several months that were pronounced dead by physicians at bedside but, alas, were not. One made it to the ICU. Neither of these patients were completely asystolic with cardiac standstill at time of death, and thus, were not Lazarus patients. 

But, when a patient is in asystole, and is confirmed to have cardiac standstill via POCUS for a significant period of time - re-aliving is certainly a phenomenon, and it’s not as rare as we’d think (up to 50% of ICU/ED docs have experienced this - but questionable what confirmation methods were considered in this statistic). It’s also likely that the event is underreported due to fear of legal repercussions. 

The review cited below (63 cases) found that 30% of patients had a good recovery after autoresuscitation - and so, it’s suggested that patients are monitored for 10 minutes after post-CPR death determination for this reason. (There are no cases of this happening without resuscitation attempts). 

There are a ton of limitations to this review, but it’s clear that a significant potential exists. Be thorough in your declarations, and hang out for a bit afterwards 👀 

Have you experienced this? Tell us about it👇🏻

📚: Gordon, L., Pasquier, M., Brugger, H. et al. Autoresuscitation (Lazarus phenomenon) after termination of cardiopulmonary resuscitation - a scoping review. Scand J Trauma Resusc Emerg Med 28, 14 (2020). https://doi.org/10.1186/s13049-019-0685-4

Is close proximity to the hospital a valid reason to routinely withhold meaningful interventions?

“The hospital will just do it when we get there.”

“Using the narcs lengthens turnaround time.”

“There wasn’t time for a 12-lead.”

The reality:

It can take✨significant✨time to initiate any intervention in the ED. Patients have to be registered, orders have to be obtained, and EDs are understaffed. It’s not always fast (and sometimes it’s quite slow, depending on volume). 

The CHFer who could’ve been ahead of the eight ball with nitro and CPAP. 

The COPDer whose distress progressed while waiting for a neb. 

The septic dehydrated patient who waited an hour for a fluid bolus. 

The “not feeling right” patient who didn’t get a prehospital STEMI alert.

The abdominal pain patient who was miserable during transfer (and for 30 minutes after).

These situations (and the concurrent taxi mindset) are not in the patient’s best interest, and in some situations, they worsen outcomes. They risk delaying meaningful care, contributing to unnecessary deterioration, and leaving pain undertreated. 

THE OTHER SIDE: Many EMS systems are also slammed and understaffed. An extra intervention can mean longer turnaround time, and that can mean delayed care for the next patient who may need it more. Providers are run down and exhausted from 911 misuse, and human factors are real. Nothing is ever black and white, and there are times when operational decision-making may rightfully affect clinical decisions. 

But, on a routine basis, proximity to the hospital should not be an excuse to withhold treatment to patients 👉🏻who will benefit from them if administered now👈🏻. Being a taxi is (sometimes) optional 🚕. 

Agree or disagree?👇🏻

It’s common for EMS to treat opioid OD patients who are AAO after receiving Narcan. Many of us were taught that we should always encourage transport due to high risk of re-overdose after the Narcan wears off, but how real is this risk?

Wampler et al. (2011) examined 552 patients who received Narcan from a large urban fire-based system and refused transport. None of these patients were seen by the medical examiner (aka none of them died, presumably) within the next 48 hours. Nine patients did die within 30 days of refusal, but the shortest time-to-death post-refusal was four days. 

Multiple studies have evaluated the same, finding a <0.5% mortality rate 24-48 hours after refusal. The concern for noncardiogenic pulmonary edema after Narcan has also been found to be extremely low. But, statistics on other morbidities (rather than just mortality) after refusal are limited. 

The following criteria have been identified in patients who are likely safe to be discharged from the ER (St. Paul’s Early Discharge Rule), and can be considered in the setting of EMS (but further validation needed):

•Can mobilize as usual
•SpO2 92% or greater on RA
•RR >10 and <20
•Normothermic (35-37.5C)
•HR >50 and <100
•GCS 15

Longer acting opioids like methadone and sustained release morphine or co-ingestions require closer consideration for refusal. There is also limited data regarding refusal risk after use of synthetic agents like fentanyl. Narcan given IN has been shown to maintain the longest plasma levels, suggesting it could be the safest pre-refusal route.

Bottom line(s):

•Kidnapping is illegal
•If patients wish to refuse after Narcan, it’s likely low-risk in the absence of complications
•Always use clinical judgment
•Always advise patients of risks and leave with supervision, when possible

Panic attacks are a common presentation to EMS, but what happens when anxiety is actually a medical symptom? Patients who appear stable are too often written off as “just anxiety” without considering it as a symptom of something bigger.

⚠️Just because someone has a history of anxiety doesn’t mean that’s what’s happening today⚠️ 

Medical emergencies that may primarily present with anxiety-like symptoms:

1️⃣PULMONARY EMBOLISM. Big fat lung clots can be deadly quickly, but these patients don’t follow any consistent rules. They may be hemodynamically stable with reasonable O2 sats. They may or may not have chest pain or respiratory distress, and anxiety may be their primary symptom. We cannot rule PE out prehospitally; always consider it a possibility and look for risk factors (immobility, DVT, synthetic estrogen, recent trauma or surgery, pregnancy, etc.). Remember that lung sounds may be clear, and tachycardia is the most common EKG change.

2️⃣MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION. STEMI is just one type of occlusive MI (OMI) - there are many other occlusions that do not meet STEMI criteria; thus, a “clean” 12-lead never rules out MI. These patients don’t follow rules either - they present with pain, no pain, discomfort in weird places, nausea, dizziness, flu-like symptoms, tingling, headache, syncope…and sometimes, just anxiety. 

3️⃣AORTIC DISSECTIONS. Talk about a variety of symptoms 😮‍💨 The aorta can tear into the coronaries (MI symptoms, tamponade), the carotids (stroke symptoms), the extremities (perfusion/pressure changes), the renal arteries, spinal arteries (neuro deficits). These patients can appear “stable” pre-rupture but still be on the verge of death, and anxiety may be a presenting symptom. If assessment reveals dissection potential, one of the best things we can do prehospitally is reduce HR (shearing forces against tear) by treating pain and helping the patient stay calm.

“Stable” vitals don’t rule-out life threats. When patients present with anxiety, consider other causes. 

When have you seen sick patients present with anxiety?👇🏻

The left and right phrenic nerves (left side pictured) provide motor function to the diaphragm. They connect to the C3, C4, and C5 (they keep the diaphragm alive 🎶) nerve roots in the spinal cord; thus, spinal cord injuries at this level can result in mechanical issues with breathing. Always be ready for ventilatory decompensation in high-level spinal injuries.

Guillain-Barré syndrome, cervical spondylosis, neurological disorders like ALS or MS, and neck or chest surgery can also result in phrenic nerve paralysis (unilateral or bilateral). Chronic concerns include need for mechanical ventilatory support, shortness of breath (especially while laying flat), recurrent pneumonia, and sleep apnea. 

An irritated phrenic nerve can also be responsible for persistent hiccups 🙅🏻‍♀️ Medications, nerve blocks, and phrenicotomy (✂️) are all treatment options. 

• • • • •

Semaglutide is a prescription medication used in the management of type 2 diabetes, but in recent years, has gained traction in the media as a popular weight-loss drug. Brand names include Ozempic injection, Rybelsus tablets, and Wegovy injection. The latter is FDA approved for weight loss assistance in adults and children 12+. Wegovy is a once-weekly subcutaneous injection that can be used long-term. 

💉HOW IT WORKS: prompts body to produce more insulin, reducing blood sugar. In higher amounts, it reduces appetite and signals a feeling of fullness by slowing how quickly the stomach empties. 

☠️POTENTIAL ISSUES: unregulated versions of the drug can be purchased online which may be both unsafe and ineffective. Products containing salt formulations such as semaglutide sodium and semaglutide acetate are not FDA approved and are not guaranteed to meet quality standards. Medication should always be obtained via prescription from a qualified provider.

🤢COMMON SIDE EFFECTS: Wegovy cites largely GI issues as potential side effects. Nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, constipation, abdominal pain, bloating, heartburn, belching and gas should all be anticipated. Dizziness, fatigue, runny nose or sore throat are also possible. 

⚠️LESS-FREQUENT SIDE EFFECTS: thyroid cancer or tumors, pancreatitis, gallstones, hypoglycemia, allergic reactions. 

With the increase in usage of this drug (and unregulated versions) for weight loss, it’s important to be familiar with the potential complications and side-effects our patients may present with. 

Have you seen an increase in patients taking these medications for diabetes or weight loss?👇🏻

Finger thoracostomy is a reliable alternative to needle decompression in the setting of tension pneumothorax. 

True tension pneumos are relatively rare, and most simple pneumos will not turn into tensions. However, we must treat when there is evidence of so much air built up in the pleural space (absent or nearly absent lung sounds on affected side) that the heart and vena cava are squished and there is hemodynamic compromise. This is an immediate life threat. 

Decompression is also appropriate in the peri-arrest or arrested trauma patient with chest trauma. 

Decompression needles are narrow and risk kinking and clogging. While they are still an appropriate first-line treatment, finger thoracostomies create a larger hole in the chest wall from which air (and potentially blood) can escape. 

How is it done?

1️⃣Landmarks identified. 4th or 5th ICS, mid- or anterior-axillary line. In men, the nipple line is (typically) the bottom of the triangle of safety. In women, it’s one space above the inframammary fold. Poking and prodding any lower risks injuring abdominal organs. Clean site. Sedation & analgesia as appropriate. 

2️⃣Scalpel used to incise tissue to depth of rib (no further as to not slice internal organs).

3️⃣Kelly forceps are used to dissect through intercostal muscles as needed. Closed Kellys are used to puncture parietal pleura over top of 4th or 5th rib. Kellys are spread to open space. 

4️⃣Finger is inserted and swept to confirm entry into pleural space and clear opening. 

At this point, the life-threat should be relieved. Finger can be re-inserted as needed. A chest tube can be placed, but this is typically unnecessary in the prehospital setting. 

Does your agency utilize finger thoracostomy? How do you train?👇🏻

WPW involves 1+ accessory pathways (AP) between the atria & ventricles. Electricity fires from the SA node and travels through the unregulated pathway first (no AV node) before also traveling through the AV node, resulting in a short PRI, delta wave, and widened QRS. Some patients will not have any visible EKG changes.

There is no🫀treatment required from EMS if no rate problem exists. But, WPW patients are predisposed to tachydysrhythmias. May be wide, narrow, regular, irregular. 

Orthodromic SVTs (normal route of travel through ventricles) are narrow and can often be treated via typical means without issue (adenosine, ca channel/beta blockers). They travel down through the AV node and up through the AP, and can be disrupted as usual.

However, in the case of antidromic WPW with an atrial tach such as a-fib/flutter, AV nodal blocking agents can be lethal. When the AV node is blocked, the excess atrial impulses (up to 600x/min in af) are forced through the unregulated AP at once, risking deterioration to v-fib.

Q1️⃣: “So if it’s a narrow SVT, we can treat regularly?” 
A: If we know a patient has a hx of WPW, I’d argue we shouldn’t be banking on our EKG skills when the risk is death. When the patient’s stable, there’s no rush. Transmit & consult first. (Adenosine also carries the risk of triggering atrial dysrhythmias like afib💀).

Q2️⃣: “Can I sync cardiovert?”
A: Totally. If tachycardic WPW is unstable, electricity is safe.

Q3️⃣: “What med CAN I give if they’re stable and tachycardic?”
A: Procainamide is the safe drug of choice (slows APs). Amio is questionably safe. In the absence of procainamide or med control orders, likely prudent to avoid.

Q4️⃣: “What are some clues that the WPW patient is in a-fib with RVR?”
A: Wide, irregular QRS complexes of varying widths, beat-to-beat conduction rates of 300+ (one big box or less between 2 beats = not achievable via AV node alone). May be regular ⚠️ if a-flutter. 

Bottom line: if WPW patient is tachy & unstable, cardiovert. If they’re tachy & stable, consult before meds. If no known hx & EKG looks sus (see Q4), follow same rules. 

Sources below.

Today my MI patient initially refused fentanyl for significant chest pain because “you want to give me what!? I’ve heard about that stuff.”

Sigh. 

This is what the media is doing to medical care. 

Pain management in MI is a critical step in reducing myocardial oxygen demand and limiting infarct. It reduces blood pressure, heart rate, and overall workload. We don’t want people with dying hearts to be uncomfortable, and fentanyl is one of several great (and safe) ways to address it. 

But what does social media tell us?

☠️FENTANYL☠️ 

Touch it and OD. 
See it and OD. 
Smell it and OD. 
Hear the word and OD. 

It’s on dollar bills in parking lots, it’s on baby changing tables, overdose patients are covered in it (because who doesn’t roll in their drugs before using?). Despite sparing drug dealers and users who aren’t actively using but have direct contact with fentanyl, we, the public, are at risk of immediate overdose from being in the vicinity. Despite healthcare workers touching it regularly, the public has different skin that’s not protective. We need gloves that are “fentanyl proof,” even though we could roll in it with our closed skin and get out unscathed. Any white powder (which often turns out to not be fentanyl or the like at all) now induces anxiety symptoms and conversion disorder reactions that are advertised to the public as true overdoses, despite the absence of any respiratory or CNS depression. “Fast heart rate, “dizziness,” “losing vision,” “tingling,” and “feeling like dying” are all the new signs of overdose - someone update the medical lit. Why did they put all that money into making fentanyl patches when we could’ve just been rubbing it on our patients this whole time anyway?

It (still) doesn’t work like that. Stop the madness.

CRASH-2 and 3 demonstrated that TXA reduced 28-day mortality in patients with suspected bleeding and mild-to-moderate head injury if given within 3 hours of injury. However, most of the participants were recruited in regions without advanced trauma systems, and outcome beyond 28 days was unknown. Subsequent trials did not show benefit in more developed systems. 

Enter: PATCH-Trauma, an international, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial. 1310 patients were recruited in Australia, New Zealand, and Germany, and divided into TXA and placebo groups. TXA patients received 1g prehospitally followed by an 8-hour infusion. Authors sought to evaluate the efficacy and safety of tranexamic acid therapy in patients with severe trauma who were at risk for trauma-induced coagulopathy.

The groups showed no significant difference in survival with favorable outcome at 6 months (primary outcome). The number of serious adverse events, including vascular occlusive events, also did not differ.

Will this affect how TXA is utilized prehospitally? Leave your thoughts👇🏻

The full article is available for free if you create an account on NEJM - go check it out for yourself.

50ish y/o patient. Woke up with new onset chest pressure and pain that radiated to right shoulder, and chronic upper back pain that’s worse today. History of narcotic use, currently on suboxone. Temp 99.3F (37.3C). No recent illness or surgeries. No know cardiac history. No allergies. HR 75-80 on HEMS arrival, SBP 100-110, SpO2 98% on room air. Patient fairly well-looking with some intermittent discomfort, skin warm and dry. Patient comfortable both sitting up and laying with HOB elevated slightly. 

Differentials? Treatments? Alerts?👇🏻

Needle decompression is indicated for TENSION pneumo only. Absent (or nearly absent) lung sounds AND hemodynamic compromise must be present (exception: trauma arrest). A well-perfused patient does not have a tension, and decompression is not indicated. A simple pneumo is not a life-threat and is likely to never turn into a tension. 

Knowing landmarks and anatomy is a must - needling is not benign. Organs that have been darted: spleen, liver, heart, aorta. Don’t be that guy. 

Option 1️⃣: Mid-axillary or anterior-axillary, 4th or 5th ICS. In men, the nipple line is generally in line with the 5th ICS. In women or any patient with extra breast tissue, it’s one space above the inframammary fold (the fold under breast tissue). This is the bottom of the triangle of safety. Dart any lower and we risk puncturing abdominal organs (it happens). This is the same anatomy for finger thoracostomy. 

Option 2️⃣: Mid-clavicular, 2nd ICS. NOT mid-chest. The clavicle extends to the tip of the shoulder, making mid-clavicular more lateral than we may think. The first rib sits under the clavicle, so the space below the collar bone is the first ICS. Darting too medial risks darting the heart or great vessels (also happens). 

Darting above the rib rather than below is preferable to avoid vessels that run underneath.

When appropriate, practice finding this anatomy on stable patients so that it becomes second nature when needed.

Years ago as a baby medic, I ran an MVC with a DOA that occurred right in front of the hospital. The driver was an elderly gentleman who had run a red light and was t-boned on his side. There was some intrusion but damage was minimal. Wife in the front passenger seat was fine. 

Driver was pulseless and apneic and wife didn’t remember signs of a medical emergency leading up to the accident. No obvious trauma noted to the patient, so it was worked as a possible medical arrest. Asystole, I believe. 

It was a long time ago and many of the details are fuzzy, but I specifically remember another agency member BVMing aggressively, and instructing them to slow down. Being in the middle of the road and across the street from the hospital, we transported. 

What’s not fuzzy: the doc continuing to work the code in the ER, doing a chest X-ray, and finding a tension pneumo. He was decompressed with no change.

Was it there initially and I missed it? Did we cause it with aggressive BVMing and I missed it? I don’t know. I never got an official cause of death, but I knew very well there was a chance it was reversible and I missed it. Big oof. 

I was much younger and greener then, and bilateral needle decompression was not a part of trauma arrest care in my area (we hardly worked them to begin with). But, even if it had been, I’m not sure I would’ve treated that patient as a possible trauma arrest, or had the wherewithal to reevaluate for a pneumo. My perspective was much smaller and more prone to tunnel vision.

But, I learned. That mistake has been crossed off my list, and new ones have taken its place. 

Mistakes never go away, they just decrease in frequency and change. Our mistakes are only a problem if we were irresponsible in our lack of mitigation, if we don’t own them, or if we don’t learn from them. Own it, get better, and pass it on.

Our job is to treat patients with dignity and respect while acknowledging and addressing our intrinsic biases. It’s to understand that patients come from a plethora of backgrounds - many of which we’ll never understand. It’s to put personal feelings aside and provide the best medical care possible to every patient population. No matter how unhealthy the patient’s lifestyle, it is not our job to judge, or to decide who is and isn’t worthy of our care. 

Do first responders deal with these same challenges? Absolutely. We collectively experience food addiction, substance abuse, trauma, depression, mental health problems, chronic pain, chronic health conditions. 

But, this job is a choice. Our job description doesn’t care about our problems. We are ✨choosing✨ to put ourselves in a position where the safety and well-being of our patients and coworkers depends on our fitness. Forfeiting that responsibility is irresponsible and unfair. 

We are all human, but when we choose to do this job, we have to accept the responsibility that it’s also our job to handle our shit. Whether it’s therapy, meds, investing in a personal trainer or a food service, working OT to afford gym equipment, addiction counseling - it is our responsibility to deal with it. No one else’s. 

Personal accountability can be hard, and blaming anything else is so easy. Excuses are the easiest thing to find if we look, but no matter how we slice it, this job is a choice. Doing it right is not.

We all have our shit. How do you handle yours?👇🏻 

I’ll start: Prozac 🥰
A few minutes and the discipline is all that’s necessary. Add yours👇🏻

Heat stroke is a life-threatening emergency that requires IMMEDIATE AND RAPID COOLING. The notion that this is detrimental or dangerous is a myth. The longer these patients are at lethal core temps, the worse their prognosis. 

SYMPTOMS:

🔥Core temp typically > 40C/104F
🔥High temp associated with exertion or exposure to extreme heat (does NOT include fever)
🔥CNS dysfunction (delirium, seizures, ataxia, etc.) - this is distinguishing factor from heat exhaustion
🔥Tachycardia, tachypnea
🔥Hypotension possible
🔥Patients may still be sweating, especially in exertional heat stroke (do not rely on “dry skin”)

TREATMENT:

🥶Rapid cooling until core temp is 38-39C (100.4-102.2F)
🥶Ice bath if available, or evaporative cooling + ice packs 
🥶No role for antipyretics 
🥶Assess for other causes of AMS: hypoglycemia, cardiac, stroke, etc. 
🥶Responsible IV fluids are acceptable for hydration but are not effective as a first-line cooling effort 

How does your agency or department cool heat stroke patients?👇🏻

Your patient has shortness of breath - the list of differentials is intimidating. Let’s break them down. List not exhaustive (no more room 😢).

⚠️Presentations may be mixed based on pre-existing or concurrent conditions. Always consider multiple culprits. 

🫀🚩ACUTE CARDIAC. Do the 12-lead (all SOB patients). Any obvious arrhythmias or OMI criteria? Suspicious cardiac hx? Clean EKG doesn’t rule out MI. Rales may be present if acute inadequacy of LV.

🫁😮‍💨COPD. Known hx of emphysema or chronic bronchitis? If not, known hx of smoking or chronic exposure to inhaled pollutants? Home O2 or neb use? Barrel chest consistent with emphysema? Lung sounds may be wheezy, clear but diminished, rhonchorous, or any combo. ⚠️⚠️Remember that pre-existing COPD does not = the issue today. People with sick lungs have sick hearts. Avoid tunnel vision & assess thoroughly⚠️⚠️. COPD patients prone to lung infections. 

🫁🤒PNEUMONIA. Assess for general illness - fever, chills, aches, productive cough. Lungs may be wet from rhonchi or mild rales (often worse unilaterally). May have hx of PNA or risk factors for aspiration. 

🫀💦CHF. LV failure can acutely present as SCAPE: hypertension, hypoxia, rales. Mild presentations may present far more subtly. May be a chronic condition (check for diuretics, home O2 use) or acute onset (MI). ETCO2 cannula can help differentiate cardiac wheeze vs. bronchospasm. 

🫁ASTHMA. May be new onset in peds; usually known hx in adults. Wheezing, or silent chest in severe exacerbation. Hypercapnia in moderate to severe cases with shark-fin ETCO2 waveform. Can progress to obstructive shock. 

🐝🥜ANAPHYLAXIS. SOB & wheezing possible (not mandatory). Assess for other system involvement (GI distress, hypoperfusion, skin changes, swelling). Trigger may not be known. When in doubt, give epi (also effective for severe asthma). 

🫁🩸PULMONARY EMBOLISM. Lungs can be clear or present with mild adventitious sounds. Can present as anxiety with adequate SpO2. Assess for risk factors (synthetic estrogen, immobility, recent trauma or surgery, DVT). Pain or no pain. Shock and RV failure = ominous sign. 

Add your differentials & pearls below👇🏻

Interestingly/sadly, evidence is sorely lacking in the realm of IM and IV epi for severe asthma. But, EMS sees the sickest of the sick, and this is a tool that deserves a place in the back pocket. 

Epi may be a life-saving intervention in severe or refractory asthma. When patients are so bronchoconstricted that they’re moving minimal air, inhaled bronchodilators can’t get where they need to go. Bronchodilating from the inside out may be the answer, and epi can get it done quickly. Prehospital dosing is often in-line with anaphylaxis guidelines.

Why do we give epi in anaphylaxis?

👉🏻Inhibits inflammatory mediator release 
👉🏻Reverses distributive shock via vasoconstriction 
👉🏻Reverses bronchospasm, if present
👉🏻Improves upper airway swelling, if present 

In asthma, we’re simply using it for its beta-2 agonist/bronchodilation properties. While these patients may also be in shock, it’s obstructive from air trapping and increased intrathoracic pressure (squishing the heart) rather than distributive. This is fixed by reversing bronchospasm and improving ventilation. 

In emergent situations, IM epi is appropriate in the same doses given for anaphylaxis. It’s also safe for the vast majority of patients. 

Once IV access is obtained, push-dose epi or an epi drip may be appropriate if acuity persists (in conjunction with all other asthma pharm). Typically, doses are consistent with refractory anaphylaxis guidelines.

In cardiac arrest, we know that epi plays little role in improving outcomes - unless, the arrest is due to anaphylaxis or asthma. Get the full code dose of epi on board early and deliver it often. 

BLS providers: have a crumping asthma patient and no ALS provider in sight? Give the EpiPen. (With med control orders, of course 😉). 

How does your agency or department use epi for asthma?👇🏻

• • • • •

📚: Baggott C, Hardy JK, Sparks J, et al Epinephrine (adrenaline) compared to selective beta-2-agonist in adults or children with acute asthma: a systematic review and meta-analysis Thorax 2022;77:563-572.

📷: https://radiologykey.com/asthma/

Experience is incredibly valuable, and we all have patient care tactics that we’re more likely to use simply because we’ve seen them work. (“I believe it cuz I seen it” -me, on epi in severe asthma). There can’t be a study for everything, so sometimes anecdote & common sense are the best we have.

However, anecdote ≠ evidence. Our personal experiences do not establish causation. While they may suggest correlation, our experiences are not powered or controlled to determine cause and effect.

Our preconceived notions bias us in our interpretation of outcomes.

“I believe Narcan may help achieve ROSC after OD. I gave Narcan in an arrest and got ROSC. I got ROSC because of Narcan.”

Just an example, not a Narcan argument (there’re plenty of other posts for that💁🏻‍♀️).

What are we not considering? The high-quality compressions. The hypoxia & hypercapnia reversal. The short down-time. The lack of comorbidities. The time & route that Narcan was given, the time of ROSC. When and how did everything happen - did it happen as we think? Or are we making assumptions based on our pre-existing beliefs?

The best scientific research yields reproducible results among a statistically significant population. Variables are closely controlled & analyzed. Subjects are strategically chosen and compared. Data collection is robust and accurate. RCTs give us the most unbiased look into cause & effect relationships. 

Our individual experiences with patients - whether one call or many over time - do not establish causality amongst interventions & outcomes. 

I am not suggesting that we do not learn from our experiences. I am suggesting that as a profession, we are at times too quick to dismiss real evidence based on our personal experiences to the detriment of our patients. 

Things that used to be taboo are now first-line (see: TQs), and things that used to be first-line are now archaic (see: MAST trousers), and much of it will circle back again because that’s how medicine goes. The best we can do is use the most current & valid information we have until we learn differently. 

What beliefs do you see held dear in medicine that aren’t evidence-based?👇🏻
These gave me the warm and fuzzies 🥰 Add yours👇🏻
So much to be grateful for ♥️ Happy 4th weekend friends 🇺🇸 Stay safe.

Side effects of IV opioids given in the emergency setting include sedation, hypotension, nausea, respiratory depression, constipation, and pruritus (itching). The latter affects 10-50% of people receiving IV opioids, the frequency increasing with dosing. 

While the mechanism isn’t entirely clear, it was previously believed that opioid-induced itching was caused by histamine release from mast cells, and thus, was treated with antihistamines. These medications can contribute to the sedative effects of opioids.

More recently, the significant role that mu-opioid receptors play in this type of pruritus has been identified. While giving low-dose naloxone to combat opioid-induced itching may be the most effective approach given recent findings (more research needed), it would lessen the analgesic effects of the drug given, and is likely not practicable in the EMS setting. 

Bottom line for EMS?

Itching (especially facial) is a normal side effect after administering opioids. If a patient experiences it, advise that it’s normal (always evaluate for true allergic reaction). If disruptive, lessen doses or switch agents. 

And if the patient can’t scratch their own nose - help
‘em out 👉🏻👃🏼

• • • • •

📚: Schmelz M. Opioidinduzierter Pruritus. Mechanismen und therapeutische Ansätze [Opioid-induced pruritus. Mechanisms and treatment regimens]. Anaesthesist. 2009 Jan;58(1):61-5. German. doi: 10.1007/s00101-008-1478-8. PMID: 19132330.

What’s the deal with OMI vs. STEMI?

Positive STEMI criteria will remain MI criteria for the foreseeable future. But, it misses true occlusions that don’t meet STEMI criteria, and that’s v sad for our patients. A review by Myers et al. (2020) found that 40% of OMI patients did not present with STEMI criteria & suffered significant delays in PCI. Big womp. Enter: OMI/NOMI. 

Occlusive MI includes STEMIs + other concerning EKG findings that indicate a likely occlusion causing ischemia. N(on)OMIs lack full occlusion or infarction but may still require intervention. This list isn’t exhaustive, but highlights the most realistic characteristics to identify in the prehospital setting:

1️⃣Inferior elevation of any amount in 2+ inferior leads (even if <1mm) + any depression in aVL. Highly suspicious of inferior MI. 

2️⃣Anterior ST depression in V1-V4, with or without elevation in V7-V9. Isolated posterior until proven otherwise. 

3️⃣Elevation in aVR + diffuse multi-lead ST depression. Can be indicative of occlusion, but more likely a NOMI: critical LAD stenosis, triple vessel disease, or global myocardial hypoperfusion (shock, post-ROSC, etc.). Urgent rather than emergent cath likely indicated. 

4️⃣Smith-Modified Sgarbossa criteria in LBBB or paced rhythm. Concordant STE anywhere, and/or concordant ST depression in V1, V2 or V3, and/or excessively discordant STE anywhere (>25% preceding S wave). 

5️⃣De Winter T waves. Present in ~2% LAD occlusions. Anterior STEMI equivalent. Upsloping ST depression and peaked T waves in precordial leads. (Not to be confused with Wellens syndrome which is indicative of critical LAD stenosis). See photo. 

As always, no STEMI ≠ no MI. Transmit EKGs when possible, and advocate for patients with subtle changes + concerning clinical picture. 

Does your agency utilize OMI criteria for prehospital alerts?👇🏻

Nevermind Fred the Head’s ratchet state of existence. Let’s chat about maximizing one of our most basic, life-saving skills that we collectively suck at. 

1️⃣Two providers + two-handed EC or thumbs-down technique with jaw thrust. Opens airway and drastically improves seal. 

2️⃣ETCO2 to monitor adequacy and frequency of manual ventilations (waveform) and to trend ventilation and perfusion (numbers).

3️⃣PEEP valve. Appropriate for most patients to maximize oxygenation. 

4️⃣Recognize that adult BVMs are approximately 3x the tidal volume needed for a typical adult. Titrate volume to chest rise and ETCO2. Use appropriate rate (often much slower than we think).

Shoutout to several of you for bringing this ✨enlightening✨ topic to my attention. 

Recently, the interwebs told us that Madonna was “revived” by Narcan in her home after going unresponsive from…septic shock. 

Opioid OD cover-up? 🤷🏻‍♀️ But where did this idea of treating septic shock with Narcan even come from?

Endogenous opioids (endorphins) are believed to contribute to all kinds of shock by perpetuating hypotension and cardiovascular suppression. Perhaps, then, by blocking these receptors, we can reverse circulatory collapse. 

A 1989 review (1) that looked at 5 patients with septic shock found that naloxone increased the MAP of all patients. 

A 1981 review (2) discussed 3 patients with septic or cardiogenic shock. All three experienced an increase in BP after naloxone on 6 of 9 separate occasions. 

A 1991 review (3) reports that animal studies suggest naloxone’s usefulness in hemorrhagic shock. 

So, there you have it. It appears this stopped being entertained decades ago 🫠 But, you never know what the circle of medicine will bring. 

🚨CLARIFICATION IN CASE THERE WAS ANY CONFUSION 😅 I am NOT advocating for this as a septic shock treatment. Simply discussing how this “connection” even came about 🤓

• • • • •

1️⃣Canady J, Williams W, Thompson I, Vincent GS, Hoover E. Use of naloxone in septic shock. J Natl Med Assoc. 1989 Jun;81(6):669-73. PMID: 2746688; PMCID: PMC2625808.

2️⃣Higgins TL, Sivak ED. Reversal of hypotension with naloxone. Cleve Clin Q. 1981 Summer;48(2):283-8. doi: 10.3949/ccjm.48.2.283. PMID: 7296869.

3️⃣Reghunandanan, R., Reghunandanan, V., & Marya, R. K. (1991). Opioid antagonism in haemorrhagic shock. Current Science, 61(7), 467–471. http://www.jstor.org/stable/24095228

4️⃣Holaday JW. Opiate antagonists in shock and trauma. Am J Emerg Med. 1984 Jan;2(1):8-12. doi: 10.1016/0735-6757(84)90104-9. PMID: 6097276.

Thanks to @armyemdoc for tagging me in his post on this. We ALWAYS be looking for more support for CPRIC sedation here 😏 

Our management of cardiac arrest and high-quality compressions is improving, and cerebral perfusion during arrest is also improving. In some patients, this results in outward signs of awareness, ranging from subtle movements or eye opening to full interference with resuscitation. Consciousness dissipates when compressions are ceased. 

This new paper confirms what we already knew, but also suggests that some patients may be aware during resuscitation without it being obvious to clinicians. (Eek). 

Many agencies already have CPR-induced consciousness protocols to include ketamine and/or midazolam and fentanyl for those patients with signs of awareness. We don’t yet know what the best cocktail is, but knowingly allowing a patient to experience their own resuscitation is inhumane, and awareness interfering with resuscitation risks worsening outcomes. 

Don’t yet have guidelines for this? Bring this paper to your medical director and discuss 🤓

Ejections are some of the highest-mechanism traumas we see - 70% will die according to NHTSA. Occupants are typically unrestrained, rollover is often involved, and single-vehicle is common. Let’s discuss some considerations. 

1️⃣Trauma should be expected to be global. Neuro, hemorrhage, ortho - it’s likely to all be present, even if not outwardly evident. Maintain a high index of suspicion. 

2️⃣Always check for signs of other occupants (children or adults) that may have also been thrown: car seats, personal items, etc. Ensure someone searches the area thoroughly while care is being rendered - patients can be thrown far.

3️⃣Partial ejection may be associated with severe extremity trauma or crush injury if part of the patient remains within/under the vehicle. Consider how long ago the accident happened - is there concern for crush syndrome?

4️⃣Even non-major external bleeds can contribute to significant blood loss. Control bleeding from lacerations after major hemorrhage and other life-threats are addressed. 

5️⃣Assume spinal injuries. Move responsibly.

6️⃣If patient is conscious on arrival, be prepared for mental status and airway deterioration due to TBI that may not be immediately evident. 

7️⃣Consider contributing factors to excessive speed and loss of control, if applicable: drug or alcohol use, medical emergency, etc. 

8️⃣Prepare for competing priorities (permissive hypotension for hemorrhage, increased MAP for increased ICP). Do the best you can with what you have. 

Leave your ejection experiences and pearls below👇🏻

Typical causes of drowning include children and adults who end up in water without the appropriate ability to swim, those who get trapped under people or objects, and those who reach exhaustion without an out. Without witnessing the incident, responders can’t always know exactly what happened. Other causes to consider👇🏻

1️⃣TRAUMA. Did the patient experience a diving injury or other trauma that altered consciousness or ability to swim?

2️⃣SEIZURES. Consider possibility of seizure activity while swimming in patients with or without a seizure history. Check a glucose. 

3️⃣DRUGS & ALCOHOL. Intoxication can impede ability to swim, even in patients who are usually competent swimmers. Consider recreational, OTC, and Rx meds. 

4️⃣ARRYTHMIAS. Patients with known or unknown cardiac abnormalities or risk factors may experience arrhythmias upon exertion in water, resulting in loss of consciousness. 

5️⃣ABUSE. In children, consider intentional abuse or neglect. Report when suspected.

Patients should be treated for a hypoxic arrest while considering other possible confounding factors. Focus on oxygenation and ventilation (utilize PEEP as appropriate) and assess for and address any underlying causes. Hypothermic drownings can be viable for a significant period of time - err on side of caution and work unless signs of prolonged death are obvious.

Cocaine use commonly presents with tachycardia💓and hypertension. Most cases of tachycardia are due to CNS agitation + excess catecholamines and require no specific treatment; symptoms will resolve with time after ceasing drug use. In patients with profound hypertension, tachycardia, and agitation, benzos are a helpful aid in reducing heart rate and blood pressure. Midazolam is an excellent option due to quick onset and ability to give IM or IN. Consideration should also be given to cooling these patients🥵and replacing volume💧. 

Cocaine ❄️ has both sodium and potassium channel blocking properties which can present with prolonged QRS and QT intervals. Patients with overt toxicity may present with a wide-complex tachycardia from sodium channel blockade🧂which may be reversed with sodium bicarb (as in other sodium channel blockers like TCAs). Although true VT is possible, it is relatively uncommon. If unresponsive to bicarb, lidocaine appears to be safe. Cardioversion⚡️is appropriate for hemodynamically unstable patients. Mag can be considered for QTc > 500 ms. 

Cocaine may trigger reentrant 🔄 tachycardias. Calcium channel blockers and cardioversion may be used depending on stability. Beta blocker use is controversial due to hypothetical unopposed alpha-adrenergic response; however, more recent evidence shows no difference in outcomes in cocaine users treated with beta blockers. Labetalol or carvedilol may be preferred, as they also act as alpha blockers.

Cocaine may also result in myocardial ischemia💀from increased demand, vasospasm, and increased coagulation. Do the 12-lead and consider ischemia as a contributing factor to dysrhythmias. 

🚑BOTTOM LINE: benzos, volume replacement, and adequate oxygenation are mainstays of treatment for cocaine-induced tachycardias. Consider bicarb for wide-complex tachycardias and calcium channel blocker for narrow. Electricity is appropriate for unstable patient with obvious rate problem. Consult poison control📞for guidance when needed.

@emergencyresilience and I were talking about post-arrest waiting periods in EMS the other day, and I’m nearly certain some of you have said this is in your protocols. Conveniently, @doc.resener plopped this new review in my inbox today. Let’s discuss. 

As a reminder, auto-resuscitation or Lazarus phenomenon occurs post-CPR when patients have been deemed clinically dead, but then regain spontaneous signs of life, usually with 5-10 minutes of ceasing efforts. While this may seem like a freak hiccup in the dying process, the existing reviews show us that a significant number of these patients (~14%) end up surviving neuro in-tact (😱). 

Are some of these cases due to poor death determination skills? Probably. But many are indeed asystolic on EKG and without cardiac motion on ultrasound - and thus, are truly coming back to life. Plus, numbers are believed to be under-reported due to fear of repercussions by clinicians (let’s be real, no one wants to have to takesy backsies their death spiel to families). 

How many patients have auto-resuscitated but have been missed due to termination of monitoring? Should we be passively monitoring our cardiac arrest patients after termination of efforts? 

Arguably, it costs nothing to keep the patient attached to the monitor and do a final assessment after clean-up is complete. 

Thoughts? Do your protocols or practices address this?👇🏻

• • • • •

📚: Georgios Mavrovounis, Marina Kontou, Orestis Tsiotsikas, Maria Mermiri, Vasiliki Tsolaki, Eleftherios Beltsios, Konstantinos Gourgoulianis, Athanasios Chalkias, Ioannis Pantazopoulos,
From flatline to lifeline: A scoping review of the Lazarus phenomenon, The American Journal of Emergency Medicine, Volume 72, 2023, Pages 44-57, ISSN 0735-6757,

Automated BP cuffs measure a MAP then indirectly calculate a systolic and diastolic BP from a formula; thus, the MAP is often the most accurate part of the reading. But still, the accuracy of these readings can be affected by movement, muscle tension, vibrations, cuff size, and a number of other factors. 

Manual BPs are affected by the subjective measurement of the listener’s ears, the quality of the stethoscope, the noise of the environment, and the same factors as automated cuffs. 

SpO2 readings can be falsely reassuring in the case of CO or cyanide poisoning, where the percentage does not accurately represent the amount of O2 available to tissues. Readings in anemia or blood loss don’t reflect the lack of RBCs. Any reading can be altered by nail polish, sunlight, skin temp, or perfusion. Any reading referred to as a stat instead of a sat should def be questioned. Correlate value with a good pleth and clinical condition. (Side note: pleth is often used to confirm mechanical capture in pacing, but EMCrit recently did an episode about a case where there was a good pleth but no mechanical capture😱. Episode details below).

ETCO2, if being measured via cannula, can be diluted by any subsequent O2 being delivered through or over the cannula. (Reminder that most ETCO2 cannulas deliver O2 in a “blow by” fashion via fenestrations in the tubing; the prongs are used for CO2 sampling). Trending > single value.

EKGs provide a rate based on electrical activity, but electrical activity doesn’t always translate to mechanical activity. A patient may have bigeminal ectopy that isn’t perfusing - the monitor says 80, but palpation says 40. Artifact can mimic tachycardia or death squiggles. Potholes and shivering don’t need defibbed 🙅🏻‍♀️

Bottom line: maintain healthy skepticism, utilize physical assessment, & correlate numbers with the larger clinical picture. 

When has your equipment lied or misled?👇🏻

🎧: EMCrit Wee – Case of Failure of Pulse Ox to Confirm Transcutaneous Pacemaker (TCP) Capture with Mathieu Brunet (July 8, 2023)

We tell spouses of 50 years that their partner is dead. We see abuse & neglect at its worst. We do compressions on children with parents wailing in the background. We watch loved ones say goodbye, knowing it’ll be the last time. We see bodies stabbed & shot & crushed & mutilated; we smell burnt skin. We see people who were so desperate to escape pain or rid the world of their perceived burden that they ended their own lives. We see humans living in squalor & consumed by addiction. We see young people struck down by freak accidents & humans needlessly die from drunk driving accidents. We see kids grieve the loss of their parents & we see parents grieve the loss of their kids. We see pain at its rawest. 

I received an incredibly candid message tonight from a tenured provider regarding a call that made them realize they’re not okay. That they need help. 

Many of us have been in EMS for a long time. It’s become a way of life, and we’ve learned to cope with the shit we see. But I became emotional when I read that DM. Really emotional, because I can relate. So many of us can. 

At what point is our “normal” not normal anymore? 

We worry about our spouses not waking up from a spontaneous head bleed, our kids choking on their dinner & coding, our parents dropping dead from an MI, our best friend dying from a head-on collision. We worry about the stranger’s kid drowning in the public pool, the loved one making a long drive without falling asleep, the pregnant friend delivering without complication. We worry about everyone we love, because we see that life is fragile and tomorrow isn’t guaranteed.

We chose to be here. No one is making us do this work, and no matter what the signs say, we’re not heroes. We’re doing a job we were trained to do. But, it takes a toll, and it requires solid coping mechanisms and a very real support system. 

I’m guilty of not getting the right help when needed, because “I’m fine.” Everything’s fine.

Until it’s not. 

There is nothing “normal” about this work. It’s okay to acknowledge that it can be hard. It’s okay to not be okay. And it’s okay to get help.

We can’t take care of others if we don’t take care of ourselves.

Put you first.

Commercial airway clearing devices (ACDs) like the DeChoker & LifeVac are widely advertised for both children & adults - but what’s the evidence?

A 2023 cadaver study (1️⃣) utilizing adult males evaluated obstructions of saltines, grapes, and cashews. The DeChoker resulted in gross injury to the tongue and failed to remove the obstruction in all trials. LifeVac was successful in removing the moistened saltines but failed to remove all other foreign bodies. The authors acknowledge several limitations of this study (give it a full read). 

A 2022 phase-one retrospective descriptive analysis (2️⃣) evaluated subjects who self-reported (note bias implications) to manufacturers as having used an ACD after full-, partial-, or unknown-severity obstruction. The analysis included 124 non-invasive (LifeVac) and 61 minimally invasive (Dechoker) ACD interventions. Extremes of age (very young & very old) were most common. Despite three adverse events, all but two subjects had resolution of symptoms after ACD use. (Also note that data was not supported by medical records nor collected by medical professionals). Phase✌🏻will develop a prospective, industry independent database of ACD cases. 

Other studies have shown positive results, but notable flaws include a high risk of bias (industry involvement & reporting bias), decreased generalizability of mannequin results, and a low certainty of evidence despite high success rates of dislodgement.

BOTTOM LINE: We need more evidence. It’s important to remember that the evidence for our current practices is also lacking. But, especially as healthcare providers, we need to know with relative certainty that we’re helping without causing undue harm.

What are your experiences with these devices? Thoughts?👇🏻

A 2011 Cochran review examined 65 trials and 4800 patients who received TXA in the perioperative period. While the need for blood transfusion was reduced by 18%, there was no difference in mortality, reoperation for bleeding, or thromboembolic events. 

The HALT-IT trial (TXA in GI bleeds) found no difference in all cause mortality or need for transfusion, but did find a statistically significant difference increase in venous thromboembolic events from 0.4% to 0.8%. 

Regarding postpartum hemorrhage, the TRAAP-2 trial found a statistically significant reduction in postpartum hemorrhage, but the WOMAN trial (large RCT with 20k+ women worldwide) found no statistically significant difference in the primary outcome of all cause mortality or hysterectomy. However, “death due to bleeding” was 0.4% less in the TXA group. 

CRASH-2 is the only large RCT showing a statistically significant decrease in all-cause mortality with TXA in multisystem trauma.

CRASH-3 showed a reduction in head injury related death in the subgroup of GCS 9-15. 

And this year, PATCH-trauma, the closest replication of CRASH-2 thus far, told us that there was no difference in the primary outcome of favorable functional outcome at 6 months in TXA vs. placebo group. 

The people of the interwebs have really strong feelings about all of this, but I can’t bring myself to get worked up about it.

It’s not an immediately life-saving drug for hemorrhagic shock - this is not a surprise. Might it benefit a subset of the population? Sure. Are we doing harm by giving it appropriately to multisystem trauma? Not that we know of (yet). 

Personally, I’m going to keep TXA at the bottom of my priority list where it’s always been. Stop external bleeding, book it to a trauma center, crank the heat, give blood, get TXA on board when possible. 

10 years from now, this drug could be at the top of our list or off of it altogether. Only time and more research will tell. 

I may not share your passion, but feel free to share your feels in the comments👇🏻

Every patient is different, and clinical judgment is a must. However, anecdotally, far too many patients don’t receive analgesia for very real pain due to “soft” BPs in the 80’s or 90’s, without appropriate measures being taken to problem-solve. 

I am not advocating for prioritizing pain management in a patient with a BP of 💩/☠️. 

I’m not advocating for giving 100 mcg of fentanyl to a patient with an SBP of 70. 

I do understand that many prehospital protocols have fairly conservative systolic limits that prohibit use in these situations. 

However -

Responsible fentanyl administration is not going to induce a harmful drop in the vast majority of patients. We can give patients a bump with fluids. Give them a little norepi when appropriate or titrate up on the current drip. Start with 25-50 mcg of fentanyl, dilute and give slowly. Consider non-opioid options. As always, use caution in the geriatric population. 

But allowing patients to suffer in extreme pain (sometimes for hours in-hospital) due to a low-ish SBP is unacceptable. Pain is not an appropriate way to maintain blood pressure, and there are ways to responsibly manage blood pressure while alleviating pain. 

Try a little fluid to get BP within parameters. Call for orders for a low dose to take off the edge. Consider a vasopressor if appropriate for the patient. Don’t work for the analgesia - make the analgesia work for you 👊🏻

Do a help. Treat the pain.

Most deaths from rattlesnakes and other pit vipers are from failure to seek antivenin or immediate anaphylaxis. The venom causes tissue necrosis and leaky cell membranes (which further spreads the venom locally), and has fibrinolytic and protein C activation effects causing coagulopathy (disordered bleeding and clotting). Most pit viper venom does not have neurotoxic effects, but timber rattlesnakes and Mohave rattlesnakes can produce some. The former has been known to cause involuntary quivering of muscles in localized areas, while the latter may cause cranial nerve dysfunction, weakness, and paralysis. 

✋🏻LOCAL SYMPTOMS: pain, swelling, bleeding, necrosis, ecchymosis. 

😰SYSTEMIC SYMPTOMS: angioedema, hypotension, tachycardia, vomiting, bleeding from other orifices, hematemesis, hematochezia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dyspnea, possible anaphylaxis. 

Symptom severity depends on level of envenomation. Antivenin is only recommended for moderate to severe presentations (see photo👉🏻). 

🚑TREATMENT:

👉🏻Rapid transport to antivenin-capable facility
👉🏻Elevate extremity to reduce swelling & immobilize
👉🏻Airway management if needed
👉🏻Fluid bolus for hypotension
👉🏻Pressors for hypotensive patients refractory to fluids; blood can be considered if available if signs of significant hemorrhage
👉🏻Mark bite injury size every 15-30 minutes with marker
👉🏻TREAT PAIN
👉🏻Treat with epi for anaphylaxis if suspected 
👉🏻In ER, consult toxicologist; CroFab bolus over an hour (many vials required: 4-6 or 10 initially depending on antivenin type), followed by repeat bolus and/or maintenance doses if needed

🐍OTHER POSSIBLE COMPLICATIONS: compartment syndrome (rare), rhabdo, infection, anaphylaxis or serum sickness from antivenin, necrosis leading to need for debridement or amputation, delayed venom effects.

You’re dispatched to a 45-year-old male who was working outside his home with a ladder when the ladder was accidentally placed against an electrical line. He was shocked and rendered unconscious, but received CPR from a family member and was alert and oriented upon EMS arrival. Patient has partial-thickness burns to the palms of both hands and full-thickness burns at exit points on both feet (some toes now missing). BP 150/94, HR 130’s sinus tach, ventilation and oxygenation adequate on room air. Severe pain in both legs and feet. 

👉🏻Initial assessment & treatment?
👉🏻Concerns other than entrance/exit wound burns?
👉🏻What internal problems do you anticipate?
👉🏻Fluid bolus thoughts? Necessity and amount?

Discuss below. Full post tomorrow.

• • • • •

📷: Das RN, Kumar J. High Tension Electric Current Injury and Silent Myocardial Infarction- A Case Report. Internet Journal of Medical Update 2006 Jan-Jun;1(1):3-5.

Electrical injury patients may suffer four major mechanisms: an arc flash with superficial burns, an arc flash that ignites clothing and causes additional injury, the quick but high voltage of lightning as it flows through the body, or by becoming part of an electrical circuit, often resulting in entrance and exit sites. Type of current (AC or DC), voltage, resistance, length of exposure, size of the individual, and contact location are all factors in severity of injury.

Yesterday’s case was a true electrical injury from a power line. This patient presented with an initial reported cardiac arrest resolved with bystander CPR. It’s possible that it was a true arrest, or perhaps a transient respiratory arrest; either way, cardiac monitoring is a must. 

In electrical injuries, visible thermal burns are often small (yesterday’s patient had <5% BSA between hands and feet), but are not proportional to internal damage. Typically, a thermal burn patient with <20% TBSA does not qualify for fluid resuscitation, but electrical patients are different. We’re concerned about internal tissue and muscle damage leading to rhabdo and acute kidney injury; thus, getting (responsible) fluids on-board early can preserve kidney function. Further fluids will be directed by labs and urine output in-hospital.

🚑PREHOSPITAL TREATMENT CONSIDERATIONS:

👉🏻Be prepared for respiratory arrest or shockable rhythm if unresponsive on arrival 

👉🏻Perform full trauma assessment to identify & address any injuries caused by being thrown, falling, etc.

👉🏻Thermal burns should be covered by something dry and clean that will not stick to the wound

👉🏻Monitor for swelling and signs of compartment syndrome

👉🏻Do a 12-lead; be prepared for delayed arrhythmias from damage to cardiac myocytes or electrolyte disturbances

👉🏻Initiate fluid bolus (LR if available) at 4 mL x kg x TBSA to get ahead of AKI from rhabdo and myoglobinuria 

👉🏻Treat pain (fentanyl, pain-dose ketamine)

👉🏻Keep patient warm

👉🏻Transport to burn center when mechanism is concerning, even with low TBSA %

I’ve heard time and time again from EMS providers the desire for law enforcement to carry BVMs ✨instead of✨ Narcan. I disagree, and here’s why. 

🙅🏻‍♀️No, patients do not need 12 mg of Narcan within 2 minutes.

✔️Yes, lack of ventilation prior to Narcan contributes to agitation. 

🙅🏻‍♀️No, patients don’t die from hyponarcanemia.

✔️Yes, some patients are treated with Narcan when OD was never the problem. 

In a perfect world, law enforcement providing ventilations via BVM to apneic or agonal patients until our arrival would be the bee’s knees 🐝

But let’s be real. 

EMTs suck at using a BVM. 
Paramedics suck at using a BVM. 
I’ve seen RTs suck at using a BVM. 

It’s one of the most important skills we have as healthcare providers but we all still jack it up on the reg. 

In what world do we think that LEOs (who are already task-saturated with multiple different roles, and who often struggle to get the training needed for their basic job requirements) are going to master a skill that we as healthcare providers still struggle with?

This is a recipe for viable patients coding unnecessarily. 

Instead, I would rather LE be given Narcan ✨AND✨ a BVM with initial and recurrent training on both. This way, when the seal isn’t great and the chest-rise is mediocre, the Narcan can still do its job (let us not forget it saves lives). For those who perform the skill well, it’s an added bonus of addressing hypercapnia and hypoxia (although an O2 source is unlikely) while waiting for the IN or IM Narcan to take effect instead of slamming 3 more doses because there’s nothing else to do and bystanders are panicking.

Some of your local LE departments are already using BVMs - how’s it going? Do they also carry Narcan? Is training adequate for safe ventilations? 

Thoughts👇🏻

Pulmonary embolisms are a perfusion problem, not an airway problem. Air goes in and out without issue, but a clot (or clots) in the pulmonary arteries cause lung tissue ischemia. If the clot is big enough, it can cause obstructive shock. The RV pumps blood to the lungs via the pulmonary arteries, and pumping against a phat roadblock ain’t easy. Any assumption that CPR-induced consciousness can’t result in purposeful movement or interference with one’s own resuscitation is incorrect. 

Documented cases include:

•Groans
•Speaking (“I don’t want to die”)
•Crying 
•Purposeful movements of extremities, including towards ETTs, BVMs, defib pads, grabbing providers
•Eye opening
•Breathing

This old video has been making its rounds again, with the rescuer getting blasted for “doing shit compressions on a living person.”

Drawing this conclusion from this clip is impossible & irresponsible. @doc.resener, a HEMS physician in Brazil, spoke with the ALS crew who arrived on scene. The patient was in arrest with confirmed STEMI. There were two physicians on scene and it was deemed CPRIC - the patient survived. 

We can assume this man had a witnessed collapse. Compressions were started immediately. While they’re not perfect, they are certainly adequate, and will provide increased cardiac output - possibly enough to allow consciousness.

“But his color is good.” Can we really tell? He has a darker skin tone at baseline; he’s not going to turn into a ghost immediately (or ever), especially if receiving immediate compressions. CPRIC patients sometimes breathe and talk.

“But he’s moving for several seconds after compressions are stopped.” Perfusion can linger after pulses (or compressions) stop. The world likely saw this when Damar Hamlin went into arrest on the field and stood up before collapsing.

We don’t know for sure the state of this patient at the time of the video, but it’s very possible this man played a role in saving his life. Even if the patient was transiently pulsatile, he could have had a tachy- or bradyarrhythmia (or otherwise severely diminished cardiac output) that caused his altered mental status. Compressions = inotropy.

Stay open-minded friends. We’d want the same in return.

A 40-year-old female was found unresponsive by family after overdosing on baclofen. She had absent brainstem reflexes, was intubated, & placed in the ICU. After several days, the patient was believed to be brain dead & organ procurement was arranged. Prior to harvest, she started having purposeful movements & awoke. She was transferred to a psych facility neuro in-tact. Whew 😮‍💨

This is not the only case of a baclofen OD patient incorrectly being presumed brain dead. 

Baclofen is a muscle relaxant (GABA B agonist) used for spasticity, often in spinal cord diseases like multiple sclerosis, cerebral palsy, or other SCI. It’s typically taken orally but can also be delivered via pump in severe cases. It’s sometimes used off-label for alcohol use disorder, intractable hiccups, GERD, & anxiety. 

In OD, baclofen loses specificity for receptors in the spinal cord and has greater effects on receptors in the CNS. May result in CNS depression, respiratory depression, flaccid paralysis, hypotension or hypertension, bradycardia or tachycardia, hypothermia, arrhythmias, and seizures. CNS depression can mimic brain death in severe cases. 

Prehospital care is supportive. Airway and ventilation management, fluids and pressors as needed for hypotension, benzos for seizures, atropine can be given for bradycardia with hypoperfusion. Other differentials include sedative or opioid OD, sepsis, stroke, hypoglycemia, & electrolyte imbalances. Consider all possibilities and combos. 

Severe withdrawal can also be life-threatening, presenting with delirium, tachycardia, hypertension, hyperreflexia, & seizures. Can be treated with benzos prehospitally. 

What are your experiences with baclofen OD or withdrawal?👇🏻

📚: Sullivan R, Hodgman MJ, Kao L, Tormoehlen LM. Baclofen overdose mimicking brain death. Clin Toxicol (Phila). 2012 Feb;50(2):141-4. doi: 10.3109/15563650.2011.654209. Epub 2012 Jan 31. PMID: 22292975.

📚: Dease NM, Kershner EK, Wills BK. Baclofen Toxicity. [Updated 2023 Mar 20]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2023 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK580550/
