This is based on personal experience - programs vary significantly across the country (and world). But, here’s a few of my favorite things about this job. Flight friends - what would you add for medics and nurses thinking about making the jump? Ground clinicians - what questions do you have?👇🏻

Today we landed at a hospital helipad for a critically ill, time-sensitive interfacility flight. All 3 crew members viewed a clean & clear pad, and security was aware of our arrival. While descending to the pad, a foreign object was seen getting sucked into the rotor blades which then latched to a blade, causing an audible change in sound with rotation. We continued to land and found a plastic bag (possibly from landscaping) that had been sucked up from behind a wall that surrounds the pad (reported by bystanders).

For the safety of the crew and patient, the aircraft was immediately grounded until a mechanic could inspect the aircraft for damage. This can take extensive time based on location. 

All other local helicopters were unavailable. Luckily, there was an ambulance and provider available at the hospital that could take us (and all of our stuff) by ground to complete the transfer.

The transport took 2-3x longer than the flight would’ve. The patient had a significant decline in condition during that time which, while temporized as able, required definitive services at the receiving facility. 

LZ security matters. Walking the LZ matters. Clearing the area of all foreign objects matters. Looking for wires, obstructions, and potential hazards matters. Every time. 

In HEMS, it can take nothing but a plastic bag to hinder operations. 

Accidents happen. Many don’t have to. 

If you’re responsible for establishing LZs, leave your safety practices in the comments. Flight friends - what do you like to hear in a brief?👇🏻

Increased intracranial pressure (ICP) can arise from traumatic brain injury, strokes/bleeds, edema, increased CSF (hydrocephalus), tumor, infections, and other causes. When enough pressure builds up within the non-stretchy cranium that it displaces brain tissue, we refer to it as herniation. Type and location of brain tissue displacement varies (see 2nd photo). 

Herniation is an immediate life-threat & requires prompt recognition and treatment. Possible presentations include:

👉🏻Hypertension (increased systolic to overcome ICP) and bradycardia, with or without respiratory irregularities (Cushing’s triad)
👉🏻Neurogenic breathing patterns (hyperventilation, Cheyne-Stokes, ataxic)
👉🏻Loss of brainstem reflexes (blinking, gagging, pupil reactivity)
👉🏻Pupillary asymmetry or fixed pupils
👉🏻Altered mental status or coma
👉🏻Posturing
👉🏻Respiratory arrest

🚑PREHOSPITAL TREATMENT:

•Rapid transport to neuro-capable facility 
•Avoid any hypoxia or hypotension, even if transient (single episode of either doubles mortality, both = worse)
•Maintain MAP of ~80 in adults if possible to account for increased ICP (MAP-ICP=CPP)
•Elevate HOB 30 degrees 
•Avoid hyper- and hypoventilation
•Titrate ventilations to normocapnia; 30-35 mmHg may be requested in active herniation, but opinions vary (no evidence of improved outcomes, with risk of harm)
•Administer hypertonic saline if available as temporizing measure to decrease ICP (water follows salt🧂)
•Watch closely for seizure activity and treat accordingly (benzos, Keppra if available). May be subtle or masked, especially if paralyzed. 
•Check glucose to avoid an awkward turnover event 

⚠️If the patient is awake and talking to you and they have unequal pupils, they are not herniating. Cease panic and ask about baseline abnormalities. 

What are your guidelines and experiences with herniating patients?👇🏻

Medication bolus: X amount of drug pushed quickly or over several minutes. 1 mg epi IV push, 100 mcg fentanyl slow IV push. Can also deliver boluses IM. 

Infusion: big fat slow bolus. Drug mixed in bag because it’s easier to give slowly that way, and if we give too fast it may harm the patient. 150 mg amio mixed in a small bag given over 10 mins, 2g mag mixed in a small bag given over 10 minutes, etc. The size of the bag doesn’t particularly matter as long as it’s sensible (no need to mix it in a liter), and the time is ballpark. Just don’t want to slam it. Macroset used if not using pump. 

Drip: medication delivered precisely per minute. Norepi at 5 mcg/min, epi at 0.1 mcg/kg/min. Microset used for precision titration if not using a pump.

Yes, we know pumps are the golden standard. No, not all prehospital agencies have them. Yes, drips can be done by hand as a temporizing measure in a crumping patient prehospitally.

There are a lot of high horses🐴 about this, but the reality is, if your septic shock patient’s BP is 💩/☠️, a ballpark norepi drip is better than no drip. It’s a short-term solution to an acute problem.

Either of these can be used to make push-dose epi which is typically a 10 mcg/mL concentration (basically a vasopressor drip in a syringe). 

Option 1: mix 1 mg epi 1:1 in a 100 mL bag. Voilá - 10 mcg/mL. Draw several cc’s up in a syringe to push as needed.

Option 2: draw up 1 mL of epi 1mg/10mL (code epi) in a 10 mL syringe. This is 0.1 mg (100 mcg). Add 9 mL NS and voilà - 10 mcg/mL.

Epi drip concentrations can be anything your heart desires in any size bag. See recent med math posts for figuring out what you made 🤓

Prioritize accordingly.

I was in the produce section of the grocery store this morning when I passed the mangos and had a PSA-worthy memory from my early adulthood. I would get occasional painful & itchy rashes on and around my lips with no obvious cause, and as a 20-something hypochondriac, you can imagine the self-diagnostic possibilities.

Turns out, mango peels contain the same urushiol oil that causes poison ivy and oak reactions. And thus, if you make contact with the unpeeled fruit and are allergic/sensitized to the oil, a similar reaction can occur (common around mouth, but can occur anywhere). Have no fear mango lovers - eating pre-peeled mango avoids the issue.

IO access can be intimidating for new providers, especially outside of cardiac arrest. But, there are times when IO access is warranted in patients who are conscious or otherwise responsive to pain. 

The following examples are not absolutes or exhaustive.

🙅🏻‍♀️When is drilling an awake patient or patient with a pain response generally NOT appropriate?

👉🏻Patients who will see no meaningful benefit from access prior to ED transfer where ultrasound/other access options are available 
👉🏻Patients who need medications that can be given IN or IM (analgesia, seizures, hypoglycemics who qualify for glucagon)
👉🏻Opinion: “Proactive” IO access is often unnecessary in patients who do not immediately need it. If the patient decompensates or develops a need, IO access can be rapidly obtained. 

✔️When IS it generally appropriate to drill an awake or otherwise alive patient? 

IV access is not obtainable in a reasonable amount of time or attempts +👇🏻

👉🏻Patients (especially children) with signs of hypovolemic shock requiring fluid boluses
👉🏻Hypoglycemics who are not good candidates for glucagon (and cannot eat/drink)
👉🏻Blood candidates with product readily available
👉🏻Herniating patients qualifying for hypertonic saline
👉🏻Other forms of shock or severe illness where access will be used immediately 

⚠️The drill is not the painful part; the flush (and subsequent fluid) is. When patients are awake or responsive to pain, utilize a lidocaine flush. Consider other analgesia when situation allows.

Also note that the blue needles are now labeled down to 3kg (same as pink). Pink can be too small to reach marrow in many patients technically within range. Err on side of larger size with kids and stop drilling as soon as relief is felt.

So glad to start to see a shift in these headlines. More and more articles are citing tox experts and physicians who are speaking out about the overstatement of fentanyl exposure risk. 

Shoutout to the follower who slid this in my DMs.

Remember:

👉🏻Fentanyl is not readily absorbed through the skin and would take huge amounts over time to have an effect (even when manufactured to intentionally do this through patches, it takes 3-13 hours to reach a therapeutic level). 

👉🏻Powdered opioids do not aerosolize, and would require extreme air movement to be inhaled accidentally and cause toxicity. 

👉🏻Opioid analogs like carfentanil behave in the same manner in passive exposure. 

👉🏻At the highest airborne concentration encountered by workers who produce fentanyl in an industrial setting, an unprotected individual would require nearly 200 min of exposure to reach a dose of 100 mcg of fentanyl (‘tis but a splash in the medical world). 

👉🏻If the palms of both hands in an average adult were covered with fentanyl patches (which are actually designed to absorb this way), it would take approximately 14 minutes to receive 100 mcg of fentanyl (again, a splash). Powder does not readily absorb.

External ventricular devices (EVDs) are typically placed by a neurosurgeon or intensivist under critical neuro conditions. It allows for the drainage and monitoring of blood or CSF from the ventricles in the brain to mitigate intracranial pressure, and for the continuous monitoring of ICP. Conditions such as intracranial hemorrhage with extension of bleeding into the ventricles, hydrocephalus, subarachnoid hemorrhage, meningitis, and some TBIs may benefit from drain placement. 

The device is simple, but the implications of (mis)management are huge: building ICP or herniation if clamped, overdrainage leading to complications, etc.

There’s a fine line between discussing someone else’s call in an informal setting to learn from it and Monday-morning quarterbacking.

Others’ experiences can help us in huge ways. They push us to think through situations we may have never been in, and we learn from both positive and negative outcomes.

But too often, discussing others’ calls turns into discussing what could’ve/would’ve/should’ve been done without the proper perspective or information to do so, without positive intent, and with the consequence of discouraging an open and honest workplace. This type of conversation can turn work environments toxic by making coworkers feel attacked and judged, and by subsequently making other employees hesitant to discuss shortcomings.

Before speaking about someone else’s call in an informal environment, we should ask ourselves:

1️⃣What is my intent? Is it to learn or to gossip?
2️⃣Who is my audience? Does it make sense for me to talk about this with them?
3️⃣What is my tone? Is it supportive and educational or critical and derogatory?
4️⃣Am I forming opinions based on accurate information? Details get quickly butchered.
5️⃣Would I want to be spoken about this way if it were my call?
6️⃣Am I acknowledging the mistakes I’ve made in the past and will make in the future?

Good CQI programs offer the opportunity to discuss successes and shortcomings in a safe, non-punitive environment. Table talk can provide the same if done correctly. 

But we must keep in mind that we weren’t there, we don’t know exactly what happened, and we can’t say with certainty what we would’ve done. While sometimes negligent situations exist, these should be addressed through appropriate channels. In the event of any mistake or poor outcome, providers do not learn through public humiliation, or from gossip that turns into a game of telephone. 

Be the person your coworkers trust and confide in, not the person they’re afraid to talk around. Those people are the foundation of a healthy workplace. 🧱🌱

You have an iGel placed. Hypothetically, the opening of the iGel is right against the trachea. You place a bougie through the iGel, into the trachea, and swap the iGel for an ETT. 

Violà! Right?

I’m personally not a fan of this technique, and I’ll tell you why. I’m certain some of y’all have done this successfully. As always, nothing is black and white in medicine. 

But:

1️⃣If the iGel is working, why are we replacing it? If an SGA has been placed and ventilation and oxygenation are adequate, there are few reasons to switch prehospitally. 

2️⃣If it’s not working (oxygenation or ETCO2 are ick), why are we trusting the iGel to deliver a straight shot to the trachea?

3️⃣If it is working but we anticipate failure (placement by BLS with swelling or secretions), is blind bougie placement better than visual?

iGels are perfectly capable of adequate ventilation and oxygenation under many circumstances. The desire for a “definitive airway” can delay real definitive care prehospitally, or cause undue harm to the patient. More and more hospitals are accepting iGels until the patient is appropriately stabilized for intubation, and the bougie can certainly slip the seal into the esophagus during exchange.

My take? Use the iGel if it’s working. If it’s not, or if it’s anticipated to fail, preoxygenate via whatever means are appropriate and visualize the entire ET attempt for the best chance of first-pass success. My program specifically prohibits the use of iGels for ETT exchange, and I get it. 

Agree or disagree?👇🏻

The intranasal route is a great option for naloxone, analgesia, seizure management, and other medications. In patients with healthy and unobstructed nasal mucosa, IN meds can provide non-invasive effects within just a few minutes. 

5 TIPS FOR IN MED ADMIN:

1️⃣These meds are not supposed to be intentionally snorted or inhaled. They are meant to be misted and cover the nasal mucosa. This can’t be achieved when it’s being launched down the patient’s throat after asking them to sniff (which now means the med needs to undergo first pass metabolism). Just spray it with some oomph (note the increase in misting with increase in speed).

2️⃣Use the most concentrated version of the drug available. Limit volume to ~1mL per nare, and divide between both nares when possible to increase surface area. 

3️⃣Consider the 0.1 mL of dead space that’s in most MAD devices (I know “MAD device” is redundant and I don’t care✋🏻). Particularly relevant for small pedi doses.

4️⃣Direct the spray towards the top of the ear on the same side. Aiming up and slightly out allows the med to be directed away from the poorly-vascularized septum and towards the much-more-vascular mucosa of the turbinates and olfactory mucosa. Also leads to less runoff down the throat.

5️⃣Patients who regularly snort drugs, have a history of nasal cancer, use nasal vasoconstrictors like Afrin, or have copious nasal secretions may benefit from an alternative route.

Years ago, two parents were witness to their young adult son taking his own life on the roof of his apartment complex. 

The fire department was actively retrieving the patient from the roof and our EMS agency, still responsible for morgue transports at the time, remained on scene.

Mom and dad sat in a vehicle, watching their son’s body make its way down a ladder. A neighborhood woman stood on the sidewalk, gawking at every move. Law enforcement tried briefly to get the woman to leave, but she had no desire to, was not doing anything illegal, and LE was otherwise preoccupied. 

I watched this woman’s behavior pour salt in mom’s open wounds - staring at her dead son for her own entertainment. The lady and I had a chat regarding what it means to be a decent human being. She left.

Upon removal of the body, the parents wished to spend time with their son but met resistance from law enforcement. After some negotiation, the parents got time with their son, and the ability to touch him one last time through plastic.

Some time later, flowers and this letter were waiting for me at the station.

Yesterday, someone messaged me about their flame going out. It reminded me of this story because at the time of this call, my own was barely lit. For the first and only time in my life, I was on the verge of quitting EMS altogether.

But then I got this letter. I was overwhelmed by the strength and kindness and selflessness of this mother during what was undoubtedly the most excruciating time in her life. Amidst her own family’s pain, she took the time to make this gesture for me, a complete stranger. 

I stayed.

I don’t know where I’d be today without this letter. I keep it as a reminder for why I do this job: to help humans in any way that I can, the best that I can.

It matters.

What keeps your flame lit?👇🏻

Patient was brought to the ER within an hour of deliberately ingesting the pesticide methyl parathion. Atropine and pralidoxime were immediately started + gastric lavage and activated charcoal. Patient continued to respiratory arrest and was placed on a vent in the ICU for 7 days before weaning and eventual transfer to psych care. Atropine and pralidoxime were continued for a total of 934 mg and 9.5 gm. 

Organophosphate poisoning affects both muscarinic and nicotinic receptors in the central and peripheral nervous systems. Acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter (communication chemical) at these receptors, and acetylcholinesterase is the enzyme that breaks it down. Organophosphate toxicities inhibit acetylcholinesterase, thus allowing for an inappropriate excess of acetylCHOLINE (CHOLINErgic toxicity).

💦MUSCARINIC SYMPTOMS:

D - defecation 💩 
U - urination 🧻 
M - miosis 👀
B - bradycardia, bronchorrhea, bronchospasm ☠️ 
E - emesis 🤢 
L - lacrimation 😭
S - salivation 🤤 

These are addressed via atropine, atropine, atropine - an ANTIcholinergic that will address the “killer Bs” in high doses. Give benzos for seizures.

😴NICOTINIC SYMPTOMS: CNS depression, paralysis, fasciculations. Hypertension and tachycardia possible. 

These symptoms require pralidoxime (2-PAM) which binds to the organophosphate and reactivates acetylcholine. Must be given before aging - a process that renders acetylcholinesterase resistant to reactivation - occurs. Timeline varies by agent. 

• • • • •

📚: Bhattarai MD, Singh DL, Chalise BS, Koirala P. A case report and overview of organophosphate (OP) poisoning. Kathmandu Univ Med J (KUMJ). 2006 Jan-Mar;4(1):100-4. PMID: 18603880. (http://www.kumj.com.np/issue/13/100-104.pdf)

📚: Robb EL, Baker MB. Organophosphate Toxicity. [Updated 2023 Apr 24]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2023 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470430/

Chest tubes are placed through the chest wall into the pleural space for the purpose of creating negative pressure, allowing the lung to re-expand, and removing air, blood, and other unwanted fluids from the space. The distal end of the chest tube is connected to a drainage system that typically has three chambers: suction, water seal, and collection. An Oasis Atrium is pictured here.

The water seal is a one-way valve that allows air to leave the pleural space but not re-enter. As pressure changes with inhalation and exhalation, normal tidaling - rising and falling of water level - can be seen. Intermittent bubbling here 4️⃣ can be a sign of pneumothorax (common in our setting), but unexpected persistent bubbling should prompt a check of tube placement, system, and connections.

For early and active drainage, suction is attached to the suction port 1️⃣ and is typically set to -20 cm H2O 2️⃣. Watch for the bellows 3️⃣ to expand to confirm suction is suctioning. Some patients will drain to gravity (no suction) and bellows will not expand. 

Keep drain below level of chest tube site, check drainage level 5️⃣ often, and continue to evaluate for signs of reaccumulation.

Drain systems vary by manufacturer. Ensure familiarity with what you carry or transport. 

📷: Patient with hemopneumothorax from penetrating trauma. Positive tidaling, negative bubbling, continuously accumulating blood drainage. Pneumo presumably resolved, hemo requiring surgical intervention. Blood initiated during transport due to patient increasingly looking yuck.

Pediatric exposures to edible cannabinoids has become increasingly common with the rise in accessibility + the development of edibles that are appealing to kids. Calls to poison control centers and ED visits are rapidly on the rise with legalization. 

The AAP used AAPCC (poison control) data to examine unintentional pediatric cannabis exposure trends across the country between 2017-2021 and found that, during this time, exposures in ages 5 and under increased 1375%. Severity is also increasing rapidly, with more ICU admissions and less treat-and-releases. 

Adult starting doses are typically 2.5-10 mg of THC. Multiple doses are often contained within a single toddler-sized portion 🍬🍪

What symptoms should we expect?

🧠NEUROLOGICAL:
•CNS depression
•Coma
•Ataxia
•Confusion
•Agitation
•Tremors
•Seizures
•Hallucinations

🫀CARDIOVASCULAR:
•Tachycardia
•Less common: bradycardia, hypotension, hypertension

👀GI, OCULAR, RESPIRATORY:
•Vomiting
•Mydriasis (dilated pupils)
•Respiratory depression 

🚑TREATMENT: supportive care is mainstay of treatment. Fluids, benzos, antiemetics as needed. Consider co-ingestions. Check glucose. Consider possibility of underlying medical problems + accidental or intentional ingestion, and possibility of caregivers not being forthcoming about exposure.

🙅🏻‍♀️PREVENTION: caregiver education regarding proper storage is paramount. Usage in front of children should be minimized to avoid mimicking behavior. Recognize that dosing can be significant per small portion, and packaging is often not well-marked. May qualify for mandatory reporting to CPS.

Taking the airway of a living person is the highest-risk procedure we perform. While done with the intention of improving ventilation, oxygenation, or preventing aspiration, we have the ability to increase morbidity and mortality if proper care isn’t taken to avoid complications. 

Among these is hypotension - a complication that can result in peri-arrest and arrest situations, and can be hugely detrimental to our TBI patients in any amount.

What causes hypotension before, during, and after RSI?

1️⃣Patient condition. Many of our patients are sick sick - hemorrhagic shock, septic shock, cardiogenic shock, obstructive shock, any of the shocks. Our patients often enter the chat behind the eight ball already. Address any reversible causes.

2️⃣Induction medications. Any sedative (including ketamine) has the ability to drop BP, especially when given too quickly or in large doses. If using ketamine, give slowly over 2 minutes (an actual 2 minutes, not an ambulance “2 minutes”) and consider cutting doses in half in shock. Paralytics have minimal effect on blood pressure.

3️⃣Positive pressure ventilation. The way we naturally breathe - via negative pressure ventilation - contributes to our positive venous return and cardiac output. When we pull a sneaky on the pressure in the intrathoracic cavity and initiate PPV, we alter our patient’s natural physiology. Increased intrathoracic pressure can decrease cardiac output, and PEEP can add to this decrease, especially if the patient is hemodynamically unstable at baseline. We must be prepared to mitigate this effect.

How do we address peri-RSI hypotension?

✨Resuscitation before intubation✨. If MAP, systolic, or shock index aren’t adequate, give blood, fluids, or pressors as needed BEFORE inducing, and before switching to PPV when possible. Address reversible causes. In borderline or “normal” patients, be ready to address a drop in perfusion quickly. Be prepared to provide continued support as needed via volume, vasopressors, and appropriate vent settings or manual ventilations (avoiding hyperventilation). Continue to use responsible dosing for repeat sedation and analgesia.

Sources in comments.

Small detail that’s often overlooked in paramedic education: extension sets like this 8 inch Curaplex version are common prehospitally. It holds 2 mL of fluid💧 

Let’s say you want to give 150 mg ketamine sloooowwww IV push for RSI. Your vial is 50 mg/mL. That’s 3 mLs. You push your meds through the extension set over 2 minutes then slam the flush.

😱You actually only slow-pushed ~50 mg (1 mL) and slammed the rest (2 mL). Your vial is 100 mg/mL? The whole dose (1.5 mL) got slammed. 

There are several medications we give slowly to mitigate negative side-effects. Remember that slow-pushing through an extension set or distal port of IV tubing doesn’t slow-deliver to the patient. Load the line with meds then flush slowly 🐢🤓 or dilute the med when appropriate into a small bag or large syringe.

What meds do you push slow? How do you ensure they get delivered slowly?👇🏻

You’re dispatched for a patient with stroke symptoms & find them to be stroke scale positive. During your assessment, you perform an EKG and find an inferior MI. Does the patient simply have impeccable timing, or are these problems related?

When the inside layers of the aorta dissect (tear away), they create a false lumen for blood to flow into (TL in photo = true lumen). This lumen 1. holds unused blood volume 2. risks rupture and 3. can occlude actual blood flow.

Dissections can be isolated to any part of the main aorta, but they can also spread into any of the many arterial branches. Some unfortunate patients dissect from (what seems like) head-to-toe. 

Dissections can tear into the subclavians, disrupting perfusion to the arms. They can tear into the iliac and femoral arteries, disrupting perfusion to lower extremities. Tears can spread into renal arteries making sad kidneys, and even into spinal arteries causing neuro deficits. 

Those that involve the ascending aorta (the part that comes up off the left ventricle) are a yuge concern. They’re high-risk and generally considered a surgical emergency.

Although rare, it’s possible for a dissection in this region to tear downward into the coronary arteries and upward into a carotid, causing both OMI and stroke symptoms. The false lumen in the affected coronary artery(ies) occludes blood flow to the heart, and the false lumen in or near the carotid disrupts blood flow to the brain. And thus, we have a doubly bad day.

Perfusion to multiple major systems disrupted? Think aortic dissection.

Tell us about your dissection experiences👇🏻 

Sources in comments.

Acute aortic dissections that have been deemed surgical emergencies need rapid pharmacological management while en route to surgical intervention. Commonly, these are type A dissections (those involving the ascending aorta) that are being sent out via critical care transport to a facility with vascular surgery capabilities. 

Upon diagnosis, algorithm for hemodynamically stable patients is as follows. Medication choices vary by locality - options listed are not exhaustive.

1️⃣PAIN CONTROL. Heart rate is our biggest concern, and discomfort can increase heart rate and blood pressure. Use fentanyl/opioids to achieve comfort (drip is great option for consistent coverage). Ketamine not preferred due to potential catecholamine surge (increase in HR is opposite of what we want). Alleviate any nausea with an antiemetic.

2️⃣HEART RATE CONTROL. Usually achieved via beta blocker unless contraindicated. We want HR as low as patient’s perfusion can tolerate (<60 if possible). Each heart beat is a shearing force against the tear and risks worsening of the false lumen or rupture. Esmolol is a common first-line; labetalol or metoprolol may also be used. This must be done✨before✨lowering BP to avoid a compensatory increase in HR. 

3️⃣PRESSURE CONTROL. After achieving heart rate goal, address any remaining BP needs with an antihypertensive. SBP goal <120. Nicardipine and clevidipine are common agents. 

Goal is lowest possible HR and BP that maintains end-organ perfusion⬇️⬇️

⚠️When a dissection patient presents shocky, common sense must be used with opioids and beta blockers. Consider low-dose pain control and give only what patient can tolerate. Be prepared for resuscitation with blood products. 

How does your program or department manage these patients?👇🏻

📚: [Peer-Reviewed, Web Publication] Hemmert K, Macias M (2017, May 30). Aortic Dissection: Practice Update. [NUEM Blog. Expert Commentary By Gisondi M]. Retrieved from http://www.nuemblog.com/blog/aortic-dissection

When we breathe naturally, we breathe via negative pressure. Our diaphragm drops down and sucks air in, inflating our lungs with the help of a stable rib cage to facilitate expansion. (This is why a flail chest disrupts natural ventilation - the vacuum sucks air in, but the rib cage isn’t intact to allow expansion, and thus, the segment sucks in when it should be going out).

When we ventilate someone via BVM, we switch from negative to positive pressure. Instead of air getting sucked in, we’re pushing it in, and that’s not what the body’s used to. (This can “splint” a flail chest, however, by forcing the affected lung out and allowing ventilation). 

PPV can increase intrathoracic pressure and reduce preload by compressing the vena cava and right heart - especially in patients with inadequate volume. 

What does this mean for us?

1️⃣We must ventilate responsibly with a rate, volume, and minute ventilation that are appropriate for the patient. Too much ventilation can worsen these complications. High levels of PEEP can also increase intrathoracic pressure and decrease cardiac output (➡️obstructive shock). 

2️⃣We must anticipate a decrease in cardiac output when switching any patient to PPV. In an RSI situation, this means resuscitating first as needed to mitigate hypoperfusion from both meds and our BVM/ventilator. We must also watch blood pressures in non-hypertensive patients requiring non-invasive ventilation (BiPAP). 

🫁PPV: do it well, do it responsibly.

For prehospital providers who RSI or achieve ROSC after intubation, the typical sedation method has been repeat boluses. With the increasing accessibility of pumps in EMS, there is little reason not to transition to a pump for continued sedation after loading doses.

⚠️EDIT FOR EMPHASIS: drips maintain sedation, they don’t achieve it. Loading boluses are necessary to achieve desired effect first.

💧KETAMINE. Common dosing of 0.5-4 mg/kg/hr.
💧VERSED. Common dosing of 0.05-0.2 mg/kg/hr.
💧FENTANYL. As an analgesic adjunct to sedation. Common dosing of 1-2 mcg/kg/hr. 

Reminder that etomidate should not be given repeatedly or via drip. One and done.

The chart above illustrates why drips are favorable to multiple boluses (applies to pressors as well).

1️⃣Repeated boluses create unpredictable ups-and-downs of sedation and hemodynamics. A drip allows for consistent coverage that can be titrated as needed. 

2️⃣Patients may easily end up under-sedated during bolus sedation. Patients chew through meds at different rates. A q 15 bolus might be okay for some but not for all. 

3️⃣If our patient is paralyzed, we have no way of knowing what their sedation status is. While BP, HR, and tearing should be evaluated, they are NOT reliable sole indicators for whether a patient is well-sedated or not. A drip guarantees some degree of consistent coverage. 

4️⃣Drips reduce cognitive load and free up hands. Instead of watching a clock and repeating boluses, we can set a pump and let it ride, titrating as necessary. It also removes the possibility of getting distracted and forgetting a timely bolus. 

Check out a few anecdotes above from the ED-AWARENESS study (2021). Authors looked at the prevalence of awareness with paralysis in a hospital setting (single-center). They didn’t evaluate drips vs. boluses; rather, the results harp on the importance of effective sedation during paralysis. The anecdotes are hard to read, and I would argue the numbers (10/383 patients - already too high) are significantly less than would be found in a multi-center study.

Sedate ya patients.
Thoughts?👇🏻

I’m fine. I’m not going through anything. Seriously - nothing. I’m coasting and living a pretty damn good life that I’ve made. 

But - you all have inspired me through conversations we’ve had here over the last couple of years. “Get a therapist before you need a therapist,” you said. Then you said it again. 

I turned 34 this week. I’ve been heavily involved in EMS since 16. That’s 18 years of being knee-deep in other peoples’ trauma. 

With the exception of a few temporary PTS-inducing events over the years, I’ve always considered myself very well-adjusted to this job. It’s certainly given me perspective, but hasn’t negatively affected my mental health (right?). 

Except -

Dead infants. CPR on kids. Telling spouses their partner is dead. Sudden deaths of healthy people. Child abuse. Domestic assault. Sexual assault. Impoverished living conditions. Chronic suffering. Addiction. Kids losing parents. Parents losing kids. Screaming grieving loved ones. Burnt bodies. Mangled teenagers. Dementia. Suicide. Mental illness. Big mistakes. Second-hand grief. Hard conversations. Life-altering injuries. Patients’ last words. 

Is it possible to spend years immersed in these situations and not be chronically affected?

I’ve always thought that for me, the answer was yes. I’m good. I have a support system and I use it well. 

Except -

I didn’t sleep well last night (or last week or last year). Did my husband make it where he was going? He should’ve texted by now. It’s 3am in bed and I don’t see him breathing - is he breathing? Is my stepkid going to choke on that gum? Spit it out. And get down from there. He’s sleeping late - something’s wrong. Go check. What new symptom do I have that’s going to result in abandonment of my family? It’s a PE. Maybe cancer. Did my dad get that abdominal pain looked at? They should’ve done more tests. My mom’s calling - what happened. My friend is having her baby - I haven’t gotten news yet. Did something happen? Something happened.

All day, every day.

I think what I’ve accepted as “normal” might not be so normal after all. And it’s probably time to dig a little. 

So, today is my first therapy session.

Time to grab a shovel 🦺

You’re dispatched to a nursing home for altered mental status. You find meemaw barely responsive, tachypneic, tachycardic, cool to the touch. Radial pulses are barely palpable, BP is 60/38 (45), SpO2 is 89%. She was reportedly diagnosed with a UTI several days ago and was placed on antibiotics. It’s unknown how long she’s been like this, as this is not the staff member’s patient, and she just got here.

Although the Surviving Sepsis Campaign recommends at least 30 mL/kg of crystalloids within the first 3 hours of resuscitation for patients who are hypoperfused secondary to sepsis, this recommendation is based on weak evidence. Common sense + physical assessment is key regarding patient needs and order of operations.

In our scenario, meemaw has multiple signs of poor perfusion. Her MAP is 💩, her mental status is yuck, her skin is cool, her peripheral pulses are making an exit. She needs perfusion support ASAP. Does she need fluids for her likely dehydration and distributive shock? Certainly. But we can initiate low-dose pressors (preferably norepi) simultaneously and titrate to a MAP of 65 or signs of adequate perfusion. Calculate a 30 mL/kg bolus, and check for signs of overload frequently.

If our patient isn’t so critical - say, peepaw next door has signs of pneumonia, a mostly-baseline mental status, tachypnea, tachycardia, warm skin, and a BP of 80/48 (59) - we need not be so aggressive. Likely, a fluid bolus will perk him up. With an okay-MAP of 59, we don’t have far to go. Start with fluids (don’t drown peepaw with 30 mL/kg if he doesn’t need it) and reevaluate.

🚑BOTTOM LINE: if the patient is profoundly hypoperfused, simultaneous fluids + pressors may be appropriate. We needn’t wait for fluids (which may or may not be effective) while the patient is experiencing end-organ damage. If you have time to work, start with fluids and reevaluate. Don’t forget the sepsis alert to minimize time to antibiotics. 

What are your guidelines? When fluids? When pressors? Do you have prehospital antibiotics?👇🏻

Cardiac arrest during pregnancy is a low-frequency, high-risk event. Prehospitally, there are several key points to consider:

1️⃣Consider etiology of arrest: PE/amniotic fluid embolism, OMI, SCAD, hemorrhage, heart failure, seizures, trauma, pre-existing medical complications, OD/toxins, etc. This can affect our management, but also paints the picture for receiving OB & neonatal teams. Attempt to get maternal & obstetric hx. 

2️⃣Perform high-quality compressions & defib as needed. Med and ⚡️ doses are unchanged. But:

3️⃣Utilize L lateral uterine displacement during compressions. During pregnancy (especially at 20+ weeks), the gravid uterus compresses the aorta & vena cava. Compression of the IVF decreases venous return & cardiac output. 

📝If fundus is at or above level of umbilicus, gestational age of 20+ weeks can be assumed. 

4️⃣Consider an advanced airway early, as changes in maternal airways increase risk of desaturation (decreased functional residual capacity, ⬆️ O2 consumption), aspiration, & failed airway (vascular engorgement ➡️ airway edema). Give 100% FiO2 & avoid hyperventilation. Place an OG if situation allows.

5️⃣Establish IV/IO access above the diaphragm for best perfusion/venous return to heart. 

6️⃣Perimortem c-section (resuscitative hysterotomy) should be considered at 5 minutes if no ROSC by 4 minutes in second- and third-trimester arrests, both for neonatal resuscitation & to improve mom’s chances of ROSC. Prehospitally, this puts us in a unique situation. Do we work on-scene then transport to provide best resuscitative efforts, or do we load, work and go? Probably go. Alert your local facility ASAP so they can prepare. 

📝Maternal & neonatal survival are higher when the time from arrest to resuscitative hysterotomy is < 5 min v. > 5 min (61% v. 35% for mom and 96% vs 70% for the baby). Removing the fetus reduces O2 consumption and optimizes vena cava flow + lung function. 

📝: Maternal survival is higher (72% v. 36%) when resuscitative hysterotomy is performed on scene of arrest. (This is just an fyi, not an invitation to go rogue). 

Leave your experiences👇🏻

📷: Dr. Shannon Zhang

Cardiomyopathy is a collection of diverse problems with the heart muscle. It can be acquired or inherited, and can result in decreased cardiac output, arrhythmias, heart failure, myocardial ischemia, valve dysfunction, and sudden death. Common types include dilated (ventricular enlargement) and hypertrophic (thickened left ventricle). Additionally, restrictive cardiomyopathy causes stiff ventricles, and arrhythmogenic RV cardiomyopathy is genetic and can cause sudden death in young people and athletes. Cardiomyopathies in general are a common cause of sudden cardiac arrest in young people. 

Heart pictured is a cardiomyopathy heart that was removed to be replaced by a transplant.

You’ve run multiple overdoses in the same neighborhood and expect the next call there to have drugs involved.

The patient appears to be of a different nationality. “Does she speak English?”

To believe that we are bias-free is a dangerous mentality. Bias is everywhere and in everyone. Anecdote ≠ evidence, but how often do we make decisions based on real or perceived patterns, both in our personal lives and at work? Recognizing patterns quite literally keeps us (and sometimes our patients) alive. It can also lead us astray.

We see (or hear) real and perceived patterns in the entirety of the world around us. Age, gender, religion, sexual orientation, nationality, education, socioeconomic status, political affiliation, occupation, appearance, criminal history - the list goes on. We cannot rid ourselves of all bias, but we can look for and acknowledge it in ourselves, keep it in check, and work to ensure that it doesn’t affect our patient care. 

We are all entitled to our own thoughts, beliefs, and opinions. That freedom is a beautiful thing. But if we’re going to choose to work in healthcare, we MUST be able to recognize our biases and proactively put them aside to treat our patients as the human beings they are. “Am I treating this patient differently because of my own beliefs or assumptions?” If we are unable to question ourselves, acknowledge bias, and change course, patient care is not the place to be.

The @mchd_tx MCHD Paramedic Podcast did a fantastic episode on this topic recently: episode 160, “ST Elevation in aVR with Diffuse ST Depression.” Go give it a listen 🎧 

The idea of OMI vs. STEMI has been gaining traction over the last several years, with multiple non-STEMI patterns getting attention as “STEMI equivalents” for their associated incidence of occlusion.

Is elevation in aVR + diffuse multi-lead depression on that list?

Not necessarily. While it should certainly be a red flag, only 10% of patients with this pattern in the study cited below were found to have a true occlusion. We know this EKG finding can be indicative of LMCA/LAD stenosis, triple vessel disease, coronary hypoperfusion from hypoxia or hypotension, and other non-occlusive problems. 

HOWEVER - 

These patients, OMI or not, were associated with a 31% in-hospital mortality 😱 compared to only 6.2% in the subgroup of patients with STEMI without elevation in aVR. Woof. 

These patients are sick.

While they may not be having a coronary occlusion warranting emergent cath, there’s a good chance they’re otherwise critical. Evaluate for MI, dissection, PE, stroke, and other major malfunctions without getting tunnel vision. Using clinical picture + history is key in determining initial direction of care. 

Concerned for OMI based on presentation and assessment? Alert cath and let them decide. 

What are your experiences with elevation in aVR + diffuse ST depression?👇🏻

This is personal preference and happens to be my program’s policy. I don’t have evidence to support it being more effective, and I know many providers simply have suction on standby and it works just fine. 

However - I personally find that this small adjustment in practice makes a huge difference in routine intubation attempts.

1️⃣Suction the oropharynx before placing the blade.
2️⃣Suction ahead of the blade to the desired view; suction the glottis.
3️⃣Remove suction and place bougie, or park it on the left if SALAD is needed. 

Why?

👉🏻Almost everyone has something in there. Why not get it out the way?
👉🏻Even small amounts of gunk can complicate views. 
👉🏻Emergency medicine patients are prone to airway nasties (chunks, blood, secretions). 
👉🏻If we thought the airway was clean but were wrong, we may have already clouded our light or camera and put ourselves at a disadvantage.
👉🏻It’s better to have and not need than need and not have. 

Muscle memory is our friend. Leading with suction every time avoids any delay in grasping for it when we decide that we need it this time.

Just my 0.02.

Do not refer to captions for spelling 🥴 Anyway, dopamine does the same things as other vasopressors but with increased risk of tachydysrhythmias and less predictable titrations. Vasopressin may be pressor or choice in hemorrhagic shock, but as always, blood products and an OR are the treatments that save lives. Epi, phenyl, vaso, and norepi can all be used as push-dose pressors, but epi and phenyl are the most common.

Last month, I told you all I was starting therapy - not because of any major issues, but because I’ve come to terms with the fact that my health anxiety isn’t normal.

Did my husband make it where he was going? Did he crash and die? Did my stepkid have a seizure in his sleep and aspirate? Is he going to fall in that bonfire? Is this mild chest discomfort an aortic dissection? Is my husband’s headache an aneurysm? Did my mom’s sugar drop while home alone? Is my dad’s abdominal pain cancer? I’m feeling short of breath - is it a PE? Who will take care of the dogs if I die?

Every. Single. Day. And so many of you said you related. 

Thanks to @emergencyresilience and other fabulous advocates for therapy on this platform, I decided to make the jump. I signed up for BetterHelp. No, this is not an ad. I did it because it’s virtual and easy and you can change therapists as often as you want. No, my therapist does not have a first responder background. Yes, he’s totally capable of handling my shit. 

I didn’t dig the bio of the first therapist I was assigned. I judged a book by its cover and I’m not sorry. I ended up with Randall and he’s fabulous. I know many people have to go therapist-shopping to find the right fit, and I know I got lucky. But we vibe, and I’m sticking with it. 

I feel physically lighter after our sessions. After a couple heavy-hitter appointments, I asked, “what do people talk about in therapy when there are no big issues to address?” And Randall assured me we can just talk about life and the happenings of the last week, and believe you me - there’s always something to dissect. 

We finished session #4 today and I’m already looking forward to #5. 

If you’re thinking about it, make the first move. You won’t regret it.

My medic class just finished their airway module where we talked about this quite a bit: the phenomenon of “ambulance time” where seconds & minutes aren’t as they seem 🥸

⏰That “3 minutes” of preoxygenation? It was 90 seconds. “Why did they desat so fast?”

⏰That ketamine that went in over “2 minutes”? It was 30 seconds. “Why did they go apneic?”

⏰That paralytic waiting period that was “60 seconds”? It was 20. “I can’t pass the tube.”

⏰That intubation attempt that was “30 seconds max”? It was 45. “Why did their sats plummet immediately after?”

⏰That “pretty quick” scene time? It was 35 minutes.

⏰That post-intubation sedation? Oh shit - it’s been 30 minutes. 

In prehospital medicine, we’re doing a lot with a little - lots of multitasking with minimal resources - and it leads to a skewed perception of time. This time warp can lead to unwanted & potentially harmful effects on our patients, but it’s a variable that can be mitigated with appropriate attention:

1️⃣Watch a clock for time-sensitive medications and interventions. Dilute meds to make it easier to deliver slowly. 

2️⃣During intubation, have a partner call out time in whatever manner suits you. We should not be operating on saturations alone, as SpO2 is not real-time. By the time we see a patient hit 90%, they’ve been there for a hot second. 30 seconds is a generally accepted max if the patient has not begun to desat earlier. 

3️⃣Utilize drips when possible to maintain sedation after therapeutic doses have been reached via boluses. This removes the potential to forget during a long transport, especially during paralysis.

4️⃣Consider the use of an IV pump when possible to deliver large medication boluses. An intended 10-minute bolus (amio, mag) can easily turn into 5. The pump can also be used to deliver timed boluses amidst a drip (ketamine, fentanyl, esmolol, etc.). 

5️⃣Communicate with your team. On large incidents or critical patients, communicate timing (just like we do on cardiac arrests) - scene time, time since medication, time preoxygenating - whatever is important to patient care so that everyone is on the same page. 

How do you ward off the ambulance time warp?👇🏻

1️⃣While superficial burns should be assessed, documented, & monitored for progression, only partial- and full-thickness burns count when calculating BSA. Apps like easyTBSA can aid in quick math.

2️⃣20%+ BSA qualifies for fluids to get ahead of third-spacing. This does not happen immediately and thus, it is not necessary to drown our patients on the way to the ER. Excessive fluid resus can result in airway edema, compartment syndrome, & other unnecessary complications. Commonly accepted hourly rates are 500 mL/hr in anyone 14+, 250 mL/hr in kids 6-13, and 125 mL/hr in kids <5 years.

3️⃣Singed facial hair or facial burns are not indicators on their own for intubation. However, these patients should be assessed closely for visible burns or edema in the airway, stridor, hoarseness, altered mental status, etc. Airway management is a priority if any of these new-onset signs are present. Soot in the mouth & burns to the lips should also be considered.

4️⃣SGAs are not an appropriate means of securing the airway of a patient with airway burns when other means are available. Laryngeal/upper airway edema can render a supraglottic device ineffective. ETT or cric is the definitive method.

5️⃣When smoke inhalation inside a closed environment has occurred, consider CO and cyanide poisoning. Supplemental O2 should be administered in these cases, even if SpO2 is normal (both cause cellular hypoxia with normal SpO2 readings). 100% FiO2 should be given if intubated until these mechanisms can be ruled out, and hydroxocobalamin should be considered. Place CO-capable pulse ox probe if available.

6️⃣Burns HURT. Treat pain.

7️⃣Keep patients warm.

8️⃣If treating thermal burns from electrical burns, internal damage often > external damage. Consider potential for cardiac arrhythmias & rhabdo.

9️⃣Know your criteria for burn center transport. Considerations are BSA%, how severe the burns are, where they are (hands, feet, genitalia, face, airway, etc.), patient age, etc. If patient has concurrent multi-system trauma requiring time-sensitive surgical services, transporting to closest-appropriate trauma center (even without burn capability) may be appropriate.

I was talking to a star I dedicated to a pedi patient who the healthcare system failed tonight. (Yeah, I do that). 

If you’ve worked in healthcare long enough, you’ve seen the system fail. A lot. You’ve seen EMS providers provide piss-poor care. You’ve seen nurses fail their patients. You’ve seen physicians contribute to killing patients at all-level facilities.

This is an attack on no one. It’s a reality, and it applies to all of us. 

Like any job, there are people who are great and there are people who are terrible. But in this world, peoples’ lives are at stake. 

I appreciated this working 911, but I appreciate it even more working HEMS with an IFT component and transporting from and to facilities throughout multiple states: pressors disconnected when advised not to followed by an arrest, death or morbidity from irresponsible airway management, refusal to provide appropriate care - the list goes on. From community hospitals to level I institutions. 

The amount of malpractice and negligence that happens on a daily basis in healthcare that patients and families never comprehend is hard to stomach. It’s a huge source of stress in this job. “What would’ve happened if someone else were there?” I know exactly where my family will and will not be transported. I know who they’ll call to oversee my own care if needed. I know where I will and won’t send my friends and family. 

Perhaps we could’ve done better. 
Our coworkers could’ve done better. 
The receiving team could’ve done better. 
And the patient suffered. 

It’s hard. 

Medicine is a practice - but where’s the line between “doing our best” and “should’ve and could’ve done better”?

Care often depends on who’s there that day, and that’s a reality. Being proficient in an ever-changing and dynamic field takes an atrocious amount of work. It’s not fair. But those are the rules. 

So -

Be the person who you’d want to be there for your family.

If we’re choosing to be in this field, we should choose to put in the work. Train. Read. Research. Practice. Don’t stop learning. Embrace criticism. Grow daily. Get better, always. 

Our patients deserve it. They don’t choose us. We choose them.

I was joking with medic students this morning about having an “off day.” A student had an off morning, and so did I. I joked about how at least we’re all in class today - no one’s life is at stake, right? What’s the worst that can happen?

But when we go to treat patients, we don’t have that luxury - a hard pill to swallow. We all get bad nights of sleep. We get a flat tire. We have issues in our personal lives. Our kids get sick. We’re distracted by our loved ones. We’ve gotten our asses kicked at work recently. We might be getting sick. In medicine, what can that mean?

We’re struggling to think clearly about this treatment plan. 

We dropped that vial of med that we need in the aircraft and now we can’t reach it. 

We didn’t pay enough attention to the vent tubing while loading and pulled the tube. 

We forgot to ask about those lab values that matter. 

Our math is slow and questionably accurate.

We forgot to check if the suction was working before the intubation (it wasn’t). 

Our sinuses are going to explode from congestion going over mountains and we’re not focused on the patient. 

We didn’t deliver that news as compassionately as we could have. 

It has consequences. Our jobs matter. Our wellness has a direct impact on our patients and their outcomes.

We can blame the system and our employers all day. Staffing and resource management are very real issues. But we all have an obligation to control what we can. 

Fitness. Nutrition. Sleep. Substance use. ✨Mental health✨. 

There are things we can control, and it’s our responsibility to do so. If we’re going to choose to have a job that impacts people’s lives, we are also choosing to take responsibility for our wellbeing. 

Fuel your body with good. Build strength and mobility. Surround yourself with positivity. Get rid of the expendable negative. Prioritize sleep. Take PTO - it’s yours. Switch employers if you’re miserable (there are good ones). Go to therapy. Take time for you. Fill your cup so that you have something to pour from.

We have a unique privilege to make a difference in human lives. Let go of what you can’t control, and take ownership of what you can. 

Our patients deserve it.

The “chest pain” call: a daily occurrence with a multitude of etiologies. Let’s discuss potential causes & relevant assessments:

CARDIAC & VASCULAR

👉🏻Occlusive MI or non-occlusive MI
👉🏻Angina
👉🏻Blunt cardiac trauma (cardiac contusion)
👉🏻Cardiac tamponade 🎈 
👉🏻Pulmonary embolism ➡️ R heart failure
👉🏻Congestive heart failure
👉🏻Tachydysrhythmias, bradydysrhythmias 💓
👉🏻Takotsubo cardiomyopathy 🐙 
👉🏻Aortic dissection ✂️ 
👉🏻Spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD)
👉🏻Cardiac infection (peri/myo/endocarditis) 🦠 

🧐ASSESS FOR: cardiac history, family history, risk factors, pain radiation, EKG changes, sus vitals, perfusion changes in extremities, fever/recent illness, accompanying symptoms 

⚠️Negative assessment and negative EKG ≠ no problem. 

RESPIRATORY

👉🏻Pulmonary embolism 🫁 
👉🏻Pneumonia/respiratory infection 😷
👉🏻Pneumothorax, hemothorax
👉🏻Pleural effusion
👉🏻Asthma, anxiety, any increased work of breathing 😮‍💨 
👉🏻Pulmonary contusion
👉🏻Pleurisy

🧐ASSESS FOR: respiratory history, recent illness, cough, fever, clotting risk factors, lung sounds, EKG changes, SpO2 and ETCO2, subcutaneous emphysema, accessory muscle use, chest trauma

⚠️PE presentation can mimic “anxiety.” Stay suspicious. 

MUSCULOSKELETAL

👉🏻Sternal or rib trauma 🦴 
👉🏻Chest wall trauma
👉🏻Costochondritis
👉🏻Muscle injury 💪🏻 

🧐ASSESS FOR: recent trauma or strenuous activity, physical abnormalities (bruising, deformities), changes in pain with movement

⚠️Reproducible pain or pain on palpation does not rule out cardiac etiology. 

GASTROINTESTINAL 

👉🏻Acid reflux/GERD 🌶️ 
👉🏻Hiatal hernia

🧐ASSESS FOR: last oral intake, GI history

Understanding basic management of pulmonary artery catheters (i.e. Swan-Ganz cath) is a must in interfacility transport. These catheters (should) sit in the pulmonary artery to provide hemodynamic numbers that can guide in-hospital treatment. 

What do we need to know?

1️⃣Ensure balloon is deflated, appropriate volume-limiting syringe is attached, and port is locked. If air gets into this balloon (shown deflated at tip of 3️⃣), we can inadvertently “wedge” or cause a man-made PE 👎🏻🎈 

2️⃣Transduce the distal PA port to obtain a PA waveform. This allows us to monitor for migration during transport to potentially dangerous locations. A change to a vfib-like PA waveform indicates a move forward to a wedge, and a change to a VT-like PA waveform indicates a move back into the RV, potentially causing a cranky RV as the tip of the catheter whips around. Address appropriately.

3️⃣Ask how placement was confirmed. Distal tip should be in PA and produce a PA waveform. 

4️⃣Assess for insertion depth. Each thin line marks 10 cm, each thick line marks 50 cm. 

5️⃣ is the proximal port that sits in the vena cava. It can be transduced to obtain CVP (often unnecessary during transport) or can be used for infusions. 

The big red port is the thermistor port used for shooting numbers in-hospital (not used by us), and the orange port is for RV pacing/infusions. 

Always inspect insertion site for bleeding, hematoma, appropriate securing, etc.

1️⃣ Choose appropriately sized needle (yellow is safest bet for humeral head in most adults).

2️⃣ Position arm at 90-degree angle over abdomen tightly against body, or place the extended arm against the patient’s body and rotate the hand so the palm is facing outward, thumb down. 

3️⃣ Place your palm on the patient’s anterior shoulder; press down firmly in larger patients. Feel for “ball” under palm. This is general target area. The spot where the “ball” meets the “tee” is the surgical neck - insertion site should be 1-2 cm above this. 

4️⃣ Point the needle at a 45-degree angle to the anterior plane and posteromedial. Press the needle into the skin until it hits bone. Ensure at least one black line is visible above skin (if it’s not, needle is too short). 

5️⃣ Apply firm pressure and drill until “relief” is felt as the needle enters the medullary space. This can be done manually in event of drill failure by grasping the hub, pressing firmly and twisting back and forth. 

6️⃣ Attach primed extension set and flush with oomph; evaluate for signs of extravasation. Consider flushing with lidocaine if patient is responsive to pain.

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is a common cause of respiratory illness in kids, especially during the 🥶 months. This year feels especially bad - anyone else?

Mild symptoms include stuffy/runny nose, sore throat, cough, fever, & poor feeding. ‘Tis a common cold 🦠 

However, many of us are seeing the sicker kids: those who progress to bronchiolitis or pneumonia. These kiddos may present with ⬆️ work of breathing, tachypnea, retractions, hypoxia, wheezing, lethargy, & dehydration from poor feeding (fewer wet diapers, tachycardia). 

Primary treatment involves supporting oxygenation & ventilation at whatever level patient condition dictates:

1️⃣ Supplemental O2 via blow-by, NRB
2️⃣ Supplemental flow & O2 via high-flow nasal cannula (AirVo, VapoTherm, etc.)
3️⃣ CPAP/BiPAP
4️⃣ Intubation

In the prehospital environment, intubation is rarely indicated for RSV. Ventilation & oxygenation should be supported via supplemental O2, NIV if available, or BVM with PEEP if indicated. 

🚑PEARLS:

👉🏻Assess closely for ⬆️ work of breathing: grunting, nasal flaring, retractions, other accessory muscle use, tachypnea. Watch for tiring & progression to respiratory failure. 
👉🏻Utilize nasal suction in snotty kids who rely on their snoot for ventilation. 
👉🏻Other siblings or household members have been sick. Ask. 
👉🏻Some kiddos need a reminder to breathe. Physical stimulation or PPV assistance can provide the reminder en route to ER. 
👉🏻HR can drop precipitously in presence of even brief hypoxia. Ensure oxygenation & ventilation are adequately supported. 
👉🏻Seizures may occur from rapid spike in temp or from other infection complications. 
👉🏻Check glucose. Sick kiddos churn through glucose, especially when not feeding well. They may need a little bump 🍩 
👉🏻Check hydrations status. Ask about feeding & wet diapers. A fluid bolus is frequently indicated (urgently if child is showing signs of shock). 
👉🏻New moms may have received RSV 💉 during pregnancy. Ask.
👉🏻Check 👶🏻 temp frequently & keep kiddos warm. Itsy bitsies lose heat like you lose that pen in your pocket. 

What have your experiences been with RSV this season?👇🏻

Sources below.

Nothing in medicine is black and white, and there is a subset of RSV patients who may benefit from bronchodilators - notably, those with a history of asthma or reactive airway disease. 

However, there is no good evidence that routine bronchodilators improve outcomes in these patients; any wheezing is likely due to mucus, not bronchospastic airways. Rather, we may increase an already elevated HR, and there is some evidence that albuterol may increase time on supplemental O2 and length of stay. The same limited evidence for improved outcomes applies to steroids. 

So, suction the gunk. Support increased work of breathing with humidified flow (HFNC, NIV as indicated). Delivering non-humidified high-flow O2 can result in a “crusty booger cake,” as @foamfrat says. Hydrate. Check glucose, support as needed.

PICU/peds ER/peds transport friends - when and how do you utilize bronchodilators and steroids in RSV?

It’s a privilege to be asked into strangers’ lives on their worst days. It’s an honor to be present for life and for death. We see people at their worst, their sickest, their most vulnerable. Sometimes we see them at their best. We are often the last option when humans feel they have nowhere else to turn. We see their messy bedrooms, their soiled bathrooms, their lived-in vehicles, their uncared-for bodies. We see embarrassment and humiliation and addictions and vices. We’re given authority, whether we deserve it or not. We’re given trust that isn’t earned. We see mental illness, physical ailments, emotional trauma. We don’t see so much more: the upbringings, the abuse, the rape, the assault, the lack of parental presence, the mental illness, the loss, the chronic pain, the miscarriage, the infertility, the fear, the mental illness, the physical and emotional and spiritual trauma. We have the opportunity to make assumptions or to offer the benefit of the doubt. To perceive system abuse or a lack of viable options. To see drug-seeking behaviors or a broken mental and physical health system. To take hostility personally or to see the hurting human being. To make a big difference via small human gestures or to become hardened and callous. 

We complain about the pay, the hours, the profession - they all have valid space for advocacy and betterment. But do not forget the unique privilege this job provides us. The ability to embrace the privilege rather than the burden over time, and to see what we all have to lose, is a honed skill that fosters longevity and resilience.

We choose this job, but our patients do not choose us. Be the person you’d want to show up for your loved one.

I almost canceled this week’s therapy session. I was feeling good, didn’t have much to address, thought it could wait a week. But I didn’t, because even when there’s not much to chat about, I always get something out of it. Mental health ✨maintenance✨. 

Then I had a pedi trauma at work that was especially not fun. It hit multiple nerves that caused a lot of yuck on a personal level.

I talked to my friendworkers about it. I had a good cry into my husband’s shirt. My people were as amazing and supportive as ever, and they were everything I needed them to be.

I don’t want to be married to or friends with impartial, personally disconnected therapists who are trained to ask specific questions to get to the root of a feeling and peel back onion layers. I love paying for it, though. Take my money. I could not wait for today. 

Today’s session was hard. The onion effect was real. I didn’t entirely realize why I was feeling the way I was until I was forced to dive deep, and it was uncomfy. But that’s where the work is done, so I’m told. 

In the first 16 years of my career, this flight would’ve landed as just another yucky call. One that would’ve been vented about initially then rarely discussed ever again. I would’ve been “totally fine” without acknowledging the downstream effects these experiences were having on my anxious, hypervigilant, and catastrophizing mentality, all while quietly suffering the consequences. 

Suffer less. Consider therapy.

Prehospital medicine is a constantly evolving field that moves faster in some places than in others. We owe it to our patients to find and to use the best tools, the best medications, and the best algorithms. 

However - one constant in emergency medicine is that doing the basics well is what saves the most lives. 

Excellent BLS airway and ventilation management. Bleeding control. Perfusion support. Rapid defibrillation. A thorough, efficient, and accurate rapid assessment. Identification and reversal of immediate life-threats. The ability to decipher an accurate clinical picture. Rapid transport to appropriate definitive care.

Even most departments that would be described as having a “limited scope” enable their providers to do these things. 

Prehospital RSI (and intubation in general) rarely saves lives. We had long happy EMS careers before ketamine was a thing. Ultrasound has a helpful place in cardiac arrest, and maybe to identify lung sliding, but no one is saved by a prehospital FAST exam that was questionably accurate and doesn’t rule-out bleeding anyway. TXA is not a magic bullet. Hypertonic saline is a bandaid for patients who really need oxygenation, perfusion, and definitive care. Blood products are fabulous, but it’s a finite resource and not currently feasible for every unit to be equipped. 

The point: we can and should advocate for our departments to have the safest and most effective options available. However, we should not be discouraged by a lack of bells and whistles. 

Doing the basics well is what saves the most lives. Do them with excellence. The rest is a bonus.

“Make me a patient” is an activity I’ve been doing with paramedic classes for years. Students may secretly hate me for it, but it makes them think through patient presentations and conditions in a different way. It can be used for any educational topic once they’ve established a decent foundation.

For example:

1️⃣ Make me a patient who requires synchronized cardioversion at 100J. 

Sample answer: “Dispatched for a 22 y/o female complaining of sudden onset palpitations, diaphoresis and shortness of breath. Presents with pallor, tachypnea, and a BP of 78/54. HR 220. SVT on monitor. Patient has no other significant medical history. Is synchronized cardioverted x 1 at 100J with successful conversion to normal sinus rhythm.” (Can ask them to google a matching EKG as well 🤓). 

2️⃣ Make me a patient who requires nitro and BiPAP. 

Sample answer: “Dispatched for a 65 y/o male with difficulty breathing x 3 hours. He’s tripoding and dyspneic on arrival with a RA sat of 78%. Audible rales noted. BP 210/105, HR 132, RR 26, ETCO2 25 and square. 12-lead shows sinus tach with occasional PVCs. Patient is given nitro SL and placed on BiPAP at 10/5 with improvement in oxygenation to 90% and decrease in work of breathing.”

3️⃣ Make me a patient who requires 0.2 mg epi IM.

Sample answer: “Dispatched for a 5 y/o (20 kg) female who presents with sudden onset GI distress after eating lunch at a birthday party. She presents pale with a BP of 70/52, has hives developing on her chest, has been incontinent of feces and has vomited x 2. Lung sounds are clear. Fluid bolus initiated after epi, symptoms begin to improve within several minutes.”

There is no single correct answer, and students can get as creative as they want as long as they make clinical sense. Scenarios are presented and discussed as a class, and any necessary modifications or additions can be reviewed. I allow students to use any resources they want to get to the most thorough answers. At least one of us enjoys it 🙃

Educators - what are your favorite critical thinking activities?👇🏻

Multisystem trauma patient with TBI. Upon arrival, ground crew getting ready to do all the hard work, but sadly, we brought the bad juju with us. Precipitous drop in BP into 60’s-70’s. SpO2 unable to be sustained in 90’s despite thumbs-down + jaw thrust 2-person BVM, PEEP valve, NC, all the O’s, and great ETCO2 waveform. Airway fairly clean. 

Decision made that even a quick ETT attempt would result in rapid desaturation due to lack of reserve (especially detrimental in presence of increased ICP). iGel placed without apneic period, transitioned to ventilator. 

During flight:

Blood🩸 
Hypertonic🧂 
Needle decompression💉 
Additional IO access🔫
Norepi drip after phenyl pushes💧

Patient delivered with a SBP in the 120’s, a normalized HR, and an SpO2 of 98%. Did they get a tube in the ER? Absolutely.

BUT -

Patient had been well-oxygenated and well-perfused for several minutes prior to medications and apneic period, and it was tolerated without issue. 

Most importantly, it’s what was best for the patient. 

After any busy flight, there’s a list of things I wish I would have considered or done differently - this one is no exception. I’m far from a perfect provider, and thank baby Jesus for my fabulous partners. What’s not on that list: going straight for an iGel.

Patient before ego.

“I’ve only posted about this trial 17x 🤦” -@armyemdoc 

Go check out his posts, but if you also missed some of the interesting details, there’s some food for thought buried in here (see second pic):

The trial was comparing first-pass success of VL vs. DL. It’s no surprise that VL won. 

But, amongst the 1417 patients and 387 intubators (91% of which were EM residents or critical care fellows), average attempt time was 38 seconds in the VL group and 46 seconds in the DL group. ✨38 seconds in VL✨

These intubations happened in hospitals. With light. And space. And help. And tables that go up and down. 

The documented times are also from initiation of laryngoscopy to intubation of the trachea. I’d argue we should be timing ventilation to ventilation in practice, since the apneic period is what matters. Time to intubation is irrelevant if we spend 10 extra seconds inflating the cuff and fumbling to attach the BVM. 

What would our results be in the field if we timed a thousand attempts? 

We regularly time peoples’ attempts in sim training, and I do the same for paramedic students. It’s quite often longer than 30 seconds, and always longer than the provider thinks (myself included 🙋🏻‍♀️). 

The takeaways?

1️⃣Practice excessively. Muscle memory is key. 
2️⃣Watch a clock in training and in practice. The EMS time warp is real. 
3️⃣Recognize that many patients requiring prehospital intubation cannot tolerate 30+ seconds of apnea. Pivot care as needed. Sats drop in an exponential fashion - a slow drop will quickly turn into a fast one. 

Do you routinely time intubation attempts in training and/or in practice?👇🏻

Our drug boxes are full of potential murder weapons if we don’t use them correctly. When it comes to sedation and analgesia in spontaneously breathing patients (ketamine, fentanyl, benzos, etc.), airway monitoring and management is key.

CLARIFICATION: There was no medical fault in this case. The point is that ketamine doesn’t kill people - uncorrected side effects do. Let’s all help mitigate the fear-mongering headlines and responsibly monitor our sedated patients. 

1️⃣Apply ETCO2 early. This is a real-time visual representation of how the patient is ventilating. 

2️⃣Monitor SpO2, but recognize that there is a delay in readings. 

3️⃣Assess the patient. Like actually look at them (not just the iPad and the monitor). Watch for chest rise and fall. 

Anticipate issues and be prepared to fix them. This could mean opening an airway, providing stimulation, applying O2, giving a few temporary BVM breaths, or in rarer cases, providing prolonged ventilation and intubation. There is no excuse for missing a complication that should be expected and can be immediately addressed.

Sedate responsibly 😴

I spent an entire therapy session talking about imposter syndrome today. My nurse partner totally carried me on a sick scene last week when I wasn’t on my A game. I wasn’t tired, I wasn’t sick, I just didn’t perform great. I didn’t like that.

I busted my ass to prepare for this job. I spent over a decade on the ground and stuffed my brain with knowledge. I had a successful orientation. I do well most of the time.

But I regularly fear not meeting the self-concocted expectations of others in my work life. I try to keep the IG pedestal low here by sharing my mistakes & failures & struggles. It’s absolutely insane to me that thousands of people from all over the world care about what I have to say, and the last thing I want is for anyone here to overestimate my abilities. I’m not the best clinician or the smartest provider. I have so many coworkers who are better at their jobs than I am. I’ve made some big mistakes in my career; I still make them, they’re just different now. I have off days and off weeks. Sometimes my partner carries my weight.

Therapist: “No need to be humble. If you could rate yourself on a scale as a medic - average, good, very good, excellent - how would you rate yourself?”

“Good to very good.” We discussed shortcomings & mistakes that make me feel less than excellent. He asked if I would automatically consider someone else not-excellent for those same mistakes, to which obviously the answer was no, because ✨double standards✨. 

“So why then don’t you consider yourself excellent?”

“Because if you consider yourself excellent, there’s little room to grow.”

And he said this mentality is probably what makes me good at my job, and he’s probably right. 

So, fellow imposters, use self-doubt to your advantage. Stay humble. Find areas for improvement & get better. Evolve. Train. Grow. Always be open to new information and new ways of doing things. Absorb other peoples’ knowledge and expertise. Be okay with being wrong. Put patient care before ego. 

But be confident enough to put those gains to work. Patients cannot benefit from our care if we’re too timid to speak up or provide it.

You’ve put in the work, now put it to work. And pass it on.

Working in emergency medicine creates a personal, ever-filling cemetery: the elder and expected, the young and tragic, the tiny and difficult to process, those that mix and match. Some deaths come and go without difficulty; others are profoundly striking and leave their mark. Some are visually scarring — broken bodies, burnt bodies, decompensated bodies who had no one to find them. Others are emotionally scarring — distraught partners of decades, wailing parents, sobbing children, dead children. Graves are marked by loved ones’ stages of grief — anger, denial, sadness, bargaining, acceptance — sometimes taken out on us, sometimes soothed by us. They’re surrounded by no one and few and many. Their stories read “suicide” and “drunk driving” and “overdose” and “heart attack.” For some, we know we did enough. For others, we wish we could’ve done more. We mourn for patients and their loved ones, and our loved ones who we’re reminded of. Sometimes we’re angry. Sad. Filled with uncertainty. Most importantly, we’re reminded of what we have to lose. 

Go visit if you need to. We’re allowed to leave.

CPR-induced consciousness (CPRIC) is gaining increasing attention in the prehospital world. While we still don’t have enough data to know which treatment option is best, we have acknowledged that the humane thing to do is do something. 

As a reminder, CPRIC occurs when a pulseless patient is being so well-perfused by artificial compressions that they show signs of life. This can range from small movements and eye opening to verbalizations and full consciousness. In some cases, patient consciousness interferes with resuscitation (grabbing at providers and tubes, etc.). 

When compressions are stopped, the patient returns to a pulseless, unconscious state. This can lead to a false sense of ROSC amongst providers and continuous interruptions in resuscitative efforts. 

You all regularly send me your guidelines for this and I LOVE it. Please add yours in the comments👇🏻

A 2022 review (cited below) examined 23 prehospital CPRIC guidelines (plus one good practice statement) and found that Midazolam is the most frequently used drug to offer sedation (61%), followed by ketamine (48%) and fentanyl (39%). 

“But won’t we cause hypotension!?“

1. They’re already pulseless. 2. We’re likely counteracting any pharmacological effects with our atrocious doses of cardiac arrest epi. 

Now - is there a “best option” for optimizing hemodynamics during a cardiac arrest and upon subsequent ROSC? Possibly. We don’t know yet. Stay tuned. 

But if I’m ever awake during an active resuscitation, y’all better send a ketamine blow dart ASAP 🎯 

⚠️: Note that CPR-induced ✨awareness✨ can occur without any signs of consciousness (😱) - @emergencyresilience has some great posts on the topic. 

• • • • •

📚 Jack Howard, Carlos Lipscombe, Bronwyn Beovich, Matthew Shepherd, Eystein Grusd, Nikiah G. Nudell, Don Rice, Alexander Olaussen,
Pre-hospital guidelines for CPR-Induced Consciousness (CPRIC): A scoping review,
Resuscitation Plus, Volume 12, 2022, 100335, ISSN 2666-5204, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.resplu.2022.100335.
(https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2666520422001357)

Is this clip CPR-induced consciousness or consciousness-induced consciousness? Unclear. But alas, the phenomenon does exist, and conveniently, one of the authors of this 🔥hot off the press🔥 Delphi study popped into the comments of yesterday’s post. Published less than a month ago, this study used an expert panel to create an international prehospital consensus definition of CPRIC, a management guideline (clear preference toward ketamine), and a data reporting framework.

More data needed, but this is a fabulous start. Don’t yet have a guideline? Advocate for one before you need it. 

Go check it out.

📚: Howard J, Grusd E, Rice D, et al. Development of an international prehospital CPR-induced consciousness guideline: A Delphi study. Paramedicine. 2023;0(0). doi:10.1177/27536386231215608

In a complete heart block, a complete separation between the atria and the ventricles has occurred. The atria are still working (firing P waves, or more rarely, other atrial arrhythmias), but the impulses can’t advance to the ventricles. 

So, something has to save the day: either the junction or the ventricles. If a junctional escape rhythm takes over, the QRS will be narrow and may be responsive to atropine (vagus nerve fibers innervate the AV node). If a ventricular escape rhythm takes over, the QRS will be wide and is likely to require pacing or epi if unstable. 

This rhythm is simply “normal” P waves (usually) that go nowhere + an escape rhythm from somewhere below to stave off death. Ps will march out at regular intervals - as will QRSs - but there is no communication between the two. There is often overlap and P waves will be buried within QRS complexes. 

In the marriage analogy of AV blocks, this is where husband and wife are separated but living in the same house. Husband comes and goes, wife comes and goes, but there’s no communication. Any overlap is simply coincidence. 

Stable? No cable. We treat the patient’s poor perfusion secondary to rate, not our puckered buttholes. 12-lead. Supportive care. Prepare for deterioration. 

Unstable? Pacing or meds. 

• • • • •

📚: Knabben V, Chhabra L, Slane M. Third-Degree Atrioventricular Block. [Updated 2023 Jul 31]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2023 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK545199/

📚: Yanagisawa Y, Ibrahim W, Kumar N. A case of atrial fibrillation complicated by complete atrioventricular block. SAGE Open Med Case Rep. 2023 Feb 27;11:2050313X231157486. doi: 10.1177/2050313X231157486. PMID: 36866023; PMCID: PMC9972045.
