Electrolytes tend to be some of the most confusing meds in our drug box. Let’s chat. 

MAGNESIUM:

👉🏻Preeclampsia (if protocols allow) or eclampsia for seizure prophylaxis.
👉🏻Torsades or other arrhythmias associated with a long QTc. Mag is a wonderful antiarrhythmic (calcium channel blocker) that doesn’t prolong QTc and risk worsening these rhythms. 
👉🏻Asthma. Mag is a smoother muscle relaxer and thus can aid in bronchodilation. 
👉🏻Preterm labor. This isn’t a typical prehospital indication, but given the right circumstances, calling med control for orders may be appropriate. 

CALCIUM (GLUCONATE OR CHLORIDE):

👉🏻Calcium channel blocker toxicity (including mag). May override calcium channel blockade and assist with inotropy. 
👉🏻Hyperkalemia with EKG changes (traumatic and atraumatic). While calcium does nothing to actually fix hyperK, it does temporarily protect the heart from its effects. Calcium can be the bandaid that wards off deterioration and/or death until we get to where it can be addressed with insulin and other more aggressive measures. 
👉🏻During/after blood product administration. Blood products have citrate in them which binds to calcium (rendering it ineffective) to inhibit clotting. Good in the bag, bad in the body. May be given after several units (protocols vary) to counteract any excess citrate that hasn’t been metabolized by the liver/body. 

BICARB:

👉🏻Sodium channel blocker (including TCA) toxicity with EKG changes. May override sodium channel blockade. 
👉🏻Brain herniation. Some agencies that don’t carry hypertonic saline will substitute bicarb for the same purpose: water follows salt, and hypertonic solutions can be a bandaid to transiently reduce ICP. 

⚠️: Bicarb for hyperK is controversial and questionably effective. 

How does your agency or department use these meds?👇🏻

@okmedicpodcast shared a super unique dissection case today (go check it out on his page 🤓) which obviously caught my eye because I LOVE dissections. Not for our patients, of course, but I find the pathophysiology and presentations utterly fascinating. 

⚠️: While dissections ✂️ and aneurysms 🎈can occur together, they are not the same. 

In an aortic dissection, the inner layer of the aorta tears away, creating a false lumen for blood flow. This false lumen can extend into and impede blood flow to essentially any area that branches off from the main aorta: arms (subclavians), legs (iliacs, femorals), brain (carotids), heart (coronary arteries), kidneys, spinal cord…

And of course, it can rupture. 

Depending on the original location, severity, and extension of the dissection, presentations can vary significantly. Here are 19 of your dissection patient presentations. Add yours👇🏻

In an acute CHF exacerbation (sometimes referred to as SCAPE - sympathetic crashing acute pulmonary edema), the sad left ventricle 😢 is not moving volume forward adequately amidst systemic vasoconstriction. Pressure backs up into the lungs, forcing fluid into the alveoli. These patients often present hypertensive and hypoxic with wet lungs and significantly increased work of breathing. 

🚑Management pearls:

1️⃣Support oxygenation and ventilation via BiPAP if available. BiPAP provides inspiratory support via pressure support to aid work of breathing while supporting oxygenation via PEEP. CPAP is an acceptable alternative to assist with oxygenation (PEEP without pressure support). Responsible benzo dosing may be helpful in aiding tolerance. 

2️⃣Reduce afterload with ✨aggressive✨ nitro ASAP. Amidst hypertension, the already-sad LV has to try and pump blood out against significant vascular resistance (afterload), worsening failure. Nitro reduces the heart’s workload by lowering both preload (the amount of blood the LV has to move) and afterload (the resistance it has to pump out against), allowing edema to redistribute appropriately. 

1️⃣ & 2️⃣ are keys to staving off intubation in a patient who does not yet need it. 

3️⃣Get the 12-lead. While chronic CHFers may be experiencing a non-ischemic exacerbation from another trigger, it’s always possible it was triggered in any patient by an MI. Find it early. 

🙅🏻‍♀️Lasix is not a life-saving drug in the acute phase of SCAPE and has been removed from many prehospital protocols. Not all SCAPE patients are hypervolemic - they may just have volume in the wrong place. 

🙅🏻‍♀️Albuterol and atrovent are not helpful in the setting of flash pulmonary edema. There are always gray areas involving patients who also have a history of COPD or asthma and may have mixed presentations, but it should not be given routinely to these patients without reason. 

📚Sources in comments.

Annual reminder that if you or your patients have chronic pain and regularly use a heating pad in the same spot (🙋🏻‍♀️) - or routinely use heated car seats - you may see this rash. 

Erythema ab igne is characterized by this reticulated pattern of hyperpigmentation and is caused by repeated exposure (usually weeks to years) to heat or infrared radiation. Exposure is usually via heating pad or occupational tasks, but can occur from electronics (repeatedly having a hot laptop on lap), space heaters, virtual headsets, car seats, etc. 

While the rash is usually benign, it does carry risk of becoming malignant. It may resolve with removal of heat source over time, but some changes may persist. Regular skin exams are recommended. 

Shoutout to TikTok for teaching me this last year and explaining the rash on the back of my legs from using heated car seats year-round 🫠

• • • • •

My partner and I recently walked in to an about-to-happen intubation. The patient had received induction meds and was being ventilated via BVM. Patient had a history of COPD (presumed poor reserve) and was satting in the 80’s.

BVM ventilations were being provided by a single provider standing at the side rather than at the head without an adequate mask seal, and without a nasal cannula. We switched to a 2-person technique as shown (mask seal always at the head, second person squeezing from the side), and within 5-10 breaths, the patient had a sat of 99%. 

Basic BVMing and airway techniques are probably one of the most under-appreciated - but most important - skills we have. A good mask seal and jaw thrust (in addition to optimal positioning) can work wonders. 

If we’re doing it right, this technique is a hand workout; practice regularly and implement. The results won’t disappoint.
How else can we not make patients worse? Add yours👇🏻

This is a topic that’s been popping up on my feed and in my DMs for a while now, and I’ve struggled to wrap my head around the “controversy.” So last night I did some googling and found a fabulous @foamfrat article that sums it up perfectly - go check it out. Foamfrat.com ➡️ “Hypoglycemia in cardiac arrest” by Sam Ireland (2023). Tons of great references listed. 

You have a known or suspected hypoglycemic arrest with a recent last seen well time. Maybe they intentionally or unintentionally overdosed on insulin. Are you going to NOT check their sugar? If it’s low, are you going to NOT treat it?

Saying no to either of these seems totally asinine to me - and yet, the practice of not checking glucose in cardiac arrest is a thing. 

What are the arguments?

“Glucose isn’t accurate in cardiac arrest.” Okay, sure, it’s not ideal. But if it reads “lo,” is it actually 300? Probably not. Use venous blood for extra warm and fuzzies. Glucose checks aren’t the most accurate in your cold shocky unresponsive patient on the side of the road either, but we still check it. 

“Hypoglycemia isn’t a reversible cause of cardiac arrest.” AHA removed this from the adult Hs & Ts years ago quietly with minimal explanation (and yet, it still remains in the pediatric list 👀). The “evidence” for this isn’t convincing enough to just ignore the problem altogether (IMO). If that’s the case, why would we even work a hypoglycemic code to begin with? Because we didn’t check the glucose so we don’t know they’re hypoglycemic? It feels silly. 

“Hyperglycemia worsens outcomes in cardiac arrest with ROSC.” Sure. No one is saying that we should throw dextrose at every arrest. This is like saying we should withhold oxygen from a hypoxic patient due to risk of hyperoxia. The risks are not samesies. If the glucose is low, we know that’s a problem. Why wouldn’t we treat it?

There are definitely a number of outdated cardiac arrest practices that carry a risk of patient harm, but I just can’t get on board with putting this one in the same category (yet). 

What do you think?👇🏻

Guys this book from @eddyjoemd is so great 🤩 I’ve only skimmed and cherry-picked some of my areas of interest thus far and am already so impressed. Simple and to-the-point (totally my jam), but wouldn’t expect anything less from a guy with 10-minute podcast episodes 😅👌🏻 Anyway, it’s on Amazon and it’s Lily-approved. Enjoy.

AV BLOCKS ALGORITHM. I’m a big fan of understanding the “why” behind EKGs rather than memorizing characteristics, but a student brought a version of this chart to me recently from the interwebs and I have to admit - I can see its utility. While we should certainly strive to learn and teach the “why” behind AV blocks (and EKGs and medicine in general), this chart can be a great tool to help confirm basic diagnosis (especially for paramedic students on tests!). Hope it helps someone somewhere get an extra rhythm right 🤓
